description: In this series, you will learn how to write a PowerShell script. We will cover the different components that make up a PowerShell script. We look at variables, arrays and hash tables. We look at comparison operators, logical operators, assignment and arithmetic operators. We look at and constructs, including if, switch, for, foreach, do and while. We will also look at creating a script module.
descriptionMD: In this series, you will learn how to write a PowerShell script. We will cover the different components that make up a PowerShell script. We look at variables, arrays and hash tables. We look at comparison operators, logical operators, assignment and arithmetic operators. We look at and constructs, including if, switch, for, foreach, do and while. We will also look at creating a script module.
name: PowerShell Scripting
subtitle: Writing scripts using the PowerShell language

episodes.description: In this series, you will learn how to write a PowerShell script. We will cover the different components that make up a PowerShell script. We look at variables, arrays and hash tables. We look at comparison operators, logical operators, assignment and arithmetic operators. We look at and constructs, including if, switch, for, foreach, do and while. We will also look at creating a script module.
episodes.title: Overview

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Cherokee start with a look at using PowerShell ISE. Then they begin their discussion on variables and data types.
episodes.title: Working with Variables
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:01.523
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.523 --> 00:00:02.313
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.313 --> 00:00:06.498
>> [CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.498 --> 00:00:08.355
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.355 --> 00:00:11.957
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:11.957 --> 00:00:15.155
>> Welcome, ladies and gentlemen to
your PowerShell scripting series.

7
00:00:15.155 --> 00:00:17.005
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

8
00:00:17.005 --> 00:00:20.985
In this episode, we will specifically be
looking at how to work with variables.

9
00:00:20.985 --> 00:00:24.215
And with us today back in
studio we have Mr Mike Rodrick.

10
00:00:24.215 --> 00:00:25.190
How's the going today, Mike?

11
00:00:25.190 --> 00:00:26.125
>> It's going great here, Cherokee.

12
00:00:26.125 --> 00:00:28.651
Thanks for having me and
excited to be here as always.

13
00:00:28.651 --> 00:00:31.938
And yeah, we're gonna take a look at
as we get in into scripting here,

14
00:00:31.938 --> 00:00:34.300
we're gonna start out
talking about variables.

15
00:00:34.300 --> 00:00:38.480
Cuz variables are gonna be something that
we're gonna need as we go through and

16
00:00:38.480 --> 00:00:41.790
we start writing our scripts,
we're gonna need variables.

17
00:00:41.790 --> 00:00:44.410
And many types of variables, and
we're kind of break them down and

18
00:00:44.410 --> 00:00:46.130
look at where we're gonna use those.

19
00:00:46.130 --> 00:00:49.810
But I thought that'd be a good place to
start for today is looking at how we work

20
00:00:49.810 --> 00:00:54.610
with variables, how we assign values to
them, things like that within PowerShell.

21
00:00:54.610 --> 00:00:56.540
>> Okay, cool.
Are there any variables that to

22
00:00:56.540 --> 00:00:59.880
get used more often or would you
say are more important than others?

23
00:00:59.880 --> 00:01:02.933
>> No, it depends on the situation,
they're very handy.

24
00:01:02.933 --> 00:01:04.559
Let's define a variable first.

25
00:01:04.559 --> 00:01:08.236
For some of you that might be newer
to scripting of any kind of language.

26
00:01:08.236 --> 00:01:09.837
And when we talk about a variable,

27
00:01:09.837 --> 00:01:13.050
a variable is a, I like to think of
it as a storage container, right?

28
00:01:13.050 --> 00:01:16.380
It's somewhere that I can store a value,
and

29
00:01:16.380 --> 00:01:21.400
then recall that information later on,
or I can manipulate that information.

30
00:01:21.400 --> 00:01:25.420
Like if we wanna store the name
of a computer, or a value,

31
00:01:25.420 --> 00:01:30.610
an IP address, or
a numeric value of some kind, or a string,

32
00:01:30.610 --> 00:01:34.936
we can store these invariables and we can
call them back later when we need them.

33
00:01:34.936 --> 00:01:38.820
Rather than I had to go through
the process of getting that IP address or

34
00:01:38.820 --> 00:01:39.460
something like that.

35
00:01:39.460 --> 00:01:43.362
So let's think of variables as just
containers that we can store these

36
00:01:43.362 --> 00:01:44.710
values in.

37
00:01:44.710 --> 00:01:48.905
Now with PowerShell, if you're familiar
with other languages,whether it's

38
00:01:48.905 --> 00:01:53.330
scripting language or not, you're gonna
understand the concept of variable.

39
00:01:53.330 --> 00:01:57.131
But every language kind of does things
a little bit differently, right,

40
00:01:57.131 --> 00:02:00.515
as far as how you declare variables,
how we make them available.

41
00:02:00.515 --> 00:02:04.440
We'll have to look at scope at some point,
but we might save that until we get more

42
00:02:04.440 --> 00:02:08.180
into functions, we'll probably keep
it kind of straightforward for now.

43
00:02:08.180 --> 00:02:10.308
So let's talk about, but
before we can get in to variables,

44
00:02:10.308 --> 00:02:11.953
we're gonna need somewhere to work, right.

45
00:02:11.953 --> 00:02:16.824
And if you've watched our previous series,
PowerShell basics, I think we ended

46
00:02:16.824 --> 00:02:20.942
up calling it, this will be,
hopefully a bit of a refresher for you.

47
00:02:20.942 --> 00:02:23.660
We're gonna be working primarily in

48
00:02:23.660 --> 00:02:26.030
the PowerShell Integrated
Scripting Environment, or

49
00:02:26.030 --> 00:02:29.470
the ISE because it's so
easier to write scripts in there.

50
00:02:29.470 --> 00:02:34.049
Because we have that upper script pane
where we can write commands without having

51
00:02:34.049 --> 00:02:36.759
them execute automatically
when we hit enter.

52
00:02:36.759 --> 00:02:38.570
So that's where we'll be
spending a lot of time.

53
00:02:38.570 --> 00:02:41.065
So let's start by looking at that and

54
00:02:41.065 --> 00:02:43.940
re-familiarizing ourselves
with that environment.

55
00:02:43.940 --> 00:02:45.531
So let's take a look at my screen here.

56
00:02:45.531 --> 00:02:49.114
I'm just on a client machine,
a Windows 10 machine, and

57
00:02:49.114 --> 00:02:54.470
I'm gonna run the ISE as administrator cuz
I right clicked on the PowerShell icon.

58
00:02:54.470 --> 00:02:58.540
The PowerShell ISE,
if you go to your Start menu and

59
00:02:58.540 --> 00:03:03.060
you start typing in PowerShell, you'll
see that it does show up PowerShell ISE.

60
00:03:03.060 --> 00:03:07.890
We don't have the, jst trying to think,
they're starting to change it.

61
00:03:07.890 --> 00:03:11.030
It used to be a separate icon
that we would put down there.

62
00:03:11.030 --> 00:03:15.289
Now they're really saying just
right-click on the PowerShell icon and

63
00:03:15.289 --> 00:03:19.770
choose ISE with Windows 10 and
some of the later versions of Windows 10.

64
00:03:19.770 --> 00:03:22.833
But the ISE is definitely not going away,
don't get me wrong.

65
00:03:22.833 --> 00:03:26.373
It's just that getting to it, a lot of
times on some of these newer versions

66
00:03:26.373 --> 00:03:29.691
of Windows 10, some of these later builds,
you type Powershell and

67
00:03:29.691 --> 00:03:33.540
you don't even see ISE coming up on
your menu, all you see is Powershell.

68
00:03:33.540 --> 00:03:35.896
If that's the case,
just right click on it, and

69
00:03:35.896 --> 00:03:39.645
you should see the option to launch ISE or
just type it all the way out, right.

70
00:03:39.645 --> 00:03:43.750
Type Powershell, or Windows Powershell ISE
in your start menu and

71
00:03:43.750 --> 00:03:45.600
you should be able to find it.

72
00:03:45.600 --> 00:03:47.854
So here we've got the integrated
scripting environment.

73
00:03:47.854 --> 00:03:53.660
It might start out something more like
this where it's just the console pane.

74
00:03:53.660 --> 00:03:55.890
Remember, this is a host for
PowerShell, right?

75
00:03:55.890 --> 00:04:00.483
We don't interact directly with
PowerShell, I know that's a weird concept.

76
00:04:00.483 --> 00:04:04.290
But PowerShell is an engine
that runs in the background.

77
00:04:04.290 --> 00:04:08.715
We use hosts to connect to that engine,
we don't connect directly to

78
00:04:08.715 --> 00:04:13.895
powershell.exe right, we have these hosts,
we have our console host.

79
00:04:13.895 --> 00:04:17.637
We have this, the Integrated Scripting
Environment, Active Directory,

80
00:04:17.637 --> 00:04:21.095
Administrative center,
would be another PowerShell host, right.

81
00:04:21.095 --> 00:04:24.068
Because it connects to that PowerShell
engine in the background and

82
00:04:24.068 --> 00:04:25.605
executes those commands.

83
00:04:25.605 --> 00:04:28.909
So this is one of our hosts, the ISE,
and it starts out looking like this.

84
00:04:28.909 --> 00:04:30.720
And this is just a normal console,

85
00:04:30.720 --> 00:04:33.660
just like if I was to launch
normal PowerShell, right?

86
00:04:33.660 --> 00:04:38.530
I can type in a command,
move that out of the way.

87
00:04:38.530 --> 00:04:44.720
Get-NetIPAddress, and it's gonna work
just like my normal PowerShell console.

88
00:04:44.720 --> 00:04:47.503
Type in your command,
hit Enter, and it's good to go.

89
00:04:47.503 --> 00:04:52.432
But you did probably notice,
as I was typing that, let's do get -p.

90
00:04:52.432 --> 00:04:54.768
You see that menu that starts dropping up.

91
00:04:54.768 --> 00:04:58.918
That's an IntelliSense that gives
me access to all these commands, so

92
00:04:58.918 --> 00:05:01.693
if I don't remember it I
can just start typing.

93
00:05:01.693 --> 00:05:06.471
And you'll see that it starts to filter
out, the more letters I type, and

94
00:05:06.471 --> 00:05:09.270
then I can simply tab to fill that in.

95
00:05:09.270 --> 00:05:13.776
Also notice that as I'm typing,
and I go to one of those commands,

96
00:05:13.776 --> 00:05:18.442
let me get that to do it again,
sometimes to get it rebuild that list,

97
00:05:18.442 --> 00:05:21.350
I got to back up past the dash or
the hyphen.

98
00:05:21.350 --> 00:05:25.013
When we Get-NetIPAddress,
as we hover over these commands,

99
00:05:25.013 --> 00:05:28.870
I'm using my arrow keys in
this case to move up and down.

100
00:05:28.870 --> 00:05:32.210
You'll see that I get syntax, or
just really pretty handy, right?

101
00:05:32.210 --> 00:05:33.420
As you're learning PowerShell,

102
00:05:33.420 --> 00:05:37.680
this is a great place to start,
because you get that syntax right there.

103
00:05:37.680 --> 00:05:40.190
We know we've learned
in our previous series

104
00:05:40.190 --> 00:05:42.770
that we can use the GET help command,
and we can always go and

105
00:05:42.770 --> 00:05:46.970
get that syntax, we can go and
get online help through PowerShell.

106
00:05:46.970 --> 00:05:51.160
But the fact that it pops up right here,
as I'm going through my commands is very,

107
00:05:51.160 --> 00:05:51.848
very handy.

108
00:05:52.871 --> 00:05:54.532
But we want to write scripts, or

109
00:05:54.532 --> 00:05:57.050
eventually that's where
we're gonna get to.

110
00:05:57.050 --> 00:06:01.130
So what you would do is come over here to
the top right-hand corner, that little

111
00:06:01.130 --> 00:06:06.440
downward pointing chevron and I can
click that, and there's my script pane.

112
00:06:06.440 --> 00:06:10.160
So now if I type Get-NetIPAddress,

113
00:06:10.160 --> 00:06:14.670
I still get the same auto sensor,
the auto fill, the IntelliSense,

114
00:06:14.670 --> 00:06:18.860
I still get all the syntax, but
if I hit Enter, nothing happens, right?

115
00:06:18.860 --> 00:06:21.425
It doesn't actually execute that command.

116
00:06:21.425 --> 00:06:24.598
If I wanna execute that command,
I would hit F5, or

117
00:06:24.598 --> 00:06:29.180
my little green play button up here and
that'll run that command.

118
00:06:29.180 --> 00:06:34.391
The handy thing about, another
handy thing about this ISE is that,

119
00:06:34.391 --> 00:06:37.142
I can run just my highlighted text.

120
00:06:37.142 --> 00:06:39.728
If I can do the F5 right now,
or click my play button,

121
00:06:39.728 --> 00:06:42.200
it's actually gonna run both commands.

122
00:06:42.200 --> 00:06:45.727
If you were quick enough,
or if you were watching,

123
00:06:45.727 --> 00:06:49.181
it went through all of
the processes in this case.

124
00:06:49.181 --> 00:06:56.239
But if I scroll back up, And get to the
top, I don't wanna scroll too far here,

125
00:06:56.239 --> 00:07:01.480
there you can see it actually
ran the Get-NetIPAddress, right?

126
00:07:01.480 --> 00:07:06.460
And then it ran the second one,
get dash process, all right?

127
00:07:06.460 --> 00:07:08.451
Let's clear that screen here.

128
00:07:11.083 --> 00:07:15.383
But what I can do in the ISE
is I can highlight a line or

129
00:07:15.383 --> 00:07:18.783
a group of lines, and I can do the F8, or

130
00:07:18.783 --> 00:07:24.000
the little play button here,
and it'll run just that one.

131
00:07:24.000 --> 00:07:30.970
It did not run the Get-NetIPAddress,
oops, it just run to get processed.

132
00:07:30.970 --> 00:07:34.160
Very handy when you're troubleshooting
a script and things like that.

133
00:07:34.160 --> 00:07:37.040
You can run just part of your script and
you can get those results.

134
00:07:37.040 --> 00:07:39.120
>> Help figure out where
that problem may lie.

135
00:07:39.120 --> 00:07:43.726
>> Exactly, all right,
another cool thing about the good old ISE,

136
00:07:43.726 --> 00:07:46.002
let me clean up my screen again.

137
00:07:46.002 --> 00:07:49.377
You can change your views if you prefer,
you can have this side by side,

138
00:07:49.377 --> 00:07:51.413
some people like this a little bit better.

139
00:07:51.413 --> 00:07:55.083
I kinda like this one but
it really depends on what I'm doing.

140
00:07:55.083 --> 00:07:58.718
You can also completely close
the The console pane and

141
00:07:58.718 --> 00:08:00.910
just have the script pane open.

142
00:08:00.910 --> 00:08:04.143
So if you're writing a script and
you don't need to execute it.

143
00:08:04.143 --> 00:08:06.420
>> You're not quite there yet,
you're not ready for that part.

144
00:08:06.420 --> 00:08:09.470
>> Yeah, you gotta little more room to
kind of work around and things like that.

145
00:08:09.470 --> 00:08:11.890
Some people get a little
claustrophobic dealing with this.

146
00:08:11.890 --> 00:08:15.250
Remember, you can always
drag that border up or down.

147
00:08:15.250 --> 00:08:20.280
And of course, if I'm going side-by-side
view, I can work with it this way as well.

148
00:08:21.290 --> 00:08:25.650
And then, you have these two guys right
here, which are the Show-Command.

149
00:08:25.650 --> 00:08:30.920
Now you can do Show-Command, right?

150
00:08:30.920 --> 00:08:34.590
And you can do this in a normal
PowerShell console, not the ISE, and

151
00:08:34.590 --> 00:08:36.690
it'll pop out this little window.

152
00:08:36.690 --> 00:08:41.190
And this is where I can see or
find a command that I'm looking for.

153
00:08:41.190 --> 00:08:43.320
I can filter it down by module if I want.

154
00:08:44.930 --> 00:08:50.190
>> So Mike, if I have a particular
series of commands that have not yet

155
00:08:50.190 --> 00:08:55.010
been invoked would they still
display here if it was for

156
00:08:55.010 --> 00:08:58.660
a particular service or role that I
hadn't installed on this machine?

157
00:08:58.660 --> 00:09:00.160
>> Absolutely, you see everything here.

158
00:09:00.160 --> 00:09:04.587
In fact, let's see,
I'm going to change this back to all and

159
00:09:04.587 --> 00:09:10.910
let's do a get-computer, you'll see
I have like a get-computer info.

160
00:09:10.910 --> 00:09:14.786
Now I don't have the Active Directory
module installed, so it does look like its

161
00:09:14.786 --> 00:09:17.943
because that module is not [CROSSTALK]
>> Okay that's what I was wondering,

162
00:09:17.943 --> 00:09:21.093
specifically I was thinking of Active
Directory, but there are some other rules

163
00:09:21.093 --> 00:09:23.840
too that are having other specific
commandments associated with it.

164
00:09:23.840 --> 00:09:28.372
>> And because this is a client, I don't
have those kind of modules available until

165
00:09:28.372 --> 00:09:30.850
I install those remote server admin tools.

166
00:09:30.850 --> 00:09:31.510
>> Makes sense, okay.

167
00:09:31.510 --> 00:09:35.042
>> Now if I was on a server,
even if the role wasn't installed,

168
00:09:35.042 --> 00:09:37.273
the module would still be available.

169
00:09:37.273 --> 00:09:40.670
It wouldn't be imported, I wouldn't
have those commands at my fingertips.

170
00:09:40.670 --> 00:09:43.672
But if I typed a command that
was in one of those modules.

171
00:09:43.672 --> 00:09:47.233
Remember with PowerShell 5, we don't
actually have to import the module,

172
00:09:47.233 --> 00:09:49.664
you can type a command and
it will go find the module.

173
00:09:49.664 --> 00:09:53.533
And as long as it's in the, remember,
the get-module -list available, and

174
00:09:53.533 --> 00:09:57.461
that will show you what modules are on
your machine, not necessarily imported,

175
00:09:57.461 --> 00:09:59.450
and then you can import them from there.

176
00:09:59.450 --> 00:10:01.630
So it does have to at
least be on the machine.

177
00:10:01.630 --> 00:10:04.350
And if we installed
Remote Server Administration Tools,

178
00:10:04.350 --> 00:10:08.176
I would see the Active Directory module
listed here, and the DNS server module and

179
00:10:08.176 --> 00:10:09.411
things like that listed.

180
00:10:09.411 --> 00:10:14.236
So as we go through and another way you
can do show-command, I can also use these

181
00:10:14.236 --> 00:10:19.620
buttons here, this one is gonna launch
it as a floater, just like we saw there.

182
00:10:19.620 --> 00:10:22.120
If I click that it's kinda
floating as a separate window.

183
00:10:22.120 --> 00:10:26.290
Very handy when I'm working with multiple
monitors I can drag that off to the side.

184
00:10:26.290 --> 00:10:29.470
This one shows it as
a separate tab in my pane.

185
00:10:29.470 --> 00:10:32.910
I lose a little bit of real
estate in my working area, but

186
00:10:32.910 --> 00:10:34.630
I have access to it over here.

187
00:10:34.630 --> 00:10:39.080
And you can find the command
you're looking for git-net i and

188
00:10:39.080 --> 00:10:42.030
there's my good old Get-NetIPAddress.

189
00:10:42.030 --> 00:10:44.780
Now what's cool about this
little Show-Command window

190
00:10:44.780 --> 00:10:48.430
is if I click on this command not only can
I find a command that I'm looking for, and

191
00:10:48.430 --> 00:10:50.250
I can use wild cards in there.

192
00:10:50.250 --> 00:10:52.870
Or you see it really does
a wild card part on it's own.

193
00:10:52.870 --> 00:10:56.491
As I'm typing, there is an asterisk
at the end that we don't see.

194
00:10:56.491 --> 00:11:00.282
>> And just starts narrowing down
the results there by the more characters?

195
00:11:00.282 --> 00:11:03.620
>> Exactly, so it's like it puts
the asterisk there for you and

196
00:11:03.620 --> 00:11:06.080
does an auto search,
it's very, very handy.

197
00:11:06.080 --> 00:11:09.994
Once I select one of these commands
you'll see I get this pane down here.

198
00:11:09.994 --> 00:11:12.060
Now, let me find one I haven't used yet.

199
00:11:14.980 --> 00:11:16.280
Well, it's not going to play along.

200
00:11:16.280 --> 00:11:18.650
Let's refresh this, see if I can it.

201
00:11:18.650 --> 00:11:21.070
Normally what will happen,
I've already opened this up.

202
00:11:21.070 --> 00:11:24.920
Let me see if I can go to
a different machine I can show you

203
00:11:24.920 --> 00:11:26.290
something about that.

204
00:11:26.290 --> 00:11:29.020
What I wanted to show you is
sometimes when you first open that up

205
00:11:29.020 --> 00:11:31.290
there's no details down there.

206
00:11:31.290 --> 00:11:35.840
So let's see, if we go back over to the
domain controller and I launch that ISE.

207
00:11:35.840 --> 00:11:39.630
Let that fire up, give

208
00:11:41.840 --> 00:11:46.270
it just a second, and
if not I can fire up another server.

209
00:11:46.270 --> 00:11:51.960
It's really not that big of a deal,

210
00:11:51.960 --> 00:11:57.648

up 32 bits of storage, in memory,
as we create this variable,

433
00:24:51.133 --> 00:24:56.060
we're really creating a container in
memory that I can store information.

434
00:24:56.060 --> 00:25:00.493
If it's a 32-bit integer,
then that's my limit, right,

435
00:25:00.493 --> 00:25:03.840
that's the biggest I can go and
with 32 bits,

436
00:25:03.840 --> 00:25:08.879
let's see if I remember,
32 bits that's an IPV4 address, right?

437
00:25:08.879 --> 00:25:10.310
>> Yes.
>> So that's gonna be,

438
00:25:10.310 --> 00:25:13.190
how many possible IP
addresses have we got?

439
00:25:13.190 --> 00:25:14.490
Four billion.

440
00:25:14.490 --> 00:25:14.990
>> Yeah.

441
00:25:14.990 --> 00:25:16.190
>> Somewhat, right?

442
00:25:16.190 --> 00:25:18.050
>> Yup.
>> But if it's signed,

443
00:25:18.050 --> 00:25:21.510
that means I can do positives and
negatives.

444
00:25:21.510 --> 00:25:22.140
All right.

445
00:25:22.140 --> 00:25:25.310
So I can't go up to four billion,
cuz half of them are gonna be negative,

446
00:25:25.310 --> 00:25:27.240
half of them are gonna be positive,
that makes sense?

447
00:25:27.240 --> 00:25:28.550
You have to split it in half.

448
00:25:28.550 --> 00:25:31.860
If you think about the overall range,
the zero's in the middle, right?

449
00:25:31.860 --> 00:25:35.760
And I can go up to, well, and let's
take a look, I'll show you how you can.

450
00:25:35.760 --> 00:25:40.659
If we do something like this,
if I do open bracket INT,

451
00:25:40.659 --> 00:25:45.470
close bracket, colon,
colon, max value, right?

452
00:25:45.470 --> 00:25:53.000
I can see, there is my maximum value, two
million, one hundred, is that millions?

453
00:25:53.000 --> 00:25:57.851
Yeah, 2,147,460,647, right?

454
00:25:57.851 --> 00:25:58.500
>> There you go.
>> Right?

455
00:25:58.500 --> 00:25:59.600
Yeah.
I can count that high?

456
00:25:59.600 --> 00:26:00.690
>> Yeah, I know.

457
00:26:00.690 --> 00:26:02.450
It's so crazy without the little commas.

458
00:26:02.450 --> 00:26:03.420
I'm like looking for the commas.

459
00:26:03.420 --> 00:26:04.660
>> I know, where is that?

460
00:26:04.660 --> 00:26:06.741
>> Okay, where did they go?
You have to count it out and put them in.

461
00:26:06.741 --> 00:26:08.073
[LAUGH]
>> Okay, you do min value.

462
00:26:08.073 --> 00:26:09.544
You know this is just the opposite,

463
00:26:09.544 --> 00:26:11.196
right on the other side of zero-
>> Okay.

464
00:26:11.196 --> 00:26:12.007
>> going the other way.

465
00:26:12.007 --> 00:26:14.401
>> Yup.
>> If this was unsigned, right, well,

466
00:26:14.401 --> 00:26:17.522
then we're gonna start at zero,
and we can only go one way.

467
00:26:17.522 --> 00:26:19.740
Because I'm saying there is no sign.

468
00:26:19.740 --> 00:26:23.570
There is no positive or
negative stored with this value.

469
00:26:23.570 --> 00:26:27.710
So everything has to be positive,
so now I can go from

470
00:26:27.710 --> 00:26:32.150
zero up to four million two hundred and
whatever that would be, right?

471
00:26:32.150 --> 00:26:35.520
We would add those two
together to get that.

472
00:26:35.520 --> 00:26:39.914
And then long, for example, is a 64-bit.

473
00:26:39.914 --> 00:26:43.182
We take a look at long.

474
00:26:43.182 --> 00:26:47.633
And what I'm doing here is, I'm actually
pulling out, when you type that open,

475
00:26:47.633 --> 00:26:50.553
close bracket,
I'm looking at the class that type.

476
00:26:50.553 --> 00:26:55.789
And then the colon, colon, and then it has
properties, it has methods associated with

477
00:26:55.789 --> 00:27:00.410
it, if we do max value, there I can see
and I'm not even gonna try to say that.

478
00:27:00.410 --> 00:27:06.585
>> Okay, Mike, so I looked it up and
it is, we've got 4,294,96,296,

479
00:27:06.585 --> 00:27:11.516
so that's probably why we couldn't
remember the exact number.

480
00:27:11.516 --> 00:27:12.404
>> Yeah, that's a big number, yup.

481
00:27:12.404 --> 00:27:15.231
>> [LAUGH]
>> And again, and I'm not trying to say,

482
00:27:15.231 --> 00:27:19.765
hey, you should memorize these values and
I don't want you to think that that

483
00:27:19.765 --> 00:27:25.320
32-bit, or that int 32-bit sign integer
has anything to do with IPv4 addresses.

484
00:27:25.320 --> 00:27:27.420
In my mind though-
>> Associations.

485
00:27:27.420 --> 00:27:31.350
>> I know how many possible IPv4 addresses
there are if we could use every possible

486
00:27:31.350 --> 00:27:31.850
address, right?

487
00:27:31.850 --> 00:27:35.160
And that's 32 bits, so that's how I
was trying to remember that number,

488
00:27:35.160 --> 00:27:37.990
I was like, wait, there's possibly
four billion blah, blah, blah,

489
00:27:37.990 --> 00:27:39.770
so that's why I using that.

490
00:27:39.770 --> 00:27:47.660
The rule of thumb is you really want to
use the smallest possible one you can.

491
00:27:47.660 --> 00:27:51.030
Because this is taking up memory.

492
00:27:51.030 --> 00:27:55.439
If I declare a long, and that's a 64-bit

493
00:27:55.439 --> 00:28:00.960
signed integer, that means it's taking
up every long variable that I create.

494
00:28:00.960 --> 00:28:03.420
Is taking up 64 bits of memory, all right.

495
00:28:03.420 --> 00:28:06.570
And if I'm only storing the number five,
well,

496
00:28:06.570 --> 00:28:10.770
I don't need quite that many bits
to store the number five, right.

497
00:28:10.770 --> 00:28:15.200
Five is 101,
I really only need a few bits there,

498
00:28:15.200 --> 00:28:17.310
I mean four bits would be plenty,
three bits we could do with that.

499
00:28:17.310 --> 00:28:20.790
So that would not be
the best data type to use.

500
00:28:20.790 --> 00:28:25.650
And that's just what I wanted to show you,
is that there are different

501
00:28:25.650 --> 00:28:29.936
data types we can use,
they have different possible values.

502
00:28:29.936 --> 00:28:33.240
I know that like in some
of the stuff I'm doing,

503
00:28:33.240 --> 00:28:36.180
we get in the habit of using int for
everything.

504
00:28:36.180 --> 00:28:38.490
But int can store a pretty big number.

505
00:28:38.490 --> 00:28:42.850
And for example, I'm doing this one
project that we're working with LEDs, and

506
00:28:42.850 --> 00:28:44.640
we're changing the PWM.

507
00:28:45.710 --> 00:28:48.630
And the only possible
value is zero to 255.

508
00:28:48.630 --> 00:28:51.330
I really don't need to use an int,

509
00:28:51.330 --> 00:28:54.290
because an int can store
a value up to two billion.

510
00:28:54.290 --> 00:29:00.030
My only possible values are zero to 255,
so we end up using a byte data type.

511
00:29:00.030 --> 00:29:05.340
Because a byte is a bits and
I'm using the space much more efficiently.

512
00:29:05.340 --> 00:29:08.020
Hopefully that makes sense
to everybody out there.

513
00:29:08.020 --> 00:29:09.290
All right, the other data types we got,

514
00:29:09.290 --> 00:29:14.620
you've got strings for
text characters, unicode characters.

515
00:29:14.620 --> 00:29:18.900
You've got a string is typically
what they say is a fixed length

516
00:29:18.900 --> 00:29:20.910
set of unicode characters.

517
00:29:20.910 --> 00:29:25.618
You got chair, car, or char, depending
on who you're talking to C-H-A-R.

518
00:29:25.618 --> 00:29:29.485
For our Unicode16-bit character,
bool, all right.

519
00:29:29.485 --> 00:29:34.580
B-O-O-L, short for bullion,
possible values true or false.

520
00:29:34.580 --> 00:29:40.420
Byte again is an 8-bit unsigned, you got
double, you got decimal, you got single.

521
00:29:40.420 --> 00:29:45.290
You've got a raise, where I can actually
store multiple values in a variable.

522
00:29:45.290 --> 00:29:48.510
So we'll take a look at
working with those as we go.

523
00:29:48.510 --> 00:29:52.880
We've got xml to store xml documents,
that's another data type.

524
00:29:52.880 --> 00:29:54.390
And we have hash tables.

525
00:29:54.390 --> 00:29:55.290
Hash tables are pretty cool.

526
00:29:55.290 --> 00:29:58.882
We'll take a look at those
as we go through the series.

527
00:29:58.882 --> 00:30:02.964
Cache tables, very similar to dictionary
objects if you come from any other

528
00:30:02.964 --> 00:30:05.852
programming languages,
either use dictionaries.

529
00:30:05.852 --> 00:30:10.441
There are ways to store key value pair,
where I can say, let's say,

530
00:30:10.441 --> 00:30:13.940
I wanna store,
put you to the test here, Cherokee.

531
00:30:13.940 --> 00:30:16.360
>> Okay.
>> I wanna store states and

532
00:30:16.360 --> 00:30:19.060
their capitals, right?

533
00:30:19.060 --> 00:30:19.560
>> Geez my-
>> [LAUGH]

534
00:30:19.560 --> 00:30:20.280
>> She's like, wait,

535
00:30:20.280 --> 00:30:24.032
you know how long it's been
since I've taken geography?

536
00:30:24.032 --> 00:30:25.060
>> Gosh.
>> [LAUGH]

537
00:30:25.060 --> 00:30:27.140
>> We'll do some relatively easy ones,

538
00:30:27.140 --> 00:30:28.255
ones that I hope I know.

539
00:30:28.255 --> 00:30:30.120
>> [LAUGH]
>> As well.

540
00:30:30.120 --> 00:30:33.910
But I might wanna store, like do you know,
what's the capital of Florida?

541
00:30:33.910 --> 00:30:34.510
>> Tallahassee.

542
00:30:34.510 --> 00:30:35.020
>> Okay.
>> [LAUGH]

543
00:30:35.020 --> 00:30:39.090
>> So I could store in my variable,

544
00:30:39.090 --> 00:30:44.178
that Florida equals Tallahassee,
and what's another one you know?

545
00:30:44.178 --> 00:30:45.833
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'm terrible with my [INAUDIBLE]

546
00:30:45.833 --> 00:30:47.460
>> That was it right?

547
00:30:47.460 --> 00:30:48.200
That was all we got.

548
00:30:48.200 --> 00:30:49.370
>> That's it.

549
00:30:49.370 --> 00:30:56.030
>> Or we could do something like,
color equals blue, size equals five,

550
00:30:56.030 --> 00:31:00.350
size equals four, and
all those are key value pairs.

551
00:31:00.350 --> 00:31:04.260
So if I want to return,
what color is that box gonna be.

552
00:31:04.260 --> 00:31:05.260
It's gonna be blue, right.

553
00:31:05.260 --> 00:31:07.680
What size is it gonna be, five inches.

554
00:31:07.680 --> 00:31:10.710
Or how many sides does it have,
four, right.

555
00:31:10.710 --> 00:31:12.612
So each one of those is a key value pair.

556
00:31:12.612 --> 00:31:15.620
There are great ways of
storing key value pairs.

557
00:31:15.620 --> 00:31:19.090
They're very efficient, great way to go in
and find the information when you need it.

558
00:31:19.090 --> 00:31:21.000
And we'll take a look
at how we create those,

559
00:31:21.000 --> 00:31:25.180
cuz those are created a little bit
differently than our standard variables.

560
00:31:25.180 --> 00:31:30.580
We have to go through some special
syntax to create those hash tables.

561
00:31:30.580 --> 00:31:33.320
So that's a look at the different
data types that are available.

562
00:31:33.320 --> 00:31:35.370
Again, great documentation
out there on Microsoft,

563
00:31:35.370 --> 00:31:38.200
go take a look at the Microsoft docs.

564
00:31:38.200 --> 00:31:40.150
You know Google, PowerShell or Bing.

565
00:31:40.150 --> 00:31:43.930
PowerShell data types, look for
a link that heads back to

566
00:31:45.880 --> 00:31:48.350
Microsoft docs, or use your Help.

567
00:31:48.350 --> 00:31:49.700
Right, we have the About.

568
00:31:49.700 --> 00:31:54.430
Hey, we might be able to do, let's see,
about under score data types,

569
00:31:55.890 --> 00:31:57.090
I'd have to do my Get Help, but

570
00:31:57.090 --> 00:32:00.220
we won't worry about it,
I know we're getting short on time here.

571
00:32:00.220 --> 00:32:03.310
They have great documentation built in to
PowerShell as well, but just go on and

572
00:32:03.310 --> 00:32:04.420
take a look at Microsoft's site,

573
00:32:04.420 --> 00:32:06.800
get some information about
the different data types.

574
00:32:06.800 --> 00:32:10.100
And I know you're giving me the signal,
so we're about out of time here.

575
00:32:10.100 --> 00:32:11.530
When we come back maybe, Cherokee,

576
00:32:11.530 --> 00:32:14.140
we can take a look at actually
creating some variables.

577
00:32:14.140 --> 00:32:18.075
>> Good, maybe you'll give some extra time
to study before the next show as well.

578
00:32:18.075 --> 00:32:19.570
>> [LAUGH]
>> But thank you so much, Mike.

579
00:32:19.570 --> 00:32:20.670
And thank you for joining us.

580
00:32:20.670 --> 00:32:22.770
You don't want to miss what
we have headed your way.

581
00:32:22.770 --> 00:32:24.380
But for this show, we are out of time.

582
00:32:24.380 --> 00:32:25.811
So we'll go ahead and sign out.

583
00:32:25.811 --> 00:32:27.111
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.

584
00:32:27.111 --> 00:32:27.881
>> And I'm Mike Roderick.

585
00:32:27.881 --> 00:32:31.283
>> See you next time here, ITProTV.

586
00:32:31.283 --> 00:32:37.199
[MUSIC]

587
00:32:37.199 --> 00:32:39.240
>> Thank you for watching IT Pro TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Cherokee continue their look at variables in PowerShell. They explain how to create variables in PowerShell and assign values
episodes.title: Working with Variables Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.230 --> 00:00:03.443
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.443 --> 00:00:05.149
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:05.149 --> 00:00:07.182
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:07.182 --> 00:00:11.843
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.843 --> 00:00:15.117
>> Welcome to your PowerShell Scripting
series, I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:15.117 --> 00:00:17.943
This is actually a part two,
a continuation,

7
00:00:17.943 --> 00:00:22.000
where we will be examining
different types of variables.

8
00:00:22.000 --> 00:00:25.060
And back with us today in studios
we have Mr. Mike Rodrick.

9
00:00:25.060 --> 00:00:25.865
How's going today, Mike?

10
00:00:25.865 --> 00:00:28.160
>> Well, it's going great, Cherokee,
thanks for having me back.

11
00:00:28.160 --> 00:00:32.353
And excited as always, especially today we
get to continue talking about variables.

12
00:00:32.353 --> 00:00:36.916
Cuz we kinda left off, we got everybody, I
think, excited like, let's see variables,

13
00:00:36.916 --> 00:00:38.690
we talked about them.

14
00:00:38.690 --> 00:00:40.535
We never really did anything with them,
did we?

15
00:00:40.535 --> 00:00:41.420
>> [LAUGH]
>> Kind of boring.

16
00:00:41.420 --> 00:00:45.619
So now we're gonna go in and
actually work with some variables.

17
00:00:45.619 --> 00:00:48.209
And again,
we're just creating some examples here,

18
00:00:48.209 --> 00:00:50.872
we're not really ready to
write a full-on script yet.

19
00:00:50.872 --> 00:00:54.527
We've gotta get all these pieces together,
we've got to learn about how we put these

20
00:00:54.527 --> 00:00:56.930
scripts together, and
then we'll take a look at that.

21
00:00:56.930 --> 00:01:00.320
So for now we're still getting
our feet wet, getting ready.

22
00:01:00.320 --> 00:01:04.135
Getting all that foundation laid
to write our really cool scripts.

23
00:01:04.135 --> 00:01:08.940
[COUGH] So we learned about variables,
we learned about data types.

24
00:01:08.940 --> 00:01:10.310
Let's see how we can go ahead and
declare variables.

25
00:01:10.310 --> 00:01:13.510
So Cherokee, do you remember what
a variable always starts with when we're

26
00:01:13.510 --> 00:01:15.190
talking about a variable name?

27
00:01:15.190 --> 00:01:16.090
>> Dollar sign.

28
00:01:16.090 --> 00:01:18.549
>> The dollar sign, you are correct-
>> Money [LAUGH].

29
00:01:18.549 --> 00:01:19.473
>> Ding, ding, ding.

30
00:01:19.473 --> 00:01:20.950
[LAUGH] Money, money, right?

31
00:01:20.950 --> 00:01:22.405
Show me the variable.

32
00:01:22.405 --> 00:01:23.817
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right,

33
00:01:23.817 --> 00:01:28.070
so if I wanna create a variable,
I can say $a, right?

34
00:01:28.070 --> 00:01:30.930
And I can actually just, whoops,
let's see if we can do this.

35
00:01:30.930 --> 00:01:33.554
I can go ahead and assign a value,
let's say $a = 5, right?

36
00:01:33.554 --> 00:01:35.800
And I'll hit Enter.

37
00:01:35.800 --> 00:01:40.610
Now notice I didn't do anything with
data types, anything like that.

38
00:01:40.610 --> 00:01:43.804
I just said hey, I wanna create a variable
called dollar sign, or called a.

39
00:01:43.804 --> 00:01:49.390
The dollar sign is what PowerShell
uses to denote that it is a variable.

40
00:01:49.390 --> 00:01:50.186
And I assigned a value to it.

41
00:01:50.186 --> 00:01:56.770
So I took the number 5 and I put it
into this container called a, right?

42
00:01:56.770 --> 00:02:01.474
So now if I wanna recall that variable,
$a, and hit Enter, and

43
00:02:01.474 --> 00:02:04.018
notice it prints out a 5, right?

44
00:02:04.018 --> 00:02:07.900
Because that is the value
stored in that variable.

45
00:02:07.900 --> 00:02:13.736
Now I could reassign that value,
I could say $a = 7, right?

46
00:02:13.736 --> 00:02:21.080
And if I do $a again,
now notice we get a 7 over there, right?

47
00:02:21.080 --> 00:02:24.540
Because the equals sign, and this is
the one you're gonna be careful with,

48
00:02:24.540 --> 00:02:27.200
we'll talk more about this
when we get into operators.

49
00:02:27.200 --> 00:02:31.133
In PowerShell, the equals sign
is the assignment operator.

50
00:02:31.133 --> 00:02:36.260
We've gotta be really, really careful,
that is not a comparison operator, right?

51
00:02:36.260 --> 00:02:39.044
I'm not saying,
are these two values the same, right,

52
00:02:39.044 --> 00:02:40.554
I would not use the equal sign.

53
00:02:40.554 --> 00:02:43.469
We'd actually use something different for
that, and again,

54
00:02:43.469 --> 00:02:46.670
we'll come to that when we get
into the comparison operators.

55
00:02:46.670 --> 00:02:50.530
But in this case, in PowerShell,
the equal sign is an assignment operator.

56
00:02:50.530 --> 00:02:53.300
So it's assigning the value on the right

57
00:02:53.300 --> 00:02:58.410
to that variable that we've declared
over there on the left, right?

58
00:02:58.410 --> 00:03:00.443
Well let's do another one, let's do $b.

59
00:03:00.443 --> 00:03:05.430
We're gonna keep it,
it keeps trying to auto-fill for me there.

60
00:03:05.430 --> 00:03:08.590
I should use different names or
something a little more complex than that.

61
00:03:08.590 --> 00:03:12.173
We'll say $b = 8, right?

62
00:03:12.173 --> 00:03:15.731
And now if I do $b,

63
00:03:15.731 --> 00:03:21.930
I can see the value 8, right?

64
00:03:21.930 --> 00:03:24.264
So there we're declaring variables and

65
00:03:24.264 --> 00:03:28.180
we're storing values in those
variables to recall later, right?

66
00:03:29.295 --> 00:03:34.720
Now we can do expressions,
right, with these variables.

67
00:03:34.720 --> 00:03:38.246
And for example,

68
00:03:38.246 --> 00:03:43.181
if I do a $c = $a + $b,

69
00:03:43.181 --> 00:03:48.350
okay, and I hit Enter.

70
00:03:48.350 --> 00:03:51.020
Well nothing happens,
I'm not telling it to show me the results.

71
00:03:51.020 --> 00:03:56.080
I'm saying,

and I've got an expression inside there.

541
00:29:39.290 --> 00:29:45.247
I hit Enter, and you'll see that it
took that $ sign and resolved this.

542
00:29:45.247 --> 00:29:49.354
It said, okay, $A is actually 8,
$B is actually 8.

543
00:29:49.354 --> 00:29:53.050
This expression then is 8 plus 8,
which is 16.

544
00:29:53.050 --> 00:29:54.732
And it printed out 16.

545
00:29:54.732 --> 00:29:57.588
Not $A plus $B or anything like that.

546
00:29:57.588 --> 00:29:59.440
That's the double quote.

547
00:29:59.440 --> 00:30:03.870
The double quotes are those
expandable string.

548
00:30:03.870 --> 00:30:06.640
But in the end we really didn't
get what I wanted, did we?

549
00:30:06.640 --> 00:30:09.400
Nowhere does it say that the value of.

550
00:30:09.400 --> 00:30:12.960
I was really trying to say
the value of $myName is Mike.

551
00:30:12.960 --> 00:30:14.200
>> You wanted Mike.

552
00:30:14.200 --> 00:30:16.790
>> One time, the first one with
the literal strings, well,

553
00:30:16.790 --> 00:30:18.860
it just showed me
the variable name both times.

554
00:30:18.860 --> 00:30:20.590
It said, I don't see variables.

555
00:30:20.590 --> 00:30:24.700
I see no variables, I got those force
fields around it, as Cherokee says.

556
00:30:24.700 --> 00:30:29.240
Now the second one, it resolved both of
them and said, hey there's a variable.

557
00:30:29.240 --> 00:30:31.400
I'm gonna put the variable
value instead of the name.

558
00:30:31.400 --> 00:30:32.570
There's another variable.

559
00:30:32.570 --> 00:30:35.440
I'm gonna put the value
instead of the name.

560
00:30:35.440 --> 00:30:38.090
It did it, but
I get the value of Mike is Mike.

561
00:30:38.090 --> 00:30:39.000
That doesn't help me out either.

562
00:30:40.020 --> 00:30:43.790
So what we have to understand is,
there is an escape character.

563
00:30:43.790 --> 00:30:48.960
And the escape character used with inside
the expandable strings will prevent

564
00:30:48.960 --> 00:30:54.712
PowerShell from actually resolving
the variable into the value.

565
00:30:54.712 --> 00:30:59.296
[COUGH] And
the escape character is the back tick, or

566
00:30:59.296 --> 00:31:04.540
the accent, or the grave, or the-
>> We're gonna have this discussion again?

567
00:31:04.540 --> 00:31:05.050
>> Nah, no.
>> [LAUGH]

568
00:31:05.050 --> 00:31:05.960
>> No we're just gonna go

569
00:31:05.960 --> 00:31:06.800
with it, all right?

570
00:31:06.800 --> 00:31:08.725
It's the tilde without the shift.

571
00:31:08.725 --> 00:31:10.610
>> [LAUGH]
>> No we know it's the grave,

572
00:31:10.610 --> 00:31:12.880
our chatroom filled us in last night,
right?

573
00:31:12.880 --> 00:31:15.240
>> Yes. [LAUGH] >> They corrected us so
we know what that is now.

574
00:31:15.240 --> 00:31:16.270
All right, so we can do that.

575
00:31:16.270 --> 00:31:17.790
And I know it's really hard to see.

576
00:31:17.790 --> 00:31:19.540
That's not a single quote.

577
00:31:19.540 --> 00:31:22.490
That's not my right pinky.

578
00:31:22.490 --> 00:31:25.760
That's my left pinky up there on
the number row underneath the tilde there,

579
00:31:25.760 --> 00:31:28.150
right above your Tab key.

580
00:31:28.150 --> 00:31:29.100
Let's see what that does.

581
00:31:32.087 --> 00:31:36.810
Look, now I've got the value
of $myName is Mike.

582
00:31:36.810 --> 00:31:40.740
So that little back tick
escaped the dollar sign.

583
00:31:40.740 --> 00:31:41.960
>> Tiny, yet powerful.

584
00:31:41.960 --> 00:31:44.035
>> I know, it really, really is.

585
00:31:44.035 --> 00:31:47.250
>> [LAUGH]
>> It took away the special meaning

586
00:31:47.250 --> 00:31:48.650
of the dollar sign.

587
00:31:48.650 --> 00:31:52.050
So now the dollar sign is no
longer a variable indicator.

588
00:31:52.050 --> 00:31:53.780
It's just a dollar sign, alright?

589
00:31:53.780 --> 00:31:54.960
And you need this a lot.

590
00:31:54.960 --> 00:31:58.190
Any time you need to use a character
that's a reserved character within

591
00:31:58.190 --> 00:32:01.670
PowerShell, and you want to
print the literal character, and

592
00:32:01.670 --> 00:32:06.720
not let it take on its special meaning,
you're gonna have to use that back tick.

593
00:32:06.720 --> 00:32:08.790
That is the escape character.

594
00:32:08.790 --> 00:32:10.780
So that is how we work with those strings,
and

595
00:32:10.780 --> 00:32:15.310
we see that there is expandable strings,
or the double quotes.

596
00:32:15.310 --> 00:32:19.000
That way, it's gonna resolve variables and
expressions and give you the results.

597
00:32:19.000 --> 00:32:22.670
You've got the literal strings,
which are these single quote marks, and

598
00:32:22.670 --> 00:32:26.970
then you have the back tick or
the grave, which is going to be a way to

599
00:32:26.970 --> 00:32:31.010
escape special characters
within our expandable strings.

600
00:32:31.010 --> 00:32:35.084
And hopefully that will get us a good
start to understanding variables,

601
00:32:35.084 --> 00:32:40.350
how we're gonna be able to use those as we
progress to learning how to write scripts.

602
00:32:40.350 --> 00:32:42.120
>> Well I feel enlightened here, Mike.

603
00:32:42.120 --> 00:32:43.110
You definitely rock.

604
00:32:43.110 --> 00:32:44.340
Thank you for sharing that with us.

605
00:32:44.340 --> 00:32:45.920
And thank you for joining us, but

606
00:32:45.920 --> 00:32:48.270
you don't want to miss what
we have coming up next.

607
00:32:48.270 --> 00:32:50.540
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose,
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

608
00:32:50.540 --> 00:32:53.336
>> See you next time here on ITPRO.TV

609
00:32:53.336 --> 00:32:59.514
[MUSIC]

610
00:32:59.514 --> 00:33:03.017
Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: This episode covers the use of arrays in PowerShell. You will learn how to create arrays and store objects in arrays. You will also see how to retrieve objects stored in an array.
episodes.title: Arrays
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:06.669
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.669 --> 00:00:08.416
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.416 --> 00:00:11.506
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:11.506 --> 00:00:14.347
>> Thanks for joining us here at
your PowerShell Scripting Series.

5
00:00:14.347 --> 00:00:15.930
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:15.930 --> 00:00:18.785
And today we'll be
taking a look at arrays.

7
00:00:18.785 --> 00:00:22.109
Back in studios with us today,
we have Mr. Mike Rodrick.

8
00:00:22.109 --> 00:00:24.569
And I'm hoping he can
explain what an array is and

9
00:00:24.569 --> 00:00:26.675
how we can use it here within PowerShell.

10
00:00:26.675 --> 00:00:27.289
>> Me too.

11
00:00:27.289 --> 00:00:28.845
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Right?

12
00:00:28.845 --> 00:00:31.020
>> That's what I'm here for
right, so I'd better be able to.

13
00:00:31.020 --> 00:00:33.789
But all kidding aside,
hello everybody, I'm glad to be here.

14
00:00:33.789 --> 00:00:35.136
Thanks for having me back, Cherokee.

15
00:00:35.136 --> 00:00:37.386
And yeah, we're gonna be
talking about arrays, right?

16
00:00:37.386 --> 00:00:41.390
We've done in a couple of episodes,
we've looked at working with variables,

17
00:00:41.390 --> 00:00:43.673
we talked about what they are, containers.

18
00:00:43.673 --> 00:00:49.307
We also talked about how PowerShell
is a dynamic type scripting language.

19
00:00:49.307 --> 00:00:55.983
In other words, we don't have to strongly
declare our variable type, right?

20
00:00:55.983 --> 00:00:59.755
I can create a variable, put an integer
in there, I can put a string in there,

21
00:00:59.755 --> 00:01:02.322
PowerShell will do everything
it can to figure out,

22
00:01:02.322 --> 00:01:02.957
>> A little flexible there.

23
00:01:02.957 --> 00:01:05.849
>> Yeah, it's very nice,
it makes much less work on me.

24
00:01:05.849 --> 00:01:08.269
It can cause problems down the road.

25
00:01:08.269 --> 00:01:11.197
It is something that we do
have to be conscious of.

26
00:01:11.197 --> 00:01:14.067
And typically the way I,
and this is just me, but

27
00:01:14.067 --> 00:01:18.477
the way I usually do things is as I'm
writing scripts and creating things,

28
00:01:18.477 --> 00:01:22.203
a lot of times I won't strongly type it,
I won't go and put it.

29
00:01:22.203 --> 00:01:24.962
Because I'm changing things very fast and
I just wanna whip it out and

30
00:01:24.962 --> 00:01:26.209
kinda work out the framework.

31
00:01:26.209 --> 00:01:30.548
But if it's gonna go into production,
if it's something that I'm gonna use,

32
00:01:30.548 --> 00:01:33.593
if it's something I'm gonna
share with other people or

33
00:01:33.593 --> 00:01:36.703
something that end users
are gonna be interacting with,

34
00:01:36.703 --> 00:01:39.857
I definitely wanna go back at
some point and change that.

35
00:01:39.857 --> 00:01:43.862
So that they can't mistakenly put a string
where I'm expecting an integer and

36
00:01:43.862 --> 00:01:44.842
things like that.

37
00:01:44.842 --> 00:01:47.489
So even though we might not
do that all the time in here.

38
00:01:47.489 --> 00:01:51.330
It's a good idea, if it's gonna be in
production use to strongly type it.

39
00:01:51.330 --> 00:01:52.453
It just prevents a lot of issues.

40
00:01:52.453 --> 00:01:55.750
>> And you're just saying by specifically
declaring that as the string, or

41
00:01:55.750 --> 00:01:58.586
in certain situations where
you're using the single quotes.

42
00:01:58.586 --> 00:01:59.982
>> [LAUGH] Yes, exactly.

43
00:01:59.982 --> 00:02:03.308
So that's something we can always
go back and fix and change and

44
00:02:03.308 --> 00:02:04.763
make production quality.

45
00:02:04.763 --> 00:02:07.672
Because we're not doing a lot of error
checking and things like that either.

46
00:02:07.672 --> 00:02:11.062
And those are other things that we would
want to eventually include any type of

47
00:02:11.062 --> 00:02:13.317
scripts that we're gonna
be using in production.

48
00:02:13.317 --> 00:02:17.508
All right, but anyway, so back to array,
so we talked about the different variable

49
00:02:17.508 --> 00:02:20.649
types in strings, boule,
double floats, things like that.

50
00:02:20.649 --> 00:02:24.561
And we mentioned arrays and
hash tables as types of variables and

51
00:02:24.561 --> 00:02:28.410
while instance strings are pretty
straight forward, right?

52
00:02:28.410 --> 00:02:29.604
I'm gonna store it in to draw a number.

53
00:02:29.604 --> 00:02:34.350
We're all familiar with working with that
or doing strings, putting text in there.

54
00:02:34.350 --> 00:02:37.690
Arrays and hash tables kinda
warrant a little deeper dive and

55
00:02:37.690 --> 00:02:39.536
that's what I wanted to do here.

56
00:02:39.536 --> 00:02:44.022
Because they're a little more
complex than a standard variable and

57
00:02:44.022 --> 00:02:45.679
we use them all the time.

58
00:02:45.679 --> 00:02:48.539
It's something that you're going
to see if you're writing scripts.

59
00:02:48.539 --> 00:02:51.327
I might have a list of computer names and

60
00:02:51.327 --> 00:02:55.054
I wanna do something to each
one of those computers.

61
00:02:55.054 --> 00:02:59.563
Well, rather than have separate
commands for each computer,

62
00:02:59.563 --> 00:03:03.232
I can use an array to store
a list of computer names.

63
00:03:03.232 --> 00:03:06.124
And then cycle through that array and
say, hey, for

64
00:03:06.124 --> 00:03:09.961
each one of these names of computers
in this array, do this process.

65
00:03:09.961 --> 00:03:13.279
Hey, do web server 1, then do web
server 2, then do web server 3,

66
00:03:13.279 --> 00:03:17.138
or do client 1, then client 2,
then client 3, up to client 200, right?

67
00:03:17.138 --> 00:03:17.791
It'll be a lot easier.

68
00:03:17.791 --> 00:03:20.956
So we work with arrays a lot.

69
00:03:20.956 --> 00:03:23.322
>> Well, you mentioned client 200 and

70
00:03:23.322 --> 00:03:28.134
if I'm working in an environment that
has 10 servers I can remember them all.

71
00:03:28.134 --> 00:03:28.806
>> Yes.

72
00:03:28.806 --> 00:03:33.443
>> And make sure that task executes for
each one, but when I have 200 or more and

73
00:03:33.443 --> 00:03:38.372
I'm even using like typing them all out or
even using like comma separated values.

74
00:03:38.372 --> 00:03:41.109
I might lose one along the way,
if I have to type that in or

75
00:03:41.109 --> 00:03:42.639
put that in every single time.

76
00:03:42.639 --> 00:03:45.820
So this is kind of like removing
some of that human error.

77
00:03:45.820 --> 00:03:46.762
>> Exactly.

78
00:03:46.762 --> 00:03:51.972
Exactly right, or if we wanna store like
some things return arrays of objects,

79
00:03:51.972 --> 00:03:53.856
like when I do a get process.

80
00:03:53.856 --> 00:03:56.271
We don't return just one process, right?

81
00:03:56.271 --> 00:03:59.570
We return all the processes that
are running on that system,

82
00:03:59.570 --> 00:04:03.711
each one being it's own object and now I
can have an array of those objects and

83
00:04:03.711 --> 00:04:06.900
I can work with them individually or
whatever I need to do.

84
00:04:06.900 --> 00:04:10.166
So yeah, we'll definitely see arrays
a lot and hash tables a lot and

85
00:04:10.166 --> 00:04:12.188
I'm gonna throw in order dictionaries.

86
00:04:12.188 --> 00:04:15.464
We did mention, well, we'll talk about
that when we get to hash tables.

87
00:04:15.464 --> 00:04:15.975
>> Okay.

88
00:04:15.975 --> 00:04:17.267
>> Let's focus on arrays for now.

89
00:04:17.267 --> 00:04:19.379
All right, so
let's start by talking about,

90
00:04:19.379 --> 00:04:21.666
let's refresh from our
working with variables.

91
00:04:21.666 --> 00:04:25.709
Remember, an array Is, or a variable
itself is just a container, right?

92
00:04:25.709 --> 00:04:29.090
It's a memory location where I
can store a value, I give it

93
00:04:29.090 --> 00:04:33.312
an easy to recall name and then I can
recall that value whenever I need it.

94
00:04:35.793 --> 00:04:39.743
Arrays are just containers,
just like a normal variable would be,

95
00:04:39.743 --> 00:04:43.086
except they have multiple
slots within that container.

96
00:04:43.086 --> 00:04:46.437
I know years ago when I was-
>> So we're talking of, I'm sorry.

97
00:04:46.437 --> 00:04:49.120
>> Yeah.
>> TSA box verses Bento box.

98
00:04:49.120 --> 00:04:50.130
>> Yes, right?

99
00:04:50.130 --> 00:04:50.653
>> Okay.

100
00:04:50.653 --> 00:04:52.270
>> Where the Bento box has
the individual compartments in it.

101
00:04:52.270 --> 00:04:52.944
>> [LAUGH] Okay.

102
00:04:52.944 --> 00:04:54.283
>> Yeah, exactly, I like that analogy.

103
00:04:54.283 --> 00:04:57.091
I was just gonna say years ago
when I was getting into this,

104
00:04:57.091 --> 00:04:59.399
the analogy was always the egg carton,
right?

105
00:04:59.399 --> 00:04:59.946
>> Okay.

106
00:04:59.946 --> 00:05:02.816
>> Where the carton typically
has a dozen little slots in

107
00:05:02.816 --> 00:05:04.292
there to hold a dozen eggs.

108
00:05:04.292 --> 00:05:07.988
And, so, that would be my array,
it's the carton itself, and

109
00:05:07.988 --> 00:05:12.317
then each one of those slots would be
known as an element within that array.

110
00:05:12.317 --> 00:05:12.832
>> Okay.

111
00:05:12.832 --> 00:05:15.340
>> And, I can have an array of one,
really,

112
00:05:15.340 --> 00:05:19.141
you can have an array with just
one element in it, or multiple,

113
00:05:19.141 --> 00:05:23.472
you can have 2, 5, 20, 100,
it just depends on what you need.

114
00:05:23.472 --> 00:05:27.291
It's not a fixed size thing, we can-
>> Not limited to a dozen.

115
00:05:27.291 --> 00:05:28.161
>> Yeah, exactly.

116
00:05:28.161 --> 00:05:29.313
>> [LAUGH]
>> We're not stuck with a dozen.

117
00:05:29.313 --> 00:05:31.103
We can do more than a dozen.

118
00:05:31.103 --> 00:05:32.767
We could do a baker's dozen if we want.

119
00:05:32.767 --> 00:05:37.209
All right, so let's see, I'll tell you
declaring an array is the easiest thing,

120
00:05:37.209 --> 00:05:39.749
because it's just like
declaring a variable,

121
00:05:39.749 --> 00:05:42.561
except you assign more than
one value to it, right?

122
00:05:42.561 --> 00:05:45.858
Normally when we assign a variable,
we'll just say,

123
00:05:45.858 --> 00:05:48.953
like we did in the early episodes $a=5,
right?

124
00:05:48.953 --> 00:05:50.745
That created a standard variable.

125
00:05:50.745 --> 00:05:54.932
If I would have said $a=5,10,
well now I'm saying hey,

126
00:05:54.932 --> 00:06:00.067
store two variable, two values in
that variable and the PowerShell says

127
00:06:00.067 --> 00:06:04.895
you've got more than one value to store,
we're gonna create an array.

128
00:06:04.895 --> 00:06:05.747
>> Okay.

129
00:06:05.747 --> 00:06:09.657
>> All right, so that's really the easiest
way or one way we can declare variables.

130
00:06:09.657 --> 00:06:11.963
So let's take a look at my screen here and
see what we got.

131
00:06:11.963 --> 00:06:15.845
Now, in order to save a little typing plus
to give you guys something to work with as

132
00:06:15.845 --> 00:06:18.625
you're studying,
you can get a copy of these show notes.

133
00:06:18.625 --> 00:06:22.755
I've kind of started writing things out in
my script pane so that we can just go and

134
00:06:22.755 --> 00:06:23.556
execute them.

135
00:06:23.556 --> 00:06:26.828
Spend a little more time looking at
the results than watching Mike type all

136
00:06:26.828 --> 00:06:27.371
of this in.

137
00:06:27.371 --> 00:06:28.625
>> [LAUGH] Yehey.

138
00:06:28.625 --> 00:06:31.483
>> And as we get further on into our
episodes throughout this series,

139
00:06:31.483 --> 00:06:33.124
the typing is gonna get more and more.

140
00:06:33.124 --> 00:06:37.097
So I figured hey, let's go ahead and
start now, working with our script thing.

141
00:06:37.097 --> 00:06:39.656
All right, so this first line here,

142
00:06:39.656 --> 00:06:45.275
remember one of the great things about the
ISE is I can execute the entire script or

143
00:06:45.275 --> 00:06:50.005
just part of the script using F8 or
my little tiny play button here.

144
00:06:50.005 --> 00:06:52.791
And you don't actually have
to select the entire line.

145
00:06:52.791 --> 00:06:56.614
I mean you can, you can click out there
on your line numbers to select the line.

146
00:06:56.614 --> 00:07:01.329
You can try to highlight and sometimes I
do still highlight because if you have a,

147
00:07:01.329 --> 00:07:06.064
you can actually highlight part of a line
and just execute that if it makes sense.

148
00:07:06.064 --> 00:07:07.295
I'll show you an example later on.

149
00:07:07.295 --> 00:07:10.904
But just to understand that really,
your cursor just has to be on that line.

150
00:07:10.904 --> 00:07:15.230
That makes that line active, and
if I hit F8, it will run just that line.

151
00:07:15.230 --> 00:07:19.270
You can also select multiple lines and
hit F8 or click my little play button.

152
00:07:19.270 --> 00:07:22.014
>> Okay, I know you said you'll
cover that but looking at that 20,

153
00:07:22.014 --> 00:07:24.563
like so if I wanted to omit 21
from that particular command,

154
00:07:24.563 --> 00:07:26.245
you could just not highlight that part?

155
00:07:26.245 --> 00:07:27.115
>> Yeah, I could just do this.

156
00:07:27.115 --> 00:07:27.766
>> Got it.

157
00:07:27.766 --> 00:07:29.511
>> And leave out that comment 21.

So it's simply a matter of calling

00:28:27.250 --> 00:28:29.810
So if you wanted to update an IP

00:28:29.810 --> 00:28:34.400

00:28:35.870 --> 00:28:40.640
You can also use a property, or I should

Remember, an array is an object.

00:28:42.370 --> 00:28:46.366
And if we take a look at, let's say, $A,

we're gonna pipe that out

00:28:51.920 --> 00:28:55.082

00:29:01.815 --> 00:29:05.840

00:29:29.830 --> 00:29:32.985
So if I do dollar sign, in fact let me

$a.

00:29:44.830 --> 00:29:46.630

So it's just another way

Open parentheses.

The index position that I'm

00:30:11.300 --> 00:30:13.600
So I'm saying in the array $a, I

00:30:14.700 --> 00:30:19.590

00:30:19.590 --> 00:30:24.115
Index position three,

00:30:24.115 --> 00:30:25.376

00:30:49.140 --> 00:30:53.720
which is gonna include the value

Or in this case, I have a an array with

00:31:25.300 --> 00:31:30.143

00:31:30.143 --> 00:31:31.060

00:31:31.060 --> 00:31:32.600

00:31:42.640 --> 00:31:45.633

587
00:31:50.135 --> 00:31:51.871
Now, there are some caveats, or

588
00:31:51.871 --> 00:31:55.470
some things we wanna keep in mind
here when we're dealing with this.

00:31:55.470 --> 00:32:00.177
When PowerShell, when I add an element
like this What PowerShell is really

00:32:00.177 --> 00:32:02.269

00:32:02.269 --> 00:32:05.880

00:32:05.880 --> 00:32:10.220
Taking all of the data that was in the old

00:32:10.220 --> 00:32:12.580

00:32:12.580 --> 00:32:16.450
It's all happening beside the scenes but

00:32:16.450 --> 00:32:20.640
aware of is in the background it is

596
00:32:20.640 --> 00:32:22.990

00:32:22.990 --> 00:32:26.820

00:32:28.260 --> 00:32:31.424
And we're doing this kind of

00:32:31.424 --> 00:32:35.303
all of a sudden you're gonna see a

00:32:35.303 --> 00:32:38.605
server [CROSSTALK] what else is doing and

602
00:32:38.605 --> 00:32:43.358
So it is something to be aware of, you
can add elements like this but if you're

00:32:43.358 --> 00:32:48.113
