might wanna watch your performance and

604
00:32:48.113 --> 00:32:53.460
maybe see if there's other ways you might
go about manipulating those arrays.

605
00:32:53.460 --> 00:32:56.754
And it depends again on the system,
how big the array is,

606
00:32:56.754 --> 00:32:58.880
how often you're doing that.

607
00:32:58.880 --> 00:33:02.583
So if you're just doing it now and
again, even though it's a huge array,

608
00:33:02.583 --> 00:33:03.977
it's no big deal, right.

609
00:33:03.977 --> 00:33:08.536
Or if the array's not that big, but
you're doing it dozens, and dozens, and

610
00:33:08.536 --> 00:33:12.490
dozens of times within a script,
maybe it makes an impact, right.

611
00:33:12.490 --> 00:33:15.700
Or if it's a huge array and you're
doing it hundreds of times in a script,

612
00:33:15.700 --> 00:33:17.750
it's most likely gonna cause an impact or

613
00:33:17.750 --> 00:33:20.075
maybe your server's beefy enough
where you don't even notice it,

614
00:33:20.075 --> 00:33:23.030
it's not doing anything else,
it doesn't have any other roles on it.

615
00:33:23.030 --> 00:33:25.420
It's just something that
you've gotta pay attention to,

616
00:33:25.420 --> 00:33:27.900
something to keep in mind if
you start writing scripts and

617
00:33:27.900 --> 00:33:31.130
you start doing things like this and
you see a performance degradation

618
00:33:31.130 --> 00:33:33.670
that's probably one of the first
things you want to look for, right.

619
00:33:33.670 --> 00:33:38.450
Removing elements from array
is really not easy at all.

620
00:33:38.450 --> 00:33:39.828
>> Really not easy.

621
00:33:39.828 --> 00:33:40.828
>> It's not.

622
00:33:40.828 --> 00:33:41.330
>> Okay.

623
00:33:41.330 --> 00:33:46.502
>> It's a complex kind of convoluted
process, I didn't even bother setting

624
00:33:46.502 --> 00:33:51.687
it up because I will tell you it's much
easier to just recreate your array.

625
00:33:51.687 --> 00:33:56.108
Honestly, I mean it can be done and
we can do get dash help,

626
00:33:56.108 --> 00:34:01.730
let's see if I can show you here,
get-helpabout_arrays I think it is.

627
00:34:03.830 --> 00:34:08.787
I don't know if I updated
my help on this guy.

628
00:34:08.787 --> 00:34:11.464
Yeah, I didn't,
I'd have to use my physical machine.

629
00:34:11.464 --> 00:34:15.148
Anyway, [COUGH] do that,
do a get-helpabout_array and

630
00:34:15.148 --> 00:34:18.472
you'll see all the help
that you can get on arrays.

631
00:34:18.472 --> 00:34:20.410
And it'll show you how
to remove an item but

632
00:34:20.410 --> 00:34:23.860
it'll even tell you that a lot of times
that it's easier just to create a new

633
00:34:23.860 --> 00:34:28.580
array rather than trying to remove
a specific element from the array.

634
00:34:29.920 --> 00:34:32.730
And the last thing I want to
show you with the array [COUGH],

635
00:34:32.730 --> 00:34:37.060
excuse me, is this value right here,
which is .length.

636
00:34:37.060 --> 00:34:41.010
This is a property of an array,
remember an array is an object so

637
00:34:41.010 --> 00:34:43.990
it has properties and
methods that we can access.

638
00:34:43.990 --> 00:34:45.700
We do that with a dot, all right.

639
00:34:45.700 --> 00:34:48.740
We got an object dot and
then we have all of their properties and

640
00:34:48.740 --> 00:34:50.580
methods available to us.

641
00:34:50.580 --> 00:34:55.100
Length is one of the properties of
the array and it's a fantastic thing.

642
00:34:55.100 --> 00:35:00.735
We will use this over and over again,
because if we're looping through an array,

643
00:35:00.735 --> 00:35:03.512
as we get into our more complex scripts,

644
00:35:03.512 --> 00:35:06.633
I need to know how many
times to run that loop.

645
00:35:06.633 --> 00:35:12.660
If there's five elements in there,
I want to run it five times, right.

646
00:35:12.660 --> 00:35:15.200
If there are 25 elements in there,
I want to loop through 25 times.

647
00:35:15.200 --> 00:35:20.350
Now there are ways to loop through without
knowing the exact number of elements, but

648
00:35:20.350 --> 00:35:25.240
sometimes I need to, there's the way I'm
writing my script, I need that length and

649
00:35:25.240 --> 00:35:26.030
I'm gonna use an indent.

650
00:35:26.030 --> 00:35:29.790
We'll will show you how to do counters and
count through the elements in the array

651
00:35:29.790 --> 00:35:32.940
but I typically need the length to
help me stop the loop at some point.

652
00:35:32.940 --> 00:35:38.150
I don't want it to run forever and ever
and lock up my machine, what have you.

653
00:35:38.150 --> 00:35:38.953
[COUGH] Excuse me, so

654
00:35:38.953 --> 00:35:42.450
that length is a property that will
show me how many elements are in there.

655
00:35:42.450 --> 00:35:45.596
We run this and say $a.length=7,

656
00:35:45.596 --> 00:35:50.805
that means there are seven
elements if I do a $a, I'll see 1,

657
00:35:50.805 --> 00:35:55.640
2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, so,
indeed there are seven.

658
00:35:56.870 --> 00:36:00.770
You can also do a dot count,
if I back up here and I do a dot and

659
00:36:00.770 --> 00:36:05.629
I use my intelliSEND, you'll see that
count is actually the first one on

660
00:36:05.629 --> 00:36:10.750
the list but notice it's actually
an alias, count equals length.

661
00:36:10.750 --> 00:36:14.570
Because from other languages, we're used
to using count, so they went ahead and

662
00:36:14.570 --> 00:36:18.200
created an alias to make it
a little bit easier to transition.

663
00:36:18.200 --> 00:36:20.900
Length is the actual
property that we want.

664
00:36:20.900 --> 00:36:25.150
You can see int length.right, and
it's got that get method to it, so

665
00:36:25.150 --> 00:36:27.020
go get the length of this array.

666
00:36:27.020 --> 00:36:30.910
Count shows you that, hey,
this is really just an alias for length.

667
00:36:30.910 --> 00:36:33.759
So either one will work,
it doesn't matter which one you use.

668
00:36:34.930 --> 00:36:38.550
Sometimes I like to stick with the,
it really doesn't matter,

669
00:36:38.550 --> 00:36:40.479
it really depends on what
kind of mood I'm in [LAUGH].

670
00:36:40.479 --> 00:36:42.528
>> [LAUGH]
>> If I'm freshly from another language

671
00:36:42.528 --> 00:36:45.540
I've been working on another project and
I come back here,

672
00:36:45.540 --> 00:36:46.998
I might very well use count.

673
00:36:46.998 --> 00:36:49.316
If I have been working in PowerShell for

674
00:36:49.316 --> 00:36:54.247
a couple of days I would probably go with
length, it is just a personal preference.

675
00:36:54.247 --> 00:36:57.595
>> Plus it nice you have that option,
also, so that's pretty cool.

676
00:36:57.595 --> 00:37:00.759
>> Exactly, and heck you might end up
using it so much you make your own alias,

677
00:37:00.759 --> 00:37:04.880
that's even shorter, like ln or something
like that, so you can always do that.

678
00:37:04.880 --> 00:37:05.740
>> Looking at the list here,

679
00:37:05.740 --> 00:37:09.830
Mike, is there anything else you want to
cover before we sign off for today's show?

680
00:37:09.830 --> 00:37:11.770
>> No, I think that about does it.

681
00:37:11.770 --> 00:37:14.880
I'll go ahead and do that count just
because I said you could do it and

682
00:37:14.880 --> 00:37:17.330
you'll see that it comes
up with seven as well.

683
00:37:17.330 --> 00:37:21.393
But I think it gives us a pretty
good beginning look at a arrays,

684
00:37:21.393 --> 00:37:23.350
how we create them, right.

685
00:37:23.350 --> 00:37:27.075
A couple of different
ways we can create them.

686
00:37:27.075 --> 00:37:31.636
One thing I didn't mention with the range
operator you can't do a range of strings,

687
00:37:31.636 --> 00:37:34.670
that's one little gotcha that
a lot of people run into.

688
00:37:34.670 --> 00:37:38.978
They'll say I could do zero dot dot 25 and

689
00:37:38.978 --> 00:37:44.258
I'll get an array of 26 positions,
zero through 25,

690
00:37:44.258 --> 00:37:49.428
that's cool, but I could also do a,
dollar sign a equals

691
00:37:49.428 --> 00:37:54.840
open bracket a dot dot z,
right, and then close bracket.

692
00:37:54.840 --> 00:37:59.210
And think they're gonna get an array that
includes a, b, c, d and all the letters,

693
00:37:59.210 --> 00:38:00.840
right, that range of letters.

694
00:38:00.840 --> 00:38:01.340
it doesn't work that way.
>> Okay.

695
00:38:01.340 --> 00:38:01.876
>> Strings,

696
00:38:01.876 --> 00:38:05.863
it can't do an incrementing and take
each one, it doesn't know what exactly,

697
00:38:05.863 --> 00:38:07.420
what one is coming next.

698
00:38:07.420 --> 00:38:09.660
But you can do ASCII value, right.

699
00:38:09.660 --> 00:38:14.145
We could do the ASCII values for
the characters, so I could do a range of,

700
00:38:14.145 --> 00:38:18.354
what's a good example again,
if you knew the keys you were looking for,

701
00:38:18.354 --> 00:38:21.614
the letters you were looking for,
you could do a range.

702
00:38:21.614 --> 00:38:26.405
I can't remember a capital A is 66,
I can't remember, it's been awhile since I

703
00:38:26.405 --> 00:38:30.247
work with ASCII but you could do
a range 66 dot dot 76 all right.

704
00:38:30.247 --> 00:38:35.552
And then as you call those values
back there's a convert to ASCII

705
00:38:35.552 --> 00:38:41.890
where I could take that number and
convert it to ASCII and get the letter.

706
00:38:41.890 --> 00:38:47.510
So, there's a way to store or
to use range operators with letters but

707
00:38:47.510 --> 00:38:49.680
it's not directly like you
think you might be able to do.

708
00:38:49.680 --> 00:38:54.980
So, don't do a open bracket d dot
dot f and think you're gonna have D,

709
00:38:54.980 --> 00:38:59.170
E, F within that array it's not
gonna work for you, all right.

710
00:38:59.170 --> 00:39:03.510
We saw how to retrieve values,
either using the position.

711
00:39:03.510 --> 00:39:07.270
Remember that the arrays
are a zero index system, so

712
00:39:07.270 --> 00:39:09.910
it's position one is index number zero.

713
00:39:09.910 --> 00:39:13.590
You can also use negative numbers
to work from the end of the array,

714
00:39:13.590 --> 00:39:16.090
that starts with negative one
there is no negative zero.

715
00:39:17.330 --> 00:39:19.050
What else did we do?

716
00:39:19.050 --> 00:39:22.830
We saw how to modify existing elements,
add new elements, and

717
00:39:22.830 --> 00:39:24.150
get the length of those arrays.

718
00:39:24.150 --> 00:39:25.730
So I think that gives us
a pretty good basis for

719
00:39:25.730 --> 00:39:28.850
using arrays as we move
forward through these lessons.

720
00:39:28.850 --> 00:39:29.470
>> Awesome, Mike.

721
00:39:29.470 --> 00:39:32.240
Well, thank you so much for that, and
thank you for joining us as well, but for

722
00:39:32.240 --> 00:39:34.340
this show,
we're going to go ahead and sign out.

723
00:39:34.340 --> 00:39:35.840
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.

724
00:39:35.840 --> 00:39:36.640
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

725
00:39:36.640 --> 00:39:38.360
>> See you next time here at ITPRO.TV.

726
00:39:38.360 --> 00:39:44.757
[MUSIC]

727
00:39:44.757 --> 00:39:47.475
Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: This episode is about using hash tables in PowerShell. You will see how to create hash tables. You will learn how to use hash tables to store key / value pairs, as well as create an ordered dictionary.
episodes.title: Hash Tables
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.240 --> 00:00:01.210
Welcome to ITPro TV.

2
00:00:01.210 --> 00:00:07.568
I'm your host, [CROSSTALK]
>> You're watching ITPro TV.

3
00:00:07.568 --> 00:00:15.210
>> Welcome ladies and gentlemen to
your PowerShell Scripting series.

4
00:00:15.210 --> 00:00:17.200
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

5
00:00:17.200 --> 00:00:20.850
In this episode we'll be taking
a look at hashing tables and

6
00:00:20.850 --> 00:00:23.880
back with us today in studios we have Mr.
Mike Rodrick.

7
00:00:23.880 --> 00:00:24.850
Thank you for joining us Mike.

8
00:00:24.850 --> 00:00:25.520
How are you?

9
00:00:25.520 --> 00:00:26.100
>> I'm doing great.

10
00:00:26.100 --> 00:00:27.140
Thanks for having me Cherokee.

11
00:00:27.140 --> 00:00:27.850
Glad to me here, and

12
00:00:27.850 --> 00:00:32.410
yeah excited, cuz we're gonna take a look
at hash tables in this particular episode.

13
00:00:32.410 --> 00:00:36.310
Which is a pretty cool way, we mentioned
this when did our episodes on working with

14
00:00:36.310 --> 00:00:40.850
variables, we talked about what a hash
table is, but let's just refresh.

15
00:00:40.850 --> 00:00:47.360
Remember, a hash table Is a way
to store key value pairs, right?

16
00:00:47.360 --> 00:00:52.840
So we have a key, a name,
whatever, really it's an object.

17
00:00:52.840 --> 00:00:54.510
It could be anything,
but typically a string,

18
00:00:54.510 --> 00:00:57.660
but I'll show you some cool things you
can do with it when they're not strings.

19
00:00:57.660 --> 00:01:02.688
But you got a key equals value and
you can have a one value pair or

20
00:01:02.688 --> 00:01:06.960
key value pair, hash table,
or it can be multiple.

21
00:01:06.960 --> 00:01:11.970
And we'll separate each one of those
key value pairs with a semicolon.

22
00:01:11.970 --> 00:01:14.390
So and I know it's like wait,
what the heck is he saying?

23
00:01:14.390 --> 00:01:15.630
We need to see this as we do it.

24
00:01:15.630 --> 00:01:16.830
But wait one second.

25
00:01:16.830 --> 00:01:19.060
Let's make sure we've got
a couple of definitions down.

26
00:01:19.060 --> 00:01:21.710
So, hash tables store key value pairs.

27
00:01:21.710 --> 00:01:24.700
You got key equals value.

28
00:01:24.700 --> 00:01:29.082
I'm gonna say they're non deterministic,
I don't know if that's the correct way to

29
00:01:29.082 --> 00:01:31.675
say it, but
they're in non deterministic order.

30
00:01:31.675 --> 00:01:36.940
Which means, when we enter in our hash
table, when we create our hash table,

31
00:01:36.940 --> 00:01:42.690
and we enter in our key value pairs, and
then we return the entire hash table.

32
00:01:42.690 --> 00:01:47.370
We might see that the key value pairs
don't show up in the same order

33
00:01:47.370 --> 00:01:49.830
that we entered them in,
which is kind of odd sometimes.

34
00:01:49.830 --> 00:01:51.990
When you're first working with it,
you're like, wait.

35
00:01:51.990 --> 00:01:53.760
I didn't enter them in that way.

36
00:01:53.760 --> 00:01:55.920
How are they being returned in that way?

37
00:01:55.920 --> 00:01:58.150
So with hash tables,

38
00:01:58.150 --> 00:02:04.590
there is no guarantee on the order that
the key value pairs are gonna be returned.

39
00:02:04.590 --> 00:02:08.390
And most of the time it doesn't matter,
because we're gonna go look for

40
00:02:08.390 --> 00:02:10.560
a particular key, and return that value.

41
00:02:10.560 --> 00:02:12.770
And it doesn't matter that it's sorted.

42
00:02:12.770 --> 00:02:16.870
It's a very efficient way to
run through a bunch of keys,

43
00:02:16.870 --> 00:02:19.940
find a particular value and
return that value.

44
00:02:19.940 --> 00:02:25.760
There are ways to make a hash table
where it is deterministic on order,

45
00:02:25.760 --> 00:02:28.320
but it's really not a hash table anymore.

46
00:02:28.320 --> 00:02:30.850
It's actually called a dictionary,
or an ordered dictionary,

47
00:02:30.850 --> 00:02:33.680
where you can use the ordered keyword, and

48
00:02:33.680 --> 00:02:38.260
I'll show you how to do that,
to create an ordered dictionary.

49
00:02:38.260 --> 00:02:43.280
You can CAST,
CAST means to change a data type.

50
00:02:43.280 --> 00:02:46.300
Convert a INT to a string,

51
00:02:46.300 --> 00:02:49.420
if I want to do concatenation with it or
something like that.

52
00:02:49.420 --> 00:02:54.140
You can CAST a hash table
as a ordered dictionary.

53
00:02:54.140 --> 00:02:56.490
In other words,
change it over to an ordered dictionary.

54
00:02:57.750 --> 00:03:00.380
And now the order that
they're in currently,

55
00:03:00.380 --> 00:03:03.620
will now be the order I
always return them in.

56
00:03:03.620 --> 00:03:06.150
If you go the other way, wait, what is it?

57
00:03:06.150 --> 00:03:10.250
If you have an ordered,
you CAST it into a hash table,

58
00:03:10.250 --> 00:03:13.010
right, you lose the ordered attribute.

59
00:03:13.010 --> 00:03:16.380
And if you try to CAST it back
into an older dictionary,

60
00:03:16.380 --> 00:03:18.730
you're not gonna get that
order of attribute back.

61
00:03:18.730 --> 00:03:22.340
It's not gonna go back to being
sorted as how you entered it.

62
00:03:22.340 --> 00:03:24.920
Typically, I don't think we really
have to worry about that too much,

63
00:03:24.920 --> 00:03:27.920
which is something I
wanted to throw in there.

64
00:03:27.920 --> 00:03:31.640
So when we create these hash tables
we're gonna use the @ symbol.

65
00:03:31.640 --> 00:03:35.124
That's gonna be our indicator to
PowerShell that we wanna create

66
00:03:35.124 --> 00:03:35.893
a hash table.

67
00:03:35.893 --> 00:03:40.939
We're gonna start with an open curly
brace to begin our hash table and

68
00:03:40.939 --> 00:03:46.330
then we're gonna put our key equals
value inside that curly brace.

69
00:03:46.330 --> 00:03:49.517
And if we have more than one,
then we're gonna put a semicolon or

70
00:03:49.517 --> 00:03:51.950
a line break,
I'll show you what I mean by that.

71
00:03:51.950 --> 00:03:56.606
You can just separate out your key
equals value pairs with a semicolon or

72
00:03:56.606 --> 00:04:00.034
a line break and
then however many you have, right?

73
00:04:00.034 --> 00:04:04.514
Semicolon or line break, after line break,
after each one of those key value pairs

74
00:04:04.514 --> 00:04:07.907
and then you wrap the whole thing
up in that ending curly brace.

75
00:04:07.907 --> 00:04:11.855
And you hit Enter, and
you have yourself a hash table, right?

76
00:04:11.855 --> 00:04:16.100
Well there was one other thing
I wanted to say with that and

77
00:04:16.100 --> 00:04:18.913
I thought of it, and
it slipped out of my mind.

78
00:04:18.913 --> 00:04:21.670
Strings, If we are gonna
put strings in here,

79
00:04:21.670 --> 00:04:24.690
we're always gonna put quotes
around our strings, right.

80
00:04:24.690 --> 00:04:27.230
We use our single quotes,
our literal strings.

81
00:04:27.230 --> 00:04:30.240
I mean, you could use expendables if
you had variable names going in there.

82
00:04:31.628 --> 00:04:35.640
If value is a string, well, strings
are always gonna have quotes on it.

83
00:04:35.640 --> 00:04:37.590
If the key of the value, but

84
00:04:37.590 --> 00:04:42.620
if the key has a space in the name,
we also wanna put quotes around that.

85
00:04:42.620 --> 00:04:45.890
I'm not a big fan of putting
spaces in the name of my keys.

86
00:04:45.890 --> 00:04:48.970
It makes it a lot easier to
work with if I skip that part.

87
00:04:48.970 --> 00:04:50.270
But just understand that you can.

88
00:04:50.270 --> 00:04:53.450
You would just need quotes,
because it will see that break.

89
00:04:53.450 --> 00:04:57.640
And it's wait key,
there's no equals, there's no value.

90
00:04:57.640 --> 00:05:00.960
And then I get this next value and
I don't want to do with it, right?

91
00:05:00.960 --> 00:05:03.030
So if you're gonna do
spaces in your key names,

92
00:05:03.030 --> 00:05:05.680
you have to have quotes around them.

93
00:05:05.680 --> 00:05:08.070
>> All right, Mike,
where would we be using hash tables?

94
00:05:08.070 --> 00:05:12.490
You're talking about keys and I'm
thinking, my mind Gges to authentication,

95
00:05:12.490 --> 00:05:15.710
we're talking about security here,
so what kind of use case.

96
00:05:15.710 --> 00:05:17.470
>> It's actually nothing to do with that.

97
00:05:17.470 --> 00:05:18.345
It's funny-
>> Perfect.

98
00:05:18.345 --> 00:05:19.530
[LAUGH]
>> Yes, I know.

99
00:05:19.530 --> 00:05:20.590
It's a great question, right?

100
00:05:20.590 --> 00:05:23.410
>> Yeah.
>> I hear hashing, or you hear hash, and

101
00:05:23.410 --> 00:05:30.200
you think hashing, hashing algorithms,
encoding this into a message digest.

102
00:05:30.200 --> 00:05:32.480
That's really not what we're doing here.

103
00:05:32.480 --> 00:05:34.714
It has nothing to do
with hashing algorithms.

104
00:05:34.714 --> 00:05:38.130
>> Good. [LAUGH] >> It just happens to be
the name that they decided to use for it.

105
00:05:38.130 --> 00:05:38.780
>> Yay.
>> Yeah, right [LAUGH]?

00:17:48.080 --> 00:17:51.730
then point it to the hash table
that already has all that stored.

334
00:17:51.730 --> 00:17:55.718
First name is Cherokee, last name
equals Boose, role equals edutainer.

335
00:17:55.718 --> 00:17:58.270
And I don't have to type
that all out in the command.

336
00:17:58.270 --> 00:18:02.161
And that gives me reusability
of that parameter set.

337
00:18:02.161 --> 00:18:07.063
So, yeah, there's a lot of uses for
hash tables.

338
00:18:07.063 --> 00:18:11.017
All right, let's take a look at this
one that I have here on my screen.

339
00:18:11.017 --> 00:18:13.817
Remember what I said that
when we look at hash tables,

340
00:18:13.817 --> 00:18:16.440
the hash table itself is an object, right?

341
00:18:16.440 --> 00:18:18.580
It has properties and
methods that we can use.

342
00:18:18.580 --> 00:18:23.630
We saw the dot keys,
the dot values, and then a keyname.

343
00:18:23.630 --> 00:18:28.470
But within the hash table,
the key is an object, right?

344
00:18:28.470 --> 00:18:30.930
The value is an object.

345
00:18:30.930 --> 00:18:34.147
We can store objects within
the hash table as well.

346
00:18:34.147 --> 00:18:36.940
Remember, everything in PowerShell
ends up being an object,

347
00:18:36.940 --> 00:18:39.550
it's what makes PowerShell so powerful.

348
00:18:40.740 --> 00:18:44.330
So in this case,
I'm going to do a new hash table,

349
00:18:44.330 --> 00:18:46.512
and I'm going to call it svc info.

350
00:18:46.512 --> 00:18:49.897
All right,
that's the name I'm going to assign it.

351
00:18:49.897 --> 00:18:51.437
At open brace.

352
00:18:51.437 --> 00:18:58.480
And then I'm going to do a string for
my key name, okay, or my key.

353
00:18:58.480 --> 00:19:01.510
Remember, strings are always
going to be enclosed in quotes.

354
00:19:01.510 --> 00:19:04.698
Equals, and then for my value,

355
00:19:04.698 --> 00:19:09.666
I'm actually going to do
a get dash service dhcp.

356
00:19:09.666 --> 00:19:13.561
So I'm going to go get that service dhcp.

357
00:19:13.561 --> 00:19:16.252
If I run get-servicedhcp, all right?

358
00:19:16.252 --> 00:19:21.690
I return information about
that particular service.

359
00:19:22.810 --> 00:19:29.400
So I'm gonna store this
information basically in this key.

360
00:19:29.400 --> 00:19:31.823
>> But dynamically, not that information
just whatever that result would be if you

361
00:19:31.823 --> 00:19:33.170
were running that command line.

362
00:19:33.170 --> 00:19:34.003
>> Exactly right.

363
00:19:34.003 --> 00:19:38.300
When I go create that hash tables,
it'll go grab this information.

364
00:19:38.300 --> 00:19:39.619
When I grab that hash table.

365
00:19:39.619 --> 00:19:43.814
Now, it doesn't automatically like
update periodically, it's not going to,

366
00:19:43.814 --> 00:19:46.571
say every five minutes I
would have to recreate this.

367
00:19:46.571 --> 00:19:47.242
Actually, you know what?

368
00:19:47.242 --> 00:19:48.330
I take that back.

369
00:19:48.330 --> 00:19:49.880
Because I am not storing, you are right.

370
00:19:49.880 --> 00:19:53.250
It would update that every time
I call that particular value.

371
00:19:53.250 --> 00:19:54.590
We can test it out.

372
00:19:54.590 --> 00:20:01.200
We'll double-check, we'll make
sure Mike is not lying to us here.

373
00:20:01.200 --> 00:20:04.287
All right, so let's run this and
see what we get.

374
00:20:04.287 --> 00:20:06.618
So now I've created my hash table.

375
00:20:06.618 --> 00:20:09.657
So now we're gonna use our commands.

376
00:20:09.657 --> 00:20:16.811
We'll say,
dollar sign service info dot dhcp.

377
00:20:16.811 --> 00:20:19.320
Look, dhcp client is running just fine.

378
00:20:19.320 --> 00:20:20.238
Status is good.

379
00:20:20.238 --> 00:20:22.501
Dollar sign svc.dns cache.

380
00:20:22.501 --> 00:20:25.818
Well, that service is running.

381
00:20:25.818 --> 00:20:30.881
So, I mean, something like this, I can
shorten up service info to maybe one or

382
00:20:30.881 --> 00:20:35.750
two characters, and you can see where
it can quickly run through a whole set

383
00:20:35.750 --> 00:20:36.386
>> And just check for

384
00:20:36.386 --> 00:20:37.420
maintenance purposes.

385
00:20:37.420 --> 00:20:39.020
>> Yes, exactly.

386
00:20:39.020 --> 00:20:40.990
This list could be much, much longer.

387
00:20:42.330 --> 00:20:47.544
There's actually another thing I might
do is, because this is an object, right?

388
00:20:47.544 --> 00:20:51.111
I could do dot status, right?

389
00:20:51.111 --> 00:20:52.498
So we could even do this differently.

390
00:20:52.498 --> 00:20:53.503
Let's try something.

391
00:20:53.503 --> 00:20:55.185
You wanna change it up on the fly?

392
00:20:55.185 --> 00:20:57.053
>> It always works great when we do that.

393
00:20:57.053 --> 00:20:58.470
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Let's do it.

394
00:20:58.470 --> 00:21:01.445
>> It never blows up when
the red light is on, right?

395
00:21:01.445 --> 00:21:04.140
>> [LAUGH]
>> Let's do another one, and

396
00:21:04.140 --> 00:21:08.254
we'll see if we can do it
right here on the camera live.

397
00:21:08.254 --> 00:21:15.670
Say dollar sign, svc, excuse me,
status, equals, at symbol, open brace.

398
00:21:15.670 --> 00:21:22.466
And then for my first value,
I'm actually going to grab this,

399
00:21:22.466 --> 00:21:27.481
because it's a lot easier
than typing it out.

400
00:21:27.481 --> 00:21:31.144
Is gonna be equal to that again.

401
00:21:37.291 --> 00:21:43.782
Let's just copy that again because
I'm such a lazy [INAUDIBLE].

402
00:21:43.782 --> 00:21:45.360
All right, that, status.

403
00:21:45.360 --> 00:21:50.308
And we might as well do both of them.

404
00:21:50.308 --> 00:21:52.451
So let's take this one.

405
00:21:53.665 --> 00:21:56.038
And let's do dot status.

406
00:21:56.038 --> 00:22:00.798
And then let's close that brace,
and let's see what we get.

407
00:22:00.798 --> 00:22:05.436
All right, so we'll execute.

408
00:22:05.436 --> 00:22:06.310
No red text?

409
00:22:06.310 --> 00:22:07.720
Always a good thing.

410
00:22:07.720 --> 00:22:12.624
And now if I do dollar sign sv status dot

411
00:22:22.488 --> 00:22:24.450
That's a good question,
I did not give that a name.

412
00:22:24.450 --> 00:22:26.630
I wonder how I'm gonna access that now.

413
00:22:27.990 --> 00:22:29.410
Let's just get the whole thing.

414
00:22:29.410 --> 00:22:31.060
There you go.

415
00:22:31.060 --> 00:22:34.790
I'm trying to recall how we would now,
because it's not really a name or

416
00:22:34.790 --> 00:22:36.700
a string.

417
00:22:36.700 --> 00:22:39.530
I think I have to type that out,
I have to double-check on that.

418
00:22:39.530 --> 00:22:43.380
But here you can see by just
returning the hash table, right,

419
00:22:43.380 --> 00:22:46.840
I can see both of those services and
their current status.

420
00:22:46.840 --> 00:22:49.170
So a quick easy way to automate.

421
00:22:49.170 --> 00:22:51.852
Yeah, I understand,
I could do a get process, right?

422
00:22:51.852 --> 00:22:52.700
Or a get service.

423
00:22:52.700 --> 00:22:55.466
But if there's three-
>> Or use slightly more system center,

424
00:22:55.466 --> 00:22:57.234
some kind of advanced solution.

425
00:22:57.234 --> 00:23:00.167
But this is being innovative or thinking,

426
00:23:00.167 --> 00:23:05.050
working with what you have, I guess is-
>> Yeah, a quick easy way maybe.

427
00:23:05.050 --> 00:23:08.182
There's only three particular services I
need to check on on those Web Servers to

428
00:23:08.182 --> 00:23:11.471
make sure they're running, and I have to
do it every morning or every hour, right?

429
00:23:11.471 --> 00:23:15.127
So we can start using that hash table
that has a list of my servers and

430
00:23:15.127 --> 00:23:18.410
their IP addresses, and
I can start pumping that in again.

431
00:23:18.410 --> 00:23:20.760
We'll get into our loops and
our constructs, but

00:23:20.760 --> 00:23:23.400
maybe I combine that with this.

433
00:23:23.400 --> 00:23:27.650
Or each one of the computers in that hash
table go get these three services and

00:23:27.650 --> 00:23:29.570
give me their status, right?

435
00:23:29.570 --> 00:23:34.490
And again, start automating some of this
daily routine that we have to do, or

436
00:23:34.490 --> 00:23:36.635
anything that we have to do repetitively.

437
00:23:36.635 --> 00:23:40.137
I hope that kinda opens your
mind a little bit, and go wow,

438
00:23:40.137 --> 00:23:44.787
it's not just key-value pairs,
like storing states and their capital, or

439
00:23:44.787 --> 00:23:47.021
computer name and their IP address.

440
00:23:47.021 --> 00:23:50.963
We can, because everything
in PowerShell is an object,

441
00:23:50.963 --> 00:23:54.502
we can store objects even as the key or
as the value.

442
00:23:54.502 --> 00:23:59.002
>> I think that's one of the reasons why,
I know I'm like, I love PowerShell so

443
00:23:59.002 --> 00:24:03.919
much is for the fact, I'm sure it's like
this with many scripting languages We look

444
00:24:03.919 --> 00:24:07.589
at something and see how it performs,
and then I think, okay,

445
00:24:07.589 --> 00:24:09.145
well, how can I use this?

446
00:24:09.145 --> 00:24:13.140
But Mike, you may have a totally different
perspective on how you would use that.

447
00:24:13.140 --> 00:24:16.055
And just talking about it and
sharing this information,

448
00:24:16.055 --> 00:24:18.220
we don't know what we'll come up with.

449
00:24:18.220 --> 00:24:19.140
>> I know.
>> [LAUGH]

450
00:24:19.140 --> 00:24:22.000
>> We talked about this back when we

451
00:24:22.000 --> 00:24:23.910
were all sitting back off camera.

452
00:24:23.910 --> 00:24:25.710
We talk about this kind of thing a lot,
and

00:24:25.710 --> 00:24:30.750
it's really cool that with programming,
there's always more than one way to go.

454
00:24:30.750 --> 00:24:31.390
>> Right.

455
00:24:31.390 --> 00:24:35.140
>> And not to say that one way might be
better than the other, or more efficient

456
00:24:35.140 --> 00:24:39.370
than the other, for sure, but one of
the things I love about PowerShell and

457
00:24:39.370 --> 00:24:42.200
programming in general is it's logical,
right?

458
00:24:43.220 --> 00:24:46.100
It's doing what you tell
it to do even though

459
00:24:46.100 --> 00:24:47.770
it's not giving you the results you want.

460
00:24:47.770 --> 00:24:49.622
That just means you're not
telling it the right way, right?

461
00:24:49.622 --> 00:24:52.506
>> [LAUGH]
>> And that can be frustrating sometimes,

462
00:24:52.506 --> 00:24:55.880
but it's very logical,
and it's like a puzzle.

463
00:24:55.880 --> 00:24:57.800
This is the result I want.

464
00:24:57.800 --> 00:24:58.820
How can I obtain this?

465
00:24:58.820 --> 00:25:03.060
What's the most efficient,
effective way to get that information, and

466
00:25:03.060 --> 00:25:04.330
that's what programming's all about.

467
00:25:04.330 --> 00:25:07.100
So it's really, really fun stuff, I think.

468
00:25:07.100 --> 00:25:08.446
Hopefully, you guys do as well.

469
00:25:08.446 --> 00:25:11.051
All right, I know we got
a few minutes left, Cherokee.

470
00:25:11.051 --> 00:25:15.683
I wanna show us that ordered
dictionary as well, yeah.

471
00:25:15.683 --> 00:25:16.228
>> Okay.

472
00:25:16.228 --> 00:25:17.780
>> So let's take a look at that.

473
00:25:17.780 --> 00:25:22.080
Let me, I'm gonna save my changes to
that script real quick just in case

00:25:22.080 --> 00:25:26.320
I goof anything up, so you guys have the
information to play with after the fact.

475
00:25:26.320 --> 00:25:31.170
So I'm gonna go up back here to our
original hash tables that we created.

476
00:25:31.170 --> 00:25:35.838
Remember, if I do $ip we're
gonna see that they are returned

00:25:35.838 --> 00:25:39.501
not in the order that I
entered those values in.

478
00:25:39.501 --> 00:25:42.115
All right, and
that's just the way hash tables are.

479
00:25:42.115 --> 00:25:49.568
But if I change this up, all right,
if I go in front of this ip.

00:25:49.568 --> 00:25:51.101
And let's change this.

00:25:51.101 --> 00:25:54.263
I'm gonna actually create a different

00:25:54.263 --> 00:25:57.600
I don't override our originals,
so we can kinda compare.

483
00:25:57.600 --> 00:26:01.174
So I'll say ipS, or how about ip2?

484
00:26:01.174 --> 00:26:02.467
Just to make that clear.

485
00:26:02.467 --> 00:26:07.270
And right in front of my at symbol,
what really starts the declaration of

486
00:26:07.270 --> 00:26:12.320
the hash table, that's where
we're gonna add in my open brace.

487
00:26:12.320 --> 00:26:18.760
I'm sorry, not open brace,
open bracket, ordered, close bracket.

488
00:26:18.760 --> 00:26:21.700
And that's it,
that's all you have to do, all right?

489
00:26:21.700 --> 00:26:22.812
So we'll go ahead and create this one.

490
00:26:25.970 --> 00:26:32.321
And now, we will return $ip2,
and take a look at the order.

491
00:26:32.321 --> 00:26:37.086
01, 02, 03, 04,
exactly as I entered them in.

492
00:26:37.086 --> 00:26:39.776
And it will always return in that order,
all right,

493
00:26:39.776 --> 00:26:43.334
no matter how many times I retrieve it,
always gonna be in the order.

494
00:26:43.334 --> 00:26:46.370
So at this point now,
I don't have a hash table.

495
00:26:46.370 --> 00:26:50.670
I have an ordered dictionary, or
dictionary object, depending on if you're

496
00:26:50.670 --> 00:26:53.540
coming from other languages,
dictionary object or ordered dictionary.

497
00:26:55.340 --> 00:26:56.450
That's all you had to do.

498
00:26:56.450 --> 00:26:57.273
You do want to be careful.

499
00:26:57.273 --> 00:27:01.238
One of the gotchas that Microsoft calls
out in some of their help docs is,

500
00:27:01.238 --> 00:27:03.389
they'll see people trying to do this.

501
00:27:05.363 --> 00:27:09.724
Where I put that ordered out
in front of the variable name,

502
00:27:09.724 --> 00:27:15.610
which when we declare it as an int, or
a bool, or a string, that's what we do.

503
00:27:15.610 --> 00:27:17.760
So it's a very common mistake.

504
00:27:17.760 --> 00:27:19.671
It will fail if I do that.

505
00:27:19.671 --> 00:27:22.469
Let's execute that.

506
00:27:22.469 --> 00:27:27.401
An ordered attribute can be specified
only on a hash literal node,

507
00:27:27.401 --> 00:27:29.610
not on my variable out there.

508
00:27:29.610 --> 00:27:31.740
So you will get a failure
if you try to do that way.

509
00:27:31.740 --> 00:27:33.885
Let me undo that, put that back.

510
00:27:33.885 --> 00:27:37.575
We'll put it over there,
run it, and we'll run just fine.

511
00:27:37.575 --> 00:27:41.418
So just make sure there that that
keyword there, that attribute ordered,

512
00:27:41.418 --> 00:27:43.675
comes in front of the at symbol,
all right,

513
00:27:43.675 --> 00:27:46.555
in front of the actual declaration for
that hash value.

514
00:27:46.555 --> 00:27:48.573
Now, once I've created that,

515
00:27:48.573 --> 00:27:52.626
working with it is no different
than working with my hash table.

516
00:27:52.626 --> 00:27:58.540
All right, $ip2.SVR03, all right.

517
00:27:58.540 --> 00:28:00.246
And I return that IP address.

518
00:28:00.246 --> 00:28:04.032
So no different there as far
as the way I work with that.

519
00:28:04.032 --> 00:28:10.190
I can still do $ip2.keys, right?

520
00:28:10.190 --> 00:28:11.590
I can return the keys.

521
00:28:11.590 --> 00:28:14.670
The difference is not in
how I work with it, but

522
00:28:14.670 --> 00:28:16.420
how the results are send back to me?

523
00:28:16.420 --> 00:28:19.940
Notice again, the keys are sorted,
01, 02, 03, 04.

524
00:28:19.940 --> 00:28:23.410
Always gonna be that way because
it is an ordered dictionary.

525
00:28:23.410 --> 00:28:28.210
So hopefully, that gives you an idea
of what we can do with hash tables,

526
00:28:28.210 --> 00:28:33.388
how we create them, how we can work with
them, manipulate them after the fact.

527
00:28:33.388 --> 00:28:35.750
What else?

528
00:28:35.750 --> 00:28:39.710
We also look that the order of
dictionaries and alternative,

529
00:28:39.710 --> 00:28:44.700
if you need to make sure that those
key value pairs are always returned in

530
00:28:44.700 --> 00:28:46.880
the order that you entered them.

531
00:28:46.880 --> 00:28:47.510
>> Okay, so

532
00:28:47.510 --> 00:28:50.770
I'm kind of excited to see what's coming
up next, because we're on a role here.

533
00:28:50.770 --> 00:28:53.360
So thank you for that, Mike,
and thank you for joining us.

534
00:28:53.360 --> 00:28:56.018
You don't wanna miss whatever it
is we have coming up next, but for

535
00:28:56.018 --> 00:28:57.660
this show we'll go ahead and sign out.

536
00:28:57.660 --> 00:28:58.940
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.

537
00:28:58.940 --> 00:28:59.545
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

538
00:28:59.545 --> 00:29:02.158
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

depending on my results, it's gonna round
down, sometimes depending on my results

723
00:37:00.315 --> 00:37:03.025
it's gonna round up and
I've gotta account for that.

724
00:37:03.025 --> 00:37:04.045
>> What did he say?

725
00:37:04.045 --> 00:37:04.940
>> Absolutely.

726
00:37:04.940 --> 00:37:06.475
>> [LAUGH]
>> He said, that would make me

727
00:37:06.475 --> 00:37:09.475
really crazy [LAUGH] He's like
I've never seen that before.

728
00:37:09.475 --> 00:37:14.105
So it is a little bit strange and that's
why I wanted to make sure I pointed it out

729
00:37:14.105 --> 00:37:18.480
to you, cuz it's different
than what we're used to and

730
00:37:18.480 --> 00:37:20.990
it's something that you're gonna
have to take into account.

731
00:37:20.990 --> 00:37:24.640
Keep in mind this is only
if I cast as an int, right?

732
00:37:24.640 --> 00:37:30.830
If I let PowerShell do it's thing, then it
would dynamically type that as a double

733
00:37:30.830 --> 00:37:35.598
and I'll have those decimal points anyway
but there's definitely cases where.

734
00:37:35.598 --> 00:37:40.660
Let's say we've got a variable
that we created earlier and

735
00:37:40.660 --> 00:37:43.950
it was strictly typed as an int, and
now I'm doing a mathematical problem and

736
00:37:43.950 --> 00:37:47.150
I'm dumping the results into that
variable, not thinking about the fact

737
00:37:47.150 --> 00:37:50.940
that my result is a double, and I'm
putting it into a variable that's an int.

738
00:37:50.940 --> 00:37:55.540
I'm going to get a failure or
it's going to round it in this case and

739
00:37:55.540 --> 00:37:58.000
I'm gonna get a result
that I might not expect.

740
00:37:58.000 --> 00:38:01.100
So it's something we definitely
have to be aware of.

741
00:38:01.100 --> 00:38:04.110
>> Well, that was quite a doozy there for
that episode.

742
00:38:04.110 --> 00:38:07.545
I'm glad you were here to help
me understand everything.

743
00:38:07.545 --> 00:38:10.980
[LAUGH] We'll see if I can retain it but
thank you for that, Mike.

744
00:38:10.980 --> 00:38:14.828
And thank you guys for joining us as well,
but we have additional operators to cover,

745
00:38:14.828 --> 00:38:18.423
so you don't wanna miss that, but for
this show, we'll go ahead and sign out.

746
00:38:18.423 --> 00:38:19.796
I've been your host Cherokee Boose.

747
00:38:19.796 --> 00:38:20.436
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

748
00:38:20.436 --> 00:38:23.621
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

749
00:38:23.621 --> 00:38:29.548
[MUSIC]

750
00:38:29.548 --> 00:38:32.336
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, we cover assignment operators. You will learn how to use assignment operators to assign values to variables. You will also see how assignment operators are used to perform numeric operations on values during assignment.
episodes.title: Assignment Operators
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.210 --> 00:00:07.293
Welcome to ITPROTV I'm
your host Don [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:07.293 --> 00:00:11.871
>> [SOUND] You're watching ITPROTV.

3
00:00:11.871 --> 00:00:16.280
>> Welcome to your PowerShell Scripting
Series, I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

4
00:00:16.280 --> 00:00:20.100
In this episode we'll be taking
a look at our assignment operators.

5
00:00:20.100 --> 00:00:23.538
And with us today back in studios we
have Mister Mike Roderick thanks for

6
00:00:23.538 --> 00:00:25.330
joining us today Mike, how are you?

7
00:00:25.330 --> 00:00:26.100
>> I'm doing great Cherokee.

8
00:00:26.100 --> 00:00:28.150
Thanks for having me back and
excited as always.

9
00:00:28.150 --> 00:00:31.190
We are continuing our conversation
on operators as you said and

10
00:00:31.190 --> 00:00:35.810
this one focusing in on those
good old assignment operators.

11
00:00:35.810 --> 00:00:37.350
And we've already hinted at this right?

12
00:00:37.350 --> 00:00:41.190
When we first started working with
variables we really had to at that point

13
00:00:41.190 --> 00:00:44.210
talk a little bit about
an assignment operator.

14
00:00:44.210 --> 00:00:48.030
We said it was the equal
sign in PowerShell.

15
00:00:48.030 --> 00:00:52.380
A single equals is our
assignment operators.

16
00:00:52.380 --> 00:00:54.670
And you know what,
I got the wrong one pulled up there.

17
00:00:54.670 --> 00:00:56.910
There we go, we didn't go to
my screen yet, so it's okay.

18
00:00:58.090 --> 00:00:59.150
So the equal sign.

19
00:00:59.150 --> 00:01:00.030
We've talked about that.

20
00:01:00.030 --> 00:01:03.430
That is our basic assignment
operator In PowerShell,

21
00:01:03.430 --> 00:01:07.420
allows me to say,
dollar sign A equals four.

22
00:01:07.420 --> 00:01:12.100
We are assigning the value
four into that variable, or

23
00:01:12.100 --> 00:01:17.690
dollar sign B equals server 0/1,
as a string, right, or an array.

24
00:01:17.690 --> 00:01:23.860
We use that equal sign to assign a value
to our variable and so that one I

25
00:01:23.860 --> 00:01:26.620
think we're already familiar with, that's
that first one that I have listed here.

26
00:01:26.620 --> 00:01:29.821
Sets the value of a variable
to the specified value.

27
00:01:29.821 --> 00:01:35.430
I also have plus equals, so
we have combined two symbols here.

28
00:01:35.430 --> 00:01:38.450
And the plus equals depending
on what we're doing

29
00:01:38.450 --> 00:01:42.690
increase the value of a variable
by the specified value.

30
00:01:42.690 --> 00:01:46.710
So I'd have a variable on one side,
on the left side of my operant and

31
00:01:46.710 --> 00:01:52.180
then I'd have plus equals, and then on the
right by how much I wanted to increase it.

32
00:01:52.180 --> 00:01:55.980
And again I'll show you examples, so
right now I'm just kinda defining these.

33
00:01:55.980 --> 00:01:59.060
So I increased the value of
a variable by the specified value,

34
00:01:59.060 --> 00:02:04.260
or append the specified
value to the existing value.

35
00:02:04.260 --> 00:02:09.200
It's gonna depend on what we're dealing
with as far as the data type goes.

36
00:02:09.200 --> 00:02:13.300
That is supposed to be a minus equal and
that's a typo on my part there, it looks

37
00:02:13.300 --> 00:02:19.030
like an underscore equal, but that should
be a minus equal just like the plus equal.

38
00:02:19.030 --> 00:02:23.701
Minus equal will decrease the value
of a variable by the specified value.

39
00:02:23.701 --> 00:02:28.910
But notice I don't have or
a remove the specified value.

40
00:02:28.910 --> 00:02:32.230
Right, so the minus symbol just
like in our arithmetic operators,

41
00:02:32.230 --> 00:02:36.670
the plus can do more than just add,
it can do, concatenation, with strings,

42
00:02:36.670 --> 00:02:38.070
arrays and hashes.

43
00:02:38.070 --> 00:02:41.780
And in the assignment the plus
can also work with strings and

44
00:02:41.780 --> 00:02:44.190
arrays and hashes the minus does not.

45
00:02:44.190 --> 00:02:46.490
The minus only does subtraction.

46
00:02:46.490 --> 00:02:50.078
So we it can decrease the value of
the variable by the specified value.

47
00:02:50.078 --> 00:02:55.780
Multiplication then would do the same
multiply by the specified value or

48
00:02:55.780 --> 00:03:00.260
if it's not an integer append
the specified value to the existing value.

49
00:03:00.260 --> 00:03:04.100
Division just divides like subtraction
there's not a lot of other

50
00:03:04.100 --> 00:03:04.770
things that it can do.

51
00:03:05.770 --> 00:03:09.854
Modular divide the value of
a variable by the specified value and

52
00:03:09.854 --> 00:03:13.190
then assign the remainder to the variable.

53
00:03:13.190 --> 00:03:17.931
Go ahead and do the module and
then assign the remainder to the variable.

54
00:03:19.410 --> 00:03:20.890
And then increase the value.

55
00:03:20.890 --> 00:03:23.940
Or the plus plus,
increase the value of a variable,

56
00:03:23.940 --> 00:03:28.310
assignable property or
array element by one.

57
00:03:28.310 --> 00:03:32.779
Or the minus minus,
decrease the value of a variable,

58
00:03:32.779 --> 00:03:36.577
assignable property or
array element by one.

59
00:03:36.577 --> 00:03:41.828
So those are the operators that we
are gonna cover here in this episode so

60
00:03:41.828 --> 00:03:44.650
let's go take a look at that, right?

61
00:03:44.650 --> 00:03:47.550
And here we go we'll start with our equals
and again I know we've already seen

62
00:03:47.550 --> 00:03:50.660
this a little bit but nothing wrong
with doing a little refresh right?

63
00:03:50.660 --> 00:03:51.330
>> That's right.

64
00:03:51.330 --> 00:03:55.940
>> So dollar sign A equals
ten I'll execute that.

65
00:03:55.940 --> 00:03:59.990
And if we call back, A of course we
probably know what we are gonna get,

66
00:03:59.990 --> 00:04:02.590
all right, the value of ten.

67
00:04:02.590 --> 00:04:06.428
Also works for strings though,

68
00:04:06.428 --> 00:04:10.842
I do $b = Power, and we call back b.

69
00:04:10.842 --> 00:04:13.940
We are gonna see the b now
stores the string Power, so

70
00:04:13.940 --> 00:04:16.700
we are assigning that
value to that variable.

71
00:04:17.860 --> 00:04:24.290
If we assign more than one value
to a variable in a single step,

72
00:04:24.290 --> 00:04:26.660
we're going to be creating an array.

73
00:04:26.660 --> 00:04:30.478
And so here I've got three integers,
I execute that.

74
00:04:30.478 --> 00:04:35.490
I've got dollar sign C,
dollar sign C, now equals that array.

75
00:04:37.290 --> 00:04:40.720
And if we were to do like
a dollar sign A.git type and

76
00:04:40.720 --> 00:04:45.710
you do have to spell that right.

77
00:04:45.710 --> 00:04:49.230
That's why tab auto complete
is the best way to go.

78
00:04:49.230 --> 00:04:50.440
Notice that A is an integer.

79
00:04:50.440 --> 00:04:53.860
Because I took an integer and
put it in there dollar sign A or

80
00:04:53.860 --> 00:04:56.630
that variable now has
an integer data type.

81
00:04:56.630 --> 00:05:01.332
If we do $b.gettype,

82
00:05:01.332 --> 00:05:05.097
and another typo.

83
00:05:05.097 --> 00:05:10.790
Like I say, that's a string and you
probably guessed what $c is going to be.

84
00:05:12.090 --> 00:05:17.010
But, just to prove it ourselves,
we can see that is an array, right?

85
00:05:18.490 --> 00:05:23.300
What about, in this case,
I've got a hash table.

86
00:05:23.300 --> 00:05:26.362
So I can store a hash table,
and we've seen this already,

87
00:05:26.362 --> 00:05:28.740
I can store a hash table in an array.

88
00:05:28.740 --> 00:05:31.371
We call that dollar sign D.

89
00:05:31.371 --> 00:05:33.077
We get my hash table back.

90
00:05:33.077 --> 00:05:36.560
And then Cherokee, you were talking
about this one the other day.

91
00:05:36.560 --> 00:05:41.500
This one is a I'm taking advantage of
something that's built in to PowerShell.

92
00:05:41.500 --> 00:05:45.621
It can actually convert kilobytes,
megabytes, gigabytes, not terabytes or

93
00:05:45.621 --> 00:05:46.610
petabytes, yet.

94
00:05:46.610 --> 00:05:51.230
I'm sure that will come, but
it can actually do the math for me and

95
00:05:51.230 --> 00:05:53.419
convert that into kilobytes.

96
00:05:53.419 --> 00:05:55.018
So I thought I'd show you
that one really quick,

97
00:05:55.018 --> 00:05:56.270
I promised you we'd take a look at it.

98
00:05:56.270 --> 00:05:58.950
So dollar sign E equals 10 kilobytes.

99
00:05:58.950 --> 00:06:02.450
I run that and then we call back E,

100
00:06:02.450 --> 00:06:07.951
we'll see it actually equals 10240, right?

101
00:06:07.951 --> 00:06:12.599
So when I had multiplied it out,
by 10240, and

102
00:06:12.599 --> 00:06:16.940
gave you my value in bytes
instead of kilobytes.

103
00:06:16.940 --> 00:06:20.110
It will work with megabytes and
gigabytes as well.

104
00:06:20.110 --> 00:06:24.166
So I do MB for
megabytes I execute that and

105
00:06:24.166 --> 00:06:30.371
we call back e it also gives
me 10,485,760 bytes and

106
00:06:30.371 --> 00:06:35.145
ten megabytes so
it's not storing the 10MB or

107
00:06:35.145 --> 00:06:43.800
the 10 KB it's actually performing
a mathematical operation when we do this.

108
00:06:43.800 --> 00:06:49.040
It's basically making it easier for
us to enter that value.

109
00:06:49.040 --> 00:06:53.371
Instead of having to type out 10485760,

110
00:06:53.371 --> 00:06:58.950
I can simply put 10 mb and
it will store the appropriate value.

111
00:06:58.950 --> 00:07:02.115
I will tell you honestly
more often than not,

112
00:07:02.115 --> 00:07:05.290
I end up trying to convert
back the other way.

113
00:07:05.290 --> 00:07:08.976
And when we get into our functions I'll
show you how to build a real quick

114
00:07:08.976 --> 00:07:12.910
easy function that can go the opposite
direction using those little tools,

115
00:07:12.910 --> 00:07:14.430
using the kb and the mb.

116
00:07:14.430 --> 00:07:16.910
Cuz a lot of times when I'm reading
information from something,

117
00:07:16.910 --> 00:07:19.100
I'm getting it back as this.

118
00:07:19.100 --> 00:07:23.270
But in my report or whatever I'm
trying to do, this doesn't help me.

119
00:07:23.270 --> 00:07:26.770
When I see how much free disk
space is on a particular server,

120
00:07:26.770 --> 00:07:30.790
a shared volume, I'd like to see
that in megabytes or in gigabytes.

121
00:07:30.790 --> 00:07:33.670
Make it a little bit easier to recognize.

122
00:07:33.670 --> 00:07:37.000
So you can write a little
function that'll divide it by and

123
00:07:37.000 --> 00:07:38.220
just use that kb divided by [INAUDIBLE].

124
00:07:40.340 --> 00:07:41.010
Pretty cool there.

125
00:07:41.010 --> 00:07:43.780
But basically the equals that's it right?

126
00:07:43.780 --> 00:07:47.316
Whatever the value is on
the right we're going to

127
00:07:47.316 --> 00:07:51.987
assign that to the variable on
the left of that equals operator.

128
00:07:51.987 --> 00:07:55.940
Now when we get down to the plus equals
you really have to think of this.

129
00:07:55.940 --> 00:07:57.199
And it's pretty straight forward.

130
00:07:57.199 --> 00:08:00.167
It's plus equals.

131
00:08:00.167 --> 00:08:02.053
They're both operands on their own.

132
00:08:02.053 --> 00:08:04.061
The = we've seen just now,

133
00:08:04.061 --> 00:08:09.092
the + we saw in our arithmetic
operators episode, it was an addition.

134
00:08:09.092 --> 00:08:11.876
So we're taking two operands and
putting them together.

135
00:08:11.876 --> 00:08:16.815
And that's exactly what it's going to do,
it is going to add and

136
00:08:16.815 --> 00:08:18.471
then assign a value.

137
00:08:18.471 --> 00:08:21.952
So, in this case, a += 5.

138
00:08:21.952 --> 00:08:25.275
Let's clear my screen down here,
and what is a currently?

139
00:08:25.275 --> 00:08:28.947
Oops, get a little focus
in the right location.

140
00:08:28.947 --> 00:08:33.316
$a is 10 right now, so

141
00:08:33.316 --> 00:08:37.068
if we run $a += 5.

142
00:08:37.068 --> 00:08:39.661
Cherokee, I'll give you
a chance to review yourself,

143
00:08:39.661 --> 00:08:41.601
what do you think that $a is gonna be now?

144
00:08:41.601 --> 00:08:44.563
>> Okay, so, the $a is going to be 11?

145
00:08:44.563 --> 00:08:45.623
>> It was 10.

146
00:08:45.623 --> 00:08:46.323
>> Right.

147
00:08:46.323 --> 00:08:47.764
>> And now we're adding 5.

148
00:08:47.764 --> 00:08:52.729
>> Plus the five, okay, I thought I was
gonna be adding 1 and then the 5, so, 15.

149
00:08:52.729 --> 00:08:56.332
We'll see, [LAUGH].

150
00:08:56.332 --> 00:08:59.583
>> 15, you are correct, you get the prize.

151
00:08:59.583 --> 00:09:02.501
>> Okay.
>> So it is doing really two operations,

152
00:09:02.501 --> 00:09:07.430
and I wrote this one out here, because
this is the exact same thing, right?

153
00:09:07.430 --> 00:09:10.589
If we take and
do what's inside our parentheses first.

154
00:09:10.589 --> 00:09:15.024
Take the current value of a,
which was 10, add 5,

155
00:09:15.024 --> 00:09:18.879
which means this whole
thing now equals 15.

156
00:09:18.879 --> 00:09:21.570
$a = 15, sure enough,

157
00:09:21.570 --> 00:09:27.549
that's what happened when we did the += 5,
a now = 15.

158
00:09:27.549 --> 00:09:30.024
So this is really what it's
doing in the background,

159
00:09:30.024 --> 00:09:31.952
is it's doing two separate operations.

160
00:09:31.952 --> 00:09:37.043
It's first doing the addition,
right, then it's doing, oops,

161
00:09:37.043 --> 00:09:41.608
and I just reversed that,
then it's doing the assignment.

162
00:09:41.608 --> 00:09:43.416
So, two separate operations going on.

163
00:09:43.416 --> 00:09:47.907
>> But unlike what we saw with our
arithmetic operators, it saves that value,

164
00:09:47.907 --> 00:09:49.673
because you use that = sign.

165
00:09:49.673 --> 00:09:51.792
So it's not something like a one and done.

166
00:09:51.792 --> 00:09:52.687
>> Exactly right.

167
00:09:52.687 --> 00:09:57.577
So we are definitely saving that result,
and this is a very common thing

168
00:09:57.577 --> 00:10:01.587
to need to add to an existing
variable a particular value.

169
00:10:01.587 --> 00:10:06.110
And so I've read this, like I said,
it works just fine, but

170
00:10:06.110 --> 00:10:07.988
it's a lot more typing.

171
00:10:07.988 --> 00:10:15.412
This is a lot less typing, and it's pretty
easy to read, += 5, it kinda makes sense.

172
00:10:15.412 --> 00:10:18.704
Whereas this one, I'm gonna say,
okay, first, it's gonna do this, and

173
00:10:18.704 --> 00:10:20.974
in a complex expression,
these are pretty simple.

174
00:10:20.974 --> 00:10:25.034
In a complex expression, that can make
a big difference, make it really easy for

175
00:10:25.034 --> 00:10:27.737
someone else to read and
figure out what's going on.

176
00:10:27.737 --> 00:10:33.324
All right, well, that's fine with
integers, what about with string?

177
00:10:33.324 --> 00:10:39.217
Let's see what b equals currently, so
we don't get any unexpected results,

178
00:10:39.217 --> 00:10:42.264
so b currently equals the string power.

179
00:10:42.264 --> 00:10:48.841
And I'm gonna do $b +=,
the string, Shell, all right?

180
00:10:48.841 --> 00:10:51.449
So any guesses on this one?

181
00:10:51.449 --> 00:10:52.382
>> PowerShell, [LAUGH].

182
00:10:52.382 --> 00:10:53.581
>> I'm gonna say PowerShell.

183
00:10:53.581 --> 00:10:57.937
I like your guess, and let's think about
that thought process, first, let's verify.

184
00:10:57.937 --> 00:11:03.653
We'll run it, and we'll call back $b,
and sure enough, we get PowerShell.

185
00:11:03.653 --> 00:11:06.476
All right, again,
two separate operations going on.

186
00:11:06.476 --> 00:11:11.830
First, the + operator is being
executed on and then the = operator,

187
00:11:11.830 --> 00:11:15.666
with strings,
the + is concatenation, right?

188
00:11:15.666 --> 00:11:20.278
So it's gonna take that existing value,
and concatenate it with Shell.

189
00:11:20.278 --> 00:11:22.519
Then the = operator says, now,

190
00:11:22.519 --> 00:11:26.855
take that new value that you've created,
and assign it to $v.

191
00:11:26.855 --> 00:11:34.408
So $v now includes the concatenated
result of our operation.

192
00:11:34.408 --> 00:11:40.929
Here, let's see what $c equals,
$c is an array.

193
00:11:40.929 --> 00:11:45.357
I've got the value of 10, 17, and 20, so

194
00:11:45.357 --> 00:11:50.443
a three element array, and
I'm going to do a += 25.

195
00:11:50.443 --> 00:11:53.766
We execute that, and we call that $c,

it says I'm gonna turn a,

427
00:25:20.600 --> 00:25:27.740
I'm gonna go ahead and increment a,
then I'm going to assign a decrying.

428
00:25:27.740 --> 00:25:31.450
So do your incrementation
of this variable.

429
00:25:31.450 --> 00:25:33.990
So now this whole process is done.

430
00:25:33.990 --> 00:25:38.580
It equals 11,
pre-inc equals 11, right here.

431
00:25:39.850 --> 00:25:46.010
Hosting says use the variable and
then increment, right?

432
00:25:46.010 --> 00:25:51.060
So here hosting, I'm assigning dollar
sign, the current value of dollar

433
00:25:51.060 --> 00:25:56.060
sign to posting then I increment, right?

434
00:25:56.060 --> 00:26:02.500
So after posting is set,
I'm actually turning $a from 10 to 11.

435
00:26:02.500 --> 00:26:07.588
And that's why posting equals 10,
even though we did in fact

436
00:26:07.588 --> 00:26:12.303
increment a, if I look at $a,
it does indeed equal 11.

437
00:26:12.303 --> 00:26:16.720
The posting saw a before
the increment happened.

438
00:26:16.720 --> 00:26:17.300
Does that make sense?

439
00:26:17.300 --> 00:26:21.140
>> No.
>> Right, so read it from left to right.

440
00:26:21.140 --> 00:26:23.270
>> Okay.
>> Do your incrementation and

441
00:26:23.270 --> 00:26:26.590
then use your variable to assign it.

442
00:26:26.590 --> 00:26:29.110
>> Okay.
>> So it was 10 before we started.

443
00:26:29.110 --> 00:26:29.610
>> Correct.

444
00:26:29.610 --> 00:26:35.740
>> And then going left to right,
10 becomes 11, so $a now equals 11.

445
00:26:35.740 --> 00:26:38.210
Pre-inc now equals a, which is 11.

446
00:26:38.210 --> 00:26:39.570
>> 11.

447
00:26:39.570 --> 00:26:44.082
>> This one going in a equals 10,
the $a comes first, so

448
00:26:44.082 --> 00:26:49.090
before you increment it,
set $ equal to post-inc.

449
00:26:49.090 --> 00:26:52.724
When we went in $a equals 10,
so post inc equals 10,

450
00:26:52.724 --> 00:26:57.750
then do your incrementation after you've
already set the value for posting.

451
00:26:58.780 --> 00:27:02.120
So posting this variable never saw the 11.

452
00:27:02.120 --> 00:27:06.490
You're doing the 11 after
you use the variable.

453
00:27:06.490 --> 00:27:09.460
And that's really way you'll read
it in most books and tutorials and

454
00:27:09.460 --> 00:27:12.350
things like that is pre,

455
00:27:12.350 --> 00:27:18.270
the plus plus variable says increment
the variable before you use the variable.

456
00:27:18.270 --> 00:27:24.640
The $a++ says, use the variable and
then increment it.

457
00:27:24.640 --> 00:27:29.608
And again this can make a big difference
when we're working with our loops and

458
00:27:29.608 --> 00:27:31.990
using these variables as counters.

459
00:27:31.990 --> 00:27:35.981
Whether or not I equals
the old value pre-increment or

460
00:27:35.981 --> 00:27:39.626
whether I equals the new
value post-increment,

461
00:27:39.626 --> 00:27:44.780
as I go through that loop, for
example, can make a big difference.

462
00:27:44.780 --> 00:27:47.678
>> And I can definitely see why people
choose to write it out the other way.

463
00:27:47.678 --> 00:27:48.795
>> Yeah, absolutely.

464
00:27:48.795 --> 00:27:51.270
>> [LAUGH]
>> If you talk to a lot off people,

465
00:27:51.270 --> 00:27:55.950
they'll say, that's really good shorthand
and it does make it kinda nice and

466
00:27:55.950 --> 00:27:57.200
neat and tidy.

467
00:27:57.200 --> 00:28:02.731
But when you go back to look
at it 6 months later and

468
00:28:02.731 --> 00:28:06.946
you got this really complex formula,

469
00:28:06.946 --> 00:28:10.781
(++i / 4) * x++ / ++z.

470
00:28:10.781 --> 00:28:15.051
>> It might take you longer to logically
work it all out to understand it then.

471
00:28:15.051 --> 00:28:20.560
>> Yeah, absolutely, so
it might not be for everybody.

472
00:28:20.560 --> 00:28:24.385
But if I'm just doing a simple
counter within a function, it's very,

473
00:28:24.385 --> 00:28:25.970
very convenient.

474
00:28:25.970 --> 00:28:28.370
It's nice and short and
sweet and to the point.

475
00:28:28.370 --> 00:28:30.300
So I wanted to make sure
I pointed that out.

476
00:28:30.300 --> 00:28:31.890
I know we're running out of time,
Cherokee.

477
00:28:31.890 --> 00:28:34.350
Just got a couple more to do here.

478
00:28:34.350 --> 00:28:38.669
With the arrays, plus plus you
can't use that on an array but

479
00:28:38.669 --> 00:28:42.493
I can use it on an individual
element within an array.

480
00:28:42.493 --> 00:28:46.630
All right, so I can say $c,
remember $c was an array.

481
00:28:48.330 --> 00:28:53.254
Right, 30, 15, 20, 25, and
if I take that first element,

482
00:28:53.254 --> 00:28:58.024
or I'm sorry, index one so
second element and I do a plus plus to it.

483
00:29:00.687 --> 00:29:02.563
And then we call back $c.

484
00:29:02.563 --> 00:29:06.573
So the second element has
been increased by one, and

485
00:29:06.573 --> 00:29:11.222
then I won't take a lot of time
to spend with the minus minus,

486
00:29:11.222 --> 00:29:14.706
this is just decrement, just the opposite.

487
00:29:14.706 --> 00:29:19.507
We're gonna decrement the value by one,
so if the string was initial, or

488
00:29:19.507 --> 00:29:23.997
I'm sorry, the integer was initially
10 and I do a decrement, and

489
00:29:23.997 --> 00:29:27.580
then I call that variable back,
I'll see it is now 9.

490
00:29:27.580 --> 00:29:33.110
Doesn't matter if I'm doing this,
which way I go, right?

491
00:29:33.110 --> 00:29:37.450
If I do it before or after,
a is still gonna equal 9.

492
00:29:37.450 --> 00:29:39.670
It's gonna decrement it by 1,

493
00:29:39.670 --> 00:29:44.700
but if I'm using it in an expression
like this, it's the same thing.

494
00:29:44.700 --> 00:29:48.462
Decrement at first, then use the variable,

495
00:29:48.462 --> 00:29:52.323
or use the variable first and
then decrement.

496
00:29:52.323 --> 00:29:56.860
Right, you use the original value or the
new value, that's really the thing there.

497
00:29:56.860 --> 00:30:02.070
And so it's the same thing, if you
do the $a --, let's say go ahead and

498
00:30:02.070 --> 00:30:07.578
use the variable, in this case assign it
to post inc then decrement the value.

499
00:30:07.578 --> 00:30:11.938
So post inc would include the old value
of a, not the current value of a.

500
00:30:11.938 --> 00:30:15.480
Whereas pre inc says do
your decrementation first,

501
00:30:15.480 --> 00:30:19.220
that's an actual word,
and then use the variable.

502
00:30:19.220 --> 00:30:23.353
So pre inc would be the current
version of a, $a and

503
00:30:23.353 --> 00:30:27.420
pre inc should equal
each other in this case.

504
00:30:27.420 --> 00:30:31.030
Same thing with an array,
I can take individual element and

505
00:30:31.030 --> 00:30:34.780
I can decrement it by one so
we'll do the same position there.

506
00:30:34.780 --> 00:30:39.845
And if we now look at c$, ops that is not,

507
00:30:39.845 --> 00:30:45.240
$c is what I meant,
16 has now been dropped back down to 15.

508
00:30:45.240 --> 00:30:46.350
>> That's my nickname.

509
00:30:46.350 --> 00:30:48.680
>> What's that?
>> That's my nickname.

510
00:30:48.680 --> 00:30:49.460
>> $c?

511
00:30:49.460 --> 00:30:50.265
>> C$.

512
00:30:50.265 --> 00:30:51.403
[LAUGH]
>> C$, nice.

513
00:30:51.403 --> 00:30:53.344
[LAUGH] So there is a good,

514
00:30:53.344 --> 00:30:58.809
hopefully a good look at assignment
operators and how we can use them.

515
00:30:58.809 --> 00:31:03.726
Our plus equals, minus equals, multiply
divide equals, modular equals, and

516
00:31:03.726 --> 00:31:07.920
we also looked at our plus plus and
our minus minus, our increment and

517
00:31:07.920 --> 00:31:11.940
our decrement that we can
use with our variables.

518
00:31:11.940 --> 00:31:14.115
>> Okay, Mike, well, thank you for
taking the time to explain that.

519
00:31:14.115 --> 00:31:17.731
Do you have any thoughts before we
continue or are we just going to go ahead

520
00:31:17.731 --> 00:31:22.010
and end it here, and then start a new
show to look at some more operators?

521
00:31:22.010 --> 00:31:23.080
What do you think?

522
00:31:23.080 --> 00:31:25.258
>> You know what, I'm sorry,
I was reading the chatroom.

523
00:31:25.258 --> 00:31:26.880
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] I did not

524
00:31:26.880 --> 00:31:28.120
even hear what you asked me.

525
00:31:28.120 --> 00:31:31.870
>> So ladies and gentlemen, we are going
to go ahead and create a new show for you,

526
00:31:31.870 --> 00:31:33.770
so just stay tuned,
you don't wanna miss it.

527
00:31:33.770 --> 00:31:35.315
For this one, we'll sign out.

528
00:31:35.315 --> 00:31:37.120
I've been your host Cherokee Boose.

529
00:31:37.120 --> 00:31:37.850
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

episodes.description: In this episode, we cover comparison operators. You will learn what comparison operators are in PowerShell and how they are used to compare values, as well as find values that match a specified pattern.
episodes.title: Comparison Operators

00:00:55.250 --> 00:00:57.790
So, yes, I'm sorry,
we're doing a comparison operators, so

let's take a look at my screen.

It started out like we did

And just got a little cheat sheet here

00:01:03.510 --> 00:01:06.480
the show notes so
you can remember what operators,

00:01:06.480 --> 00:01:10.920
in this case, what comparison
operators PowerShell supports.

35
00:01:10.920 --> 00:01:15.702
Now difference from some other scripting

36

that you might be familiar with, a lot of

37
00:01:20.638 --> 00:01:24.933
Where equals is an assignment

we're assigning the value on the one

00:01:29.517 --> 00:01:31.822

00:01:31.822 --> 00:01:36.600
But in a lot of languages will do

00:01:36.600 --> 00:01:42.785
So $A==4 is not assigning but
it's saying is $A=4 and

we get a bouillon response true or false.

00:01:47.565 --> 00:01:48.815
PowerShell does not do it that way.

00:01:48.815 --> 00:01:54.220
PowerShell went with a,

we've got some letters that

00:01:59.280 --> 00:02:02.270
I remember reading something
about the theory was that they

think this is a little
less confusing maybe.

00:02:04.840 --> 00:02:08.820
Because a lot of people do mistake
the equals, the assignment, and

00:02:08.820 --> 00:02:12.940
the comparison operators, equals
an equals equals, when do I use which?

50
00:02:12.940 --> 00:02:14.354
This is pretty clear, right.

51
00:02:14.354 --> 00:02:17.134
Equals is an assignment operator.

52
00:02:17.134 --> 00:02:19.520
-EQ is my comparison operator.

53
00:02:19.520 --> 00:02:24.086
So there is no confusing the two
as we're looking at our code.

54
00:02:24.086 --> 00:02:27.583
So, and they're pretty straight
forward because we're using letters,

55
00:02:27.583 --> 00:02:29.810
they're almost like abbreviations, right.

56
00:02:29.810 --> 00:02:32.252
-EQ is equals to.

57
00:02:32.252 --> 00:02:33.950
Does A = B?

58
00:02:33.950 --> 00:02:36.702
Are they the same, same values?

59
00:02:36.702 --> 00:02:43.710
-NE for not equals,
-GT greater than, right.

60
00:02:43.710 --> 00:02:45.165
Is one bigger than the other?

61
00:02:45.165 --> 00:02:50.715
-greater than or equal to, is it larger or
at least equal to the test value?

62
00:02:50.715 --> 00:02:55.705
-LT for less than, -LE for

63
00:02:55.705 --> 00:03:00.240
And those are pretty standard, I think
we're probably familiar with those.

64
00:03:00.240 --> 00:03:02.858
When we get down here into the likes,

65
00:03:02.858 --> 00:03:06.750
likes allow me to match using
the wild card character.

66
00:03:08.020 --> 00:03:09.450
Very very important.

67
00:03:09.450 --> 00:03:13.756
We'll use this quite often when

00:03:13.756 --> 00:03:16.590
And we want to find a process that has a,

we have a certain few characters that

70
00:03:20.730 --> 00:03:23.060
We can use the first few characters and

71
00:03:23.060 --> 00:03:25.000
That wild card name like.

72
00:03:26.260 --> 00:03:28.450
We wanna find all the computers
that start with SV, right.

73
00:03:28.450 --> 00:03:32.900
We do a dash like SV*.

74
00:03:32.900 --> 00:03:37.198
So it'll be SV and
then anything after that.

75
00:03:37.198 --> 00:03:41.330
[COUGH] Or the opposite, not like.

76
00:03:41.330 --> 00:03:44.120
We can use again our wild
card character there.

77
00:03:44.120 --> 00:03:45.160
Then we get into match.

78
00:03:45.160 --> 00:03:47.590
Match is similar to like.

79
00:03:47.590 --> 00:03:50.350
Like, though, is a little limited
as far as the wild cards go.

80
00:03:50.350 --> 00:03:51.440
We have the asterisk.

81
00:03:51.440 --> 00:03:55.700
Believe we can use, the asterisk
represents any number of characters,

82
00:03:55.700 --> 00:03:59.880
a question mark for
a single character replacement.

83
00:03:59.880 --> 00:04:03.842
We get down into match and now all of
a sudden we're using regular expressions.

84
00:04:03.842 --> 00:04:08.150
>> Just maybe in my mind I'm thinking is
it a little more specific instead of like

85
00:04:08.150 --> 00:04:12.050
asterisk dot file extension type
where as matches would have to, well,

86
00:04:12.050 --> 00:04:13.270
match the file type?

87
00:04:13.270 --> 00:04:15.060
>> It's not so
much that it's more specific,

88
00:04:15.060 --> 00:04:19.670
it's more that it's,
what's a good way to put it?

89
00:04:19.670 --> 00:04:21.597
It gives me much more control.

90
00:04:21.597 --> 00:04:24.522
We can really build,
I mean regular expressions,

91
00:04:24.522 --> 00:04:27.729
you can take classes on
building regular expressions.

92
00:04:27.729 --> 00:04:32.671
So there's much more then being able to
say, this letter and then I don't know so

93
00:04:32.671 --> 00:04:34.425
many number of characters.

94
00:04:34.425 --> 00:04:40.325
We can really get specific and look for
spaces between the letters B and

95
00:04:40.325 --> 00:04:45.990
C, or a capital C followed by
a lowercase a followed by a period.

96
00:04:45.990 --> 00:04:49.600
I mean you can get very,
very specific using regular expressions.

97
00:04:49.600 --> 00:04:54.250
So they're much more powerful
as far as a matching goes,

98
00:04:54.250 --> 00:04:56.850
then just the likes or not likes.

99
00:04:56.850 --> 00:04:59.620
But it also means you need to
learn regular expressions.

100
00:04:59.620 --> 00:05:02.890
And we're not gonna teach regular
expressions in this series or

101
00:05:02.890 --> 00:05:04.120
anything like that.

102
00:05:04.120 --> 00:05:07.500
So if you're going, no,
not regular expressions, don't worry.

103
00:05:07.500 --> 00:05:12.660
We might use a couple as we go through
our series in some of our scripts that

104
00:05:12.660 --> 00:05:16.470
we write, but we're not gonna break down
the nitty gritty of regular expressions.

105
00:05:16.470 --> 00:05:20.420
If you need that we've got other classes
in our live courses in our library

106
00:05:20.420 --> 00:05:22.844
that you can check out
that cover that in depth.

107
00:05:22.844 --> 00:05:26.748
I know Daniel has, I think,
done a few shows on regular expressions,

108
00:05:26.748 --> 00:05:31.069
because like I said, there really is
an art to writing regular expressions.

109
00:05:31.069 --> 00:05:35.434
But when you're looking for log entries
that a have a certain key word,

110
00:05:35.434 --> 00:05:40.309
plus a certain time range, plus a certain
node address, something like that,

111
00:05:40.309 --> 00:05:44.080
that's where I can't do that

112
00:05:44.080 --> 00:05:49.270
But I can do that with regular
expressions, so very, very powerful.

113
00:05:49.270 --> 00:05:53.950
And here I just wanna explain that
the match, which works like the like,

114
00:05:53.950 --> 00:05:57.525
which works similar to the likes,
so I don't be redundant there.

115
00:05:57.525 --> 00:06:00.685
It's just more powerful cuz now
I can use regular expressions

116
00:06:00.685 --> 00:06:03.225
in my clause that I have with my match.

117
00:06:03.225 --> 00:06:04.065
Same thing with not match.

118
00:06:04.065 --> 00:06:06.735
Hey, does this match with
this character pattern?

119
00:06:06.735 --> 00:06:10.345
Or does this not match this
particular character pattern?

120
00:06:10.345 --> 00:06:15.022
Then we've get contains,
not contains, in and not in.

121
00:06:15.022 --> 00:06:17.699
And these are another one that
that's kind of very similar.

122
00:06:17.699 --> 00:06:18.899
When we look at contains,
