00:18:44.820 --> 00:18:47.750
Strings go in quotes, and
it's always been a double quote.

356
00:18:47.750 --> 00:18:49.770
And I've really been trying
to do the right thing and

357
00:18:49.770 --> 00:18:51.700
use a single quote around my strings.

358
00:18:51.700 --> 00:18:54.460
Unless I need the double quote
functionality for some reason.

359
00:18:54.460 --> 00:18:57.010
I'm about ready to switch back though.

360
00:18:57.010 --> 00:19:02.730
Because I can't find any kind of
reason to not use the double quotes.

361
00:19:02.730 --> 00:19:05.820
I understand that they say, you know.

362
00:19:05.820 --> 00:19:07.830
It works fine, with double quotes.

363
00:19:07.830 --> 00:19:09.300
And if I've got a variable name and

364
00:19:09.300 --> 00:19:13.280
I'm putting it in a string,
most likely I want that to resolve.

365
00:19:13.280 --> 00:19:15.670
There's not very many times when I don't.

366
00:19:15.670 --> 00:19:19.720
And I can escape it with that back take
if I really don't want the dollar sign,

367
00:19:19.720 --> 00:19:21.096
to have a special meaning.

368
00:19:21.096 --> 00:19:23.830
So I apologize [LAUGH]

369
00:19:23.830 --> 00:19:25.730
you'll see me flip back and forth-
>> And

370
00:19:25.730 --> 00:19:30.710
if we're having confession hour here so
I've always used the double quotes also.

371
00:19:30.710 --> 00:19:31.670
>> Have you?
>> Yeah.

372
00:19:31.670 --> 00:19:34.804
>> Yeah it's just-
>> [LAUGH] I'm glad that I got that off

373
00:19:34.804 --> 00:19:35.367
my chest.

374
00:19:35.367 --> 00:19:35.932
>> You feel better?

375
00:19:35.932 --> 00:19:37.490
>> Yeah.
[LAUGH]

376
00:19:37.490 --> 00:19:39.227
>> To me it's easier not because it's so

377
00:19:39.227 --> 00:19:41.940
much easier to type because I do
have to do the shift right and

378
00:19:41.940 --> 00:19:44.510
pinky thing to get the double quote,
it's just habit.

379
00:19:44.510 --> 00:19:50.187
It's just the way I've always done it,
and until they can show me a problem that

380
00:19:50.187 --> 00:19:55.970
it causes, I think I'm gonna switch back
to using double quotes on everything.

381
00:19:57.035 --> 00:19:59.460
BecauseI can't find any
reason not to do it.

382
00:20:00.510 --> 00:20:04.780
They just say not to and I'm like a little
kid telling my parent, well, why not?

383
00:20:04.780 --> 00:20:05.290
Right?

384
00:20:05.290 --> 00:20:07.260
>> Right.
>> And if you don't give me a good reason,

385
00:20:07.260 --> 00:20:08.637
then I don't understand.

386
00:20:08.637 --> 00:20:10.280
>> [LAUGH]
>> Anyway, sorry.

387
00:20:10.280 --> 00:20:12.630
Back to the topic at hand.

388
00:20:12.630 --> 00:20:16.380
So Windows PowerShell -like "*shell".

389
00:20:16.380 --> 00:20:23.000
If we execute that, I get true, right,
because this is saying any character,

390
00:20:23.000 --> 00:20:28.500
and it's probably easier to highlight
up here, anything, then the word shell.

391
00:20:28.500 --> 00:20:31.680
Well, here's the word shell.

392
00:20:31.680 --> 00:20:37.615
And it doesn't matter, what's in front
of it, I mean it could be [SOUND] right?

393
00:20:37.615 --> 00:20:42.577
This should still evaluate to true because
the asterisk represents any number

394
00:20:42.577 --> 00:20:44.690
of characters in front of shell.

395
00:20:44.690 --> 00:20:46.650
>> Okay.
>> All right and

396
00:20:46.650 --> 00:20:49.580
let me see if I can undo that easily,
there we go good right?

397
00:20:49.580 --> 00:20:51.599
What if I switch this around though,
what if I did this?

398
00:20:52.780 --> 00:20:55.765
Put the asterisk after it,
do you think it'll match anymore?

399
00:20:55.765 --> 00:21:02.810
>> If asterisk after, yeah, because you
don't have anything after your shell.

400
00:21:02.810 --> 00:21:03.790
It really shouldn't matter.

401
00:21:03.790 --> 00:21:05.420
>> It shouldn't matter, right?

402
00:21:05.420 --> 00:21:06.480
>> That's what I would think.

403
00:21:06.480 --> 00:21:08.250
>> Yeah, unfortunately Cherokee,
I'm sorry.

404
00:21:08.250 --> 00:21:09.685
We're gonna have to ding you on that one.

405
00:21:09.685 --> 00:21:11.200
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's gonna be false.

406
00:21:11.200 --> 00:21:15.590
>> Because while you are correct
in the way you read this syntax,

407
00:21:15.590 --> 00:21:18.490
what you forgot was I removed
the asterisk from the front.

408
00:21:18.490 --> 00:21:21.720
So this is saying nothing can
be in front of shell right?

409
00:21:21.720 --> 00:21:22.690
>> It makes sense.

410
00:21:22.690 --> 00:21:25.510
>> So now if I did this right?

411
00:21:25.510 --> 00:21:26.540
>> You'd be good to go.

412
00:21:26.540 --> 00:21:29.560
>> Now we'd be good to go because
even though this could be

413
00:21:29.560 --> 00:21:30.360
>> Zero or

414
00:21:30.360 --> 00:21:32.340
more characters behind the word shell.

415
00:21:32.340 --> 00:21:36.620
So Cherokee is absolutely right, the
asterisk after it really doesn't make any

416
00:21:36.620 --> 00:21:40.390
difference because nothing is
still a match to that wild card.

417
00:21:40.390 --> 00:21:43.550
But by not having this one here,
when I move the asterisk,

418
00:21:43.550 --> 00:21:47.440
now you're saying nothing can come
in front of that S, so it's false.

419
00:21:47.440 --> 00:21:48.870
If I put this asterisk back.

420
00:21:49.920 --> 00:21:51.390
And we execute that.

421
00:21:51.390 --> 00:21:53.590
Now we're true because we're good to go.

422
00:21:53.590 --> 00:21:57.015
So play around with that
little wildcard there.

423
00:21:57.015 --> 00:21:59.520
I did another example here
where I've got multiple values.

424
00:21:59.520 --> 00:22:05.510
I got "Windows PowerShell", "ITProTV",
"Bash Shell" -like "*shell".

425
00:22:05.510 --> 00:22:06.940
Is it gonna match?

426
00:22:06.940 --> 00:22:07.690
What's it gonna match?

427
00:22:07.690 --> 00:22:08.694
Oops, I ran that twice.

428
00:22:13.539 --> 00:22:15.760
I had the other line selected still.

429
00:22:15.760 --> 00:22:17.070
So let's run this one and see.

430
00:22:17.070 --> 00:22:19.460
Now again, anything shell.

431
00:22:20.530 --> 00:22:26.130
So if we look, most likely this
one because anything shell.

432
00:22:26.130 --> 00:22:27.270
This one maybe not.

433
00:22:28.310 --> 00:22:31.906
This one I gotta space,
does that count as anything?

434
00:22:31.906 --> 00:22:34.850
Let's see what we got here.

435
00:22:34.850 --> 00:22:40.240
And sure enough,
I get both of those values back.

436
00:22:40.240 --> 00:22:46.860
So we can send in multiple values, and
look for that particular string pattern or

437
00:22:46.860 --> 00:22:50.880
character pattern I should say and then
not like would be just the opposite right?

438
00:22:50.880 --> 00:22:54.580
We're saying I don't want
anything that has anything and

439
00:22:54.580 --> 00:22:58.532
then followed by the word shell or
the characters S-H-E-L-L.

440
00:22:58.532 --> 00:22:59.572
So we hit that.

441
00:22:59.572 --> 00:23:04.280
That's gonna be false because it
definitely does have S-H-E-L-L as

442
00:23:04.280 --> 00:23:06.990
a pattern of characters there.

443
00:23:06.990 --> 00:23:11.990
Same thing here, if we have multiple
values going in, it will test each

444
00:23:11.990 --> 00:23:16.686
one of those values, but it is gonna
return the ones that are not like shell.

445
00:23:16.686 --> 00:23:22.140
And so, ITPRO.TV comes back,
not Windows PowerShell and not barshell.

446
00:23:24.610 --> 00:23:26.060
Then we've got match.

447
00:23:26.060 --> 00:23:27.000
And the match is the one,

448
00:23:27.000 --> 00:23:31.520
I didn't actually do very complex
regular expressions, not all that good.

449
00:23:31.520 --> 00:23:34.900
Regular expressions,
I guess they can be challenging.

450
00:23:34.900 --> 00:23:37.060
And I wanted to keep this
relatively simple and

451
00:23:37.060 --> 00:23:40.050
didn't wanna spend a whole lot of time
writing out some crazy expressions.

452
00:23:40.050 --> 00:23:44.460
So I did just a simple match but
it shows what we can do with it.

453
00:23:44.460 --> 00:23:47.240
So here I've got several values, and

454
00:23:47.240 --> 00:23:52.100
I'm gonna do a /match, and
then look for "sun", all right?

455
00:23:52.100 --> 00:23:53.880
And we'll execute that,

456
00:23:53.880 --> 00:23:57.160
I think Tim would be disappointed
in your choice of weekdays there.

457
00:23:57.160 --> 00:23:58.530
>> What's that?

458
00:23:58.530 --> 00:24:01.710
I know I did leave out my Mike,
Mike, Mike, what day is it?

459
00:24:01.710 --> 00:24:04.052
Favorite day there.

460
00:24:04.052 --> 00:24:07.761
>> And that's Wednesday if you
guys don't know, Wednesday.

461
00:24:07.761 --> 00:24:11.896
Every Wednesday he tells
us what day it is, no joke.

462
00:24:11.896 --> 00:24:17.402
All right, I do, I have to do that
at stand up every Wednesday morning.

463
00:24:17.402 --> 00:24:20.911
So match sun, sure enough, I get Sunday.

464
00:24:20.911 --> 00:24:24.858
Not Monday, not Tuesday,
because they don't have sun in them.

465
00:24:24.858 --> 00:24:27.944
But notice I didn't have
to use a wild card.

466
00:24:27.944 --> 00:24:30.724
But with this regular,
this is a type of regular expression,

467
00:24:30.724 --> 00:24:33.562
it's just a very simple one,
it's just characters, [LAUGH].

468
00:24:33.562 --> 00:24:35.450
But it is looking for that pattern.

469
00:24:35.450 --> 00:24:38.077
>> Well, yeah, they're all contiguous and
they're all together right there.

470
00:24:38.077 --> 00:24:41.410
>> I found that pattern and
the word Sunday, all right?

471
00:24:41.410 --> 00:24:44.705
But here is what's
interesting about match.

472
00:24:44.705 --> 00:24:48.899
With multiple values that I'm testing,
I get,

473
00:24:48.899 --> 00:24:53.160
it returns the value that did match,
right?

474
00:24:53.160 --> 00:24:57.431
And let's see when I had a single value,
right?

475
00:24:57.431 --> 00:25:01.070
Notice I get true instead of the match,
okay?

476
00:25:01.070 --> 00:25:03.990
So something to keep in mind,
if you pass a single

477
00:25:03.990 --> 00:25:05.688
value as a test value-
>> Yeah,

478
00:25:05.688 --> 00:25:07.650
that could be a little deceiving almost.

479
00:25:07.650 --> 00:25:11.736
>> Yeah, you've got to pay attention and
know what you should expect for results.

480
00:25:11.736 --> 00:25:15.443
If I've got a single value in front
of my expression, dash match,

481
00:25:15.443 --> 00:25:19.280
then I'm going to get a Boolean
as a result, true or false?

482
00:25:19.280 --> 00:25:21.786
Either this is in there,
or it's not in there.

483
00:25:21.786 --> 00:25:25.847
If I have multiple values to test,
it can't just say true or false,

484
00:25:25.847 --> 00:25:29.550
because which one was true,
which one was false?

485
00:25:29.550 --> 00:25:32.771
So it actually returns anything
that matched, in this case, Sunday.

486
00:25:32.771 --> 00:25:39.200
If I change this to day, and we execute
that, I'll see all three come back.

487
00:25:39.200 --> 00:25:45.565
Because all three have the characters
D-A-Y in them somewhere, okay?

488
00:25:45.565 --> 00:25:50.180
The matches variable, this is something
that I've actually struggled with

489
00:25:50.180 --> 00:25:52.246
getting to finding a good use for.

490
00:25:52.246 --> 00:25:55.190
Let me see if I have anything in there,
could we reset that?

491
00:25:58.740 --> 00:26:04.569
With the, I'm gonna say, matches =

492
00:26:06.652 --> 00:26:11.049
And then I'm going to execute
this first command again.

493
00:26:11.049 --> 00:26:13.330
So we're going to look for
our match within multiple values.

494
00:26:13.330 --> 00:26:20.532
And then I'm going to check the value of
matches, this variable called matches.

495
00:26:20.532 --> 00:26:23.658
And I'll see it actually equals 0, cuz
that's what I just set it to a minute ago.

496
00:26:23.658 --> 00:26:28.450
Matches is an automatically
created variable when you use

497
00:26:28.450 --> 00:26:30.804
the dash match expression.

498
00:26:30.804 --> 00:26:36.121
It's not populated when I have
multiple values going in, all right?

499
00:26:36.121 --> 00:26:39.708
Because it's gonna list the values
out as a result of the command.

500
00:26:39.708 --> 00:26:44.301
But when I have a single value going in,
we end up with a Boolean response,

501
00:26:44.301 --> 00:26:48.030
true or false, so
when I execute that, I get true.

502
00:26:48.030 --> 00:26:50.804
And if we now look at
the value of matches,

503
00:26:50.804 --> 00:26:53.750
we'll see it actually equals sun, right?

504
00:26:53.750 --> 00:26:58.625
Which is the match that
it found in that value.

505
00:27:01.488 --> 00:27:05.720
Now, again, this is something, I couldn't
think of a really good example for

506
00:27:05.720 --> 00:27:06.300
this one.

507
00:27:06.300 --> 00:27:10.215
Because I'm not sure where
I would end up using this.

508
00:27:10.215 --> 00:27:14.598
It seems like it would be more
helpful if I actually got the value,

509
00:27:14.598 --> 00:27:17.239
not just what matched out of the value.

510
00:27:17.239 --> 00:27:22.040
But I know there's a use for it,
because it's in here, right?

511
00:27:22.040 --> 00:27:25.270
They call that out, they're like,
this is an automatically created variable.

512
00:27:25.270 --> 00:27:28.412
When you use the match
comparison operator,

513
00:27:28.412 --> 00:27:32.225
that will store the value of
what it found in the match.

514
00:27:32.225 --> 00:27:35.892
So you're trying to figure out what
was it that made this successful,

515
00:27:35.892 --> 00:27:37.020
how did it match sun?

516
00:27:37.020 --> 00:27:41.625
Well now I know, it found an uppercase S,
lowercase u, lowercase n,

517
00:27:41.625 --> 00:27:45.000
in my value,
that's why it came back as true.

518
00:27:45.000 --> 00:27:48.677
So if you're trying to figure out why it
came back as true, this will tell you,

519
00:27:48.677 --> 00:27:50.980
this will show you what
matched from that value.

520
00:27:50.980 --> 00:27:55.868
It almost seems like it would be more
helpful when you had multiple values,

521
00:27:55.868 --> 00:28:00.290
but I guess in that case it's
always gonna be the same.

522
00:28:00.290 --> 00:28:03.566
Like I said, I struggled trying
to find a good purpose for

523
00:28:03.566 --> 00:28:06.652
that, but just I wanted you
guys to know what it does.

524
00:28:06.652 --> 00:28:10.104
It's created automatically,
I didn't have to create matches, right,

525
00:28:10.104 --> 00:28:12.300
I never declared it,
although I did reset it.

526
00:28:12.300 --> 00:28:15.918
But the point is,
PowerShell creates it automatically and

527
00:28:15.918 --> 00:28:17.590
it stores the match found.

528
00:28:17.590 --> 00:28:23.649
But only when you're passing a single
value into the matched expression.

529
00:28:23.649 --> 00:28:24.942
>> All right, sorry.

530
00:28:24.942 --> 00:28:25.449
>> That's okay.

531
00:28:25.449 --> 00:28:27.624
>> I'm looking at the clock, Mike,

532
00:28:27.624 --> 00:28:32.165
and I see we have some more comparison
operators on our list here.

533
00:28:32.165 --> 00:28:34.605
I don't know if we should come
back with a part two, though.

534
00:28:34.605 --> 00:28:37.040
>> If we're about out of time,
I've got a few more to do, so, yeah.

535
00:28:37.040 --> 00:28:39.207
>> [LAUGH]
>> You guys know the way I talk, so.

536
00:28:39.207 --> 00:28:39.885
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

537
00:28:39.885 --> 00:28:40.463
>> It's okay,

538
00:28:40.463 --> 00:28:43.200
it means you're passionate about it,
that's all, right?

539
00:28:43.200 --> 00:28:45.201
Okay, then make sure you come back for

540
00:28:45.201 --> 00:28:48.465
this part two here taking a look
at our comparison operators.

541
00:28:48.465 --> 00:28:51.844
But for now, we'll sign out,
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.

542
00:28:51.844 --> 00:28:53.173
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

543
00:28:53.173 --> 00:28:54.274
>> See you next time here at ITPRO.TV.

544
00:28:55.925 --> 00:29:01.849
[MUSIC]

545
00:29:01.849 --> 00:29:04.240
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, we cover comparison operators. You will learn what comparison operators are in PowerShell and how they are used to compare values, as well as find values that match a specified pattern.
episodes.title: Comparison Operators Part 2

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:02.790
Welcome to ITPRO.TV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.790 --> 00:00:06.228
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.228 --> 00:00:08.356
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.356 --> 00:00:12.063
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:12.063 --> 00:00:15.179
>> Welcome back to your PowerShell
Scripting series, I'm your show host,

6
00:00:15.179 --> 00:00:16.290
Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:16.290 --> 00:00:19.710
And I say welcome back, because if you're
not aware, this is actually a part two.

8
00:00:19.710 --> 00:00:23.234
If you want to catch the previous episode
with our other comparison operators,

9
00:00:23.234 --> 00:00:26.170
you need to make sure you look
at the course library there.

10
00:00:26.170 --> 00:00:29.958
But we're gonna pick right back up
where we left off with the wonderful,

11
00:00:29.958 --> 00:00:31.647
the fantastic, Mike Rodrick.

12
00:00:31.647 --> 00:00:34.280
>> I don't know about all that,
but thank you very much, Cherokee.

13
00:00:34.280 --> 00:00:35.570
>> [LAUGH]
>> Glad to be back.

14
00:00:35.570 --> 00:00:39.134
And yeah, I had to come back, cuz we left
off, and we were like, we did match,

15
00:00:39.134 --> 00:00:40.377
we know there is a no match.

16
00:00:40.377 --> 00:00:40.932
Where the heck is it, right?

17
00:00:40.932 --> 00:00:43.556
>> I know, I kind of cut you off right
there, but yeah, we were out of time.

18
00:00:43.556 --> 00:00:44.695
>> That clock, always just tick,
tick, tick, ticks.

19
00:00:44.695 --> 00:00:48.028
>> [LAUGH]
>> So, all right, back to it,

20
00:00:48.028 --> 00:00:50.433
we talked about match,
let's take a look at no match.

21
00:00:50.433 --> 00:00:53.910
Pretty straightforward concept right now,
it's just gonna say, is this not, right?

22
00:00:53.910 --> 00:00:55.782
Is there not a match?

23
00:00:55.782 --> 00:00:58.440
Hence the word notmatch [LAUGH].

24
00:00:58.440 --> 00:01:02.155
All right, so here's Sunday,
Monday, Tuesday, same one,

25
00:01:02.155 --> 00:01:05.109
now we're saying notmatch sun,
and we run that.

26
00:01:05.109 --> 00:01:09.230
And I give Monday and Tuesday,
again, multiple values going in.

27
00:01:09.230 --> 00:01:15.254
It's going to show me all of the values
that evaluated to true in this case.

28
00:01:15.254 --> 00:01:20.220
So, Monday, notmatch sun,
true, do be careful with that.

29
00:01:20.220 --> 00:01:26.069
Sometimes logically we can think, wait
a second, why would you return Monday?

30
00:01:26.069 --> 00:01:30.108
Monday doesn't match sun, so
why is it showing up as true?

31
00:01:30.108 --> 00:01:35.910
We're saying notmatch, so that's
a double negative there, is that right?

32
00:01:35.910 --> 00:01:36.658
I think, in a way.

33
00:01:36.658 --> 00:01:38.651
>> [LAUGH] If you have two negatives,
then it's a double negative.

34
00:01:38.651 --> 00:01:41.207
>> All right, yes, right?

35
00:01:41.207 --> 00:01:44.210
So it's not a double negative,
but it is in my mind.

36
00:01:44.210 --> 00:01:44.886
All right,

then we get adding a single value is

False, no, it's not.

So here are these two commands, this one

I know this is a little beyond

But I think it's a good example,

We'll come back and

But get a list of processes, so

00:06:30.232 --> 00:06:33.112
now I've got this big list of all

00:06:33.112 --> 00:06:37.738
Now type that in and

00:06:37.738 --> 00:06:44.290
Out of that list, only return

00:06:44.290 --> 00:06:47.940
And that would include powershell,
powershell_ise, and notepad.

00:06:49.560 --> 00:06:51.021
Same thing is going on down here,

00:06:51.021 --> 00:06:53.799
go get a list of the processes
that are running on this machine.

112
00:06:53.799 --> 00:06:56.798
Type that list into my where clause,

00:06:56.798 --> 00:07:00.870
but now I'm gonna do dollar
sign names contains.

Again, the collection is now on
the left side of my operator,

00:07:06.264 --> 00:07:11.474
and then the value I'm testing for
is on the right, right?

116
00:07:11.474 --> 00:07:17.230
So we have to, so the syntax becomes a

As you can see, I have to take advantage

00:07:22.127 --> 00:07:25.138
each object as I go through

But in the end, they'll both

Here, if I use the one that

00:07:31.899 --> 00:07:33.849
the one that's using the in clause.

00:07:33.849 --> 00:07:38.870
I can see powershell_ise is running on

Because it's accomplishing

it's just doing it in

And, to me, this is much easier to read,

This one where dollar sign name contains

I said to look for B, and

If I run that, book does not change,

00:09:48.191 --> 00:09:52.704

I'm only replacing capital B.

00:09:54.856 --> 00:09:59.527
If I go and change this to a capital B,

Because it says, there is a capital

00:10:06.952 --> 00:10:13.165
So that's C for case sensitive, I could

00:10:13.165 --> 00:10:17.799
So dash i replace, which means it forces

00:10:17.799 --> 00:10:20.790
PowerShell is case insensitive by default.

So that's being a little redundant, but

So that's just a way to ensure that

>> Like if you lost a file and

Then I've got my is and is not and

00:11:20.630 --> 00:11:26.354
For example, dollar sign a = 1,

00:11:31.910 --> 00:11:35.019

00:11:38.305 --> 00:11:43.624

00:11:50.053 --> 00:11:52.830
I'm ready to go back to

00:11:52.830 --> 00:11:56.000
But now b equals the string one,

00:11:56.000 --> 00:12:00.815

You can also compare variables, like here,

I've got dollar sign a is

So what's gonna happen is

00:12:28.369 --> 00:12:32.661

And so it's gonna say, is dollar sign

00:12:39.883 --> 00:12:40.787
We'll see what happens.

00:12:43.384 --> 00:12:46.179
I just executed this one part

00:12:46.179 --> 00:12:50.830
So b GetType, there,
we're just proving that b is a string,

we already know that a is an int,

00:12:55.313 --> 00:12:59.933
If I want to run the comparison here,

00:12:59.933 --> 00:13:05.543
because a is not the same type as b,

00:13:05.543 --> 00:13:09.509
The a is 1, we'll go ahead and

00:13:09.509 --> 00:13:12.125

00:13:12.125 --> 00:13:16.129
We'll set b equal to the string 1,

00:13:16.129 --> 00:13:20.450
that's true, b is not an integer,

00:13:20.450 --> 00:13:26.460
If I try to compare the two, I should

00:13:26.460 --> 00:13:30.111
I'm saying, is a not the same type as b?

00:13:30.111 --> 00:13:34.020
Indeed they are not,

218
00:13:34.020 --> 00:13:36.413
So just comparisons that we can use for

00:13:39.646 --> 00:13:43.110
Especially as we've seen with

221
00:13:43.110 --> 00:13:47.924
And sometimes doing some things that maybe

00:13:47.924 --> 00:13:49.141

00:13:49.141 --> 00:13:53.533

00:13:53.533 --> 00:13:55.190

00:13:55.190 --> 00:13:56.998

00:13:56.998 --> 00:14:01.424
So maybe I want to check type before I go

00:14:01.424 --> 00:14:02.360

228
00:14:02.360 --> 00:14:05.811
Or giving me a chance to

00:14:05.811 --> 00:14:09.172
And throw up a message, hey, please enter

00:14:09.172 --> 00:14:10.370

00:14:10.370 --> 00:14:14.253
So just some really good expressions,
and that, I think,

00:14:14.253 --> 00:14:17.291

episodes.description: In this episode, we discuss If statements. You will learn how to use If statements to run code blocks based on the results of one or more conditional tests. You will also learn how to specify additional conditional tests and a code block to run if none of the conditions evaluate to true.

>> We've got all sorts of, yeah,
potential silliness here with this one.

19
00:00:38.231 --> 00:00:39.223
>> Absolutely.

20
00:00:39.223 --> 00:00:41.265
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah, and

21
00:00:41.265 --> 00:00:43.380
we're recording this on a Friday,
so that helps too.

22
00:00:43.380 --> 00:00:45.890
All right, so yeah, we're going to
be taking a look at IF statements.

23
00:00:45.890 --> 00:00:48.440
And this is probably one
of the more powerful

24
00:00:48.440 --> 00:00:51.060
constructs that we have in PowerShell.

25
00:00:51.060 --> 00:00:53.060
You're gonna end up using this a lot.

26
00:00:53.060 --> 00:00:56.530
Again, as we start getting into
writing actual scripts and

27
00:00:56.530 --> 00:00:58.640
doing productive things with this.

28
00:00:58.640 --> 00:01:01.040
This is going to be a big part of that,

29
00:01:01.040 --> 00:01:05.640
just like we said about arrays,
IF statements are used quite a bit.

30
00:01:05.640 --> 00:01:09.490
And an IF statement is really,
the idea is,

31
00:01:09.490 --> 00:01:12.862
I need to do something
based on a condition.

32
00:01:12.862 --> 00:01:15.327
I wanna check a condition,
a value of something,

33
00:01:15.327 --> 00:01:17.277
that we're gonna call it a condition.

34
00:01:17.277 --> 00:01:22.337
And if that condition rings true,
then I wanna perform this action, right.

35
00:01:22.337 --> 00:01:24.910
That's really what an IF
statement breaks down to.

36
00:01:24.910 --> 00:01:29.855
And that's a very powerful concept
when it comes to writing scripts.

37
00:01:29.855 --> 00:01:34.000
Because instead of just writing a script
that everything is gonna execute,

38
00:01:34.000 --> 00:01:36.260
now all of a sudden I can
have conditions in there.

39
00:01:36.260 --> 00:01:41.210
I can say, if this service isn't running,
let's start it or let's print a log,

40
00:01:41.210 --> 00:01:43.720
or let's do something about it, right.

41
00:01:43.720 --> 00:01:45.880
That's the kind of power that
we get with IF statements.

42
00:01:45.880 --> 00:01:48.970
We can check a statement,
check a value, check a condition and

43
00:01:48.970 --> 00:01:50.500
then perform an action.

44
00:01:50.500 --> 00:01:54.060
So let's take a look at my screen here and
let's get started with an IF statement.

45
00:01:54.060 --> 00:01:57.190
I've got the syntax laid out for
us at the very beginning.

46
00:01:57.190 --> 00:01:59.860
It's gonna start with the keyword, IF.

47
00:01:59.860 --> 00:02:04.568
And then you're gonna have your condition,
right, this is what you wanna test for.

48
00:02:04.568 --> 00:02:07.350
And that's gonna go inside parenthesis.

49
00:02:08.520 --> 00:02:12.250
And then after the condition we're gonna
have an open curly brace or an open brace,

50
00:02:12.250 --> 00:02:17.448
then we're gonna have our statements
that we wanna execute if true.

51
00:02:17.448 --> 00:02:20.334
And notice I said statements or
statements and

52
00:02:20.334 --> 00:02:22.927
then s and, I try to be fancy with that.

53
00:02:22.927 --> 00:02:25.610
>> [LAUGH]
>> Possibly an s, possibly not an s.

54
00:02:25.610 --> 00:02:29.180
The point is you could have
a single statement in there,

55
00:02:29.180 --> 00:02:31.710
you need at least one
statement to have an IF.

56
00:02:31.710 --> 00:02:36.760
I need my IF, I need my condition inside
parentheses, I have to have an open and

57
00:02:36.760 --> 00:02:40.570
closing brace, and I've gotta have
at least one statement in there or

58
00:02:40.570 --> 00:02:42.070
my IF is going to fail.

59
00:02:42.070 --> 00:02:45.210
But I can, I wanted to point out,
I can have multiple statements in there,

60
00:02:45.210 --> 00:02:47.610
I'm not limited to just doing one thing.

61
00:02:47.610 --> 00:02:50.880
I can have a series of commands
that I want to go through,

62
00:02:50.880 --> 00:02:52.270
if my condition rings true.

63
00:02:53.270 --> 00:02:56.943
In fact, we can even start nesting IF.

64
00:02:56.943 --> 00:03:01.529
If this condition is true,
then it's gonna execute this.

65
00:03:01.529 --> 00:03:06.100
But these statements could be another IF
statement that checks another condition.

66
00:03:06.100 --> 00:03:12.150
I mean, we can have a lot of fun and get
really crazy complex with our ifs, right?

67
00:03:12.150 --> 00:03:16.010
But there's also other ways we
can write things like that,

68
00:03:16.010 --> 00:03:18.690
that I'm gonna show you
in a future episode.

69
00:03:18.690 --> 00:03:20.160
Right, so that's my basic syntax.

70
00:03:20.160 --> 00:03:26.210
IF condition, open brace, statements,
close brace, there we go that's our IF.

71
00:03:27.440 --> 00:03:29.280
So what I'm gonna do,
let's try it out here.

72
00:03:29.280 --> 00:03:32.140
I've got a variable $A and
I'm gonna go ahead and

73
00:03:32.140 --> 00:03:36.010
assign that the value of 5,
just to kind of get us started here.

74
00:03:36.010 --> 00:03:41.624
And in my very first IF statement
that we have, IF, open parenthesis,

75
00:03:41.624 --> 00:03:47.532
$A-eq dash, remember what we learned
about in our operators episodes.

76
00:03:47.532 --> 00:03:50.113
If you didn't see those make sure
you go back and check them out.

77
00:03:50.113 --> 00:03:54.219
Equals 5, close parentheses,
open brace, and

78
00:03:54.219 --> 00:04:00.399
then I've got a string in here I just
want to print this out, $A equals 5.

79
00:04:00.399 --> 00:04:07.820
And also I've used my single quote marks,
because I do not want $A resolving.

80
00:04:07.820 --> 00:04:10.180
I don't want it to say 5 equals 5,

81
00:04:10.180 --> 00:04:16.230
I want it to say the name of the variable
itself equals 5, if this is true, right?

82
00:04:16.230 --> 00:04:20.106
So, lets see what happen,
right now we know I just set $A to 5, so

83
00:04:20.106 --> 00:04:22.064
if we execute this IF statement.

84
00:04:24.219 --> 00:04:29.045
We'll see that it echoes out the command
first that you're running and

85
00:04:29.045 --> 00:04:32.080
that actually $A equals 5, beautiful.

86
00:04:32.080 --> 00:04:32.860
>> Just what you wanted.

87
00:04:32.860 --> 00:04:34.952
>> Exactly what we wanted, all right?

88
00:04:34.952 --> 00:04:39.379
Now let's see what happens if
it doesn't equal 5, all right?

89
00:04:39.379 --> 00:04:43.528
So I'm gonna change A to 6, we're gonna
execute that same statement again.

90
00:04:45.939 --> 00:04:47.730
And notice I get nothing back.

91
00:04:47.730 --> 00:04:52.580
It does still echo out the command I'm
executing, but I get no results back,

92
00:04:52.580 --> 00:04:58.360
because this IF statement is saying,
if this is true, then do this.

93
00:04:58.360 --> 00:05:00.560
But this is not true?

94
00:05:00.560 --> 00:05:02.490
Then that's the end of the IF
statement in this case.

95
00:05:02.490 --> 00:05:05.154
The way we've got it laid out now,
there's nothing to do.

96
00:05:05.154 --> 00:05:07.027
It says, nope, that's not true.

97
00:05:07.027 --> 00:05:09.341
And it moves on outside of the IF,

98
00:05:09.341 --> 00:05:14.730
to whatever the next line in your script
might be, that IF statement is done.

99
00:05:14.730 --> 00:05:17.970
If it's false,
it doesn't do anything in this case.

100
00:05:19.808 --> 00:05:24.310
Now I wanna make sure we point out here,
while I'm at this spot.

101
00:05:24.310 --> 00:05:26.520
This is a very common mistake.

102
00:05:26.520 --> 00:05:27.670
I see it all the time.

103
00:05:27.670 --> 00:05:31.400
Heck, I do this now and again,
especially if you switch back and

104
00:05:31.400 --> 00:05:35.845
forth between different languages,
you might find yourself doing this.

105
00:05:35.845 --> 00:05:38.365
Cherokee, I'm gonna put
you on the spot here.

106
00:05:38.365 --> 00:05:38.965
>> Okay.

107
00:05:38.965 --> 00:05:42.026
>> Can you remember, and no problem if
you don't, we just did this, right?

108
00:05:42.026 --> 00:05:44.326
But,
>> Goodness [CROSSTALK].

109
00:05:44.326 --> 00:05:45.820
Do you know what the mistake is?

110
00:05:45.820 --> 00:05:49.821
>> All right, so
I'm looking at this, A equals 10.

111
00:05:49.821 --> 00:05:54.365
So that, you're now saying that $A is 10.

112
00:05:54.365 --> 00:05:57.470
If you wanted to say equals,
you would put -eq.

113
00:05:57.470 --> 00:05:58.810
>> Perfect, right?

114
00:05:58.810 --> 00:06:03.205
A single equal sign is
an assignment operator.

115
00:06:03.205 --> 00:06:05.701
>> Is that hashtag common mistake?

116
00:06:05.701 --> 00:06:09.381
>> Yes, exactly that is a very
common mistake [LAUGH].

117
00:06:09.381 --> 00:06:10.160
>> [LAUGH]
>> But

118
00:06:10.160 --> 00:06:14.430
she's exactly right, what I'm doing here,
is I'm not testing anything.

119
00:06:14.430 --> 00:06:19.520
I'm actually assigning the value
10 to the variable A, right?

120
00:06:19.520 --> 00:06:23.890
Which is not what I wanna do,
A should still equal 6 in our case, so

121
00:06:23.890 --> 00:06:26.348
that's fine,
we'll see what happens when I run this.

122
00:06:26.348 --> 00:06:32.520
If $A equals 10 or that's what we think
we're doing, then do this, right?

123
00:06:32.520 --> 00:06:34.520
Well I'll go ahead and execute it.

124
00:06:34.520 --> 00:06:38.310
Notice it does perform the inner
statement, $A equals 10,

125
00:06:38.310 --> 00:06:39.678
well of course it did.

126
00:06:39.678 --> 00:06:42.270
A equals 10 because I just said it,
equal to 10.

127
00:06:42.270 --> 00:06:46.428
So the end result of this expression
is actually a true, right,

128
00:06:46.428 --> 00:06:49.830
it does come back true if
you are setting this value.

129
00:06:49.830 --> 00:06:52.881
But there's no test involved, so

130
00:06:52.881 --> 00:06:58.154
just the fact that this
assignment succeeded, I get true.

131
00:06:58.154 --> 00:07:00.913
Not the fact that it actually equals 10,
in fact here,

132
00:07:00.913 --> 00:07:03.512
let's do something like this,
what if I put in 15?

133
00:07:03.512 --> 00:07:04.696
Oops that is not.

134
00:07:04.696 --> 00:07:07.220
>> [LAUGH]
>> Let's check your Num Lock there.

135
00:07:07.220 --> 00:07:12.700
I'll say, IF A equals 15 we'll execute it,
notice I still get my result.

136
00:07:12.700 --> 00:07:15.280
It still does execute that inner block.

137
00:07:15.280 --> 00:07:17.690
Again, because this is
not checking anything.

138
00:07:17.690 --> 00:07:18.950
It's just doing an assignment.

139
00:07:18.950 --> 00:07:23.680
The assignment succeeded, so
I'm getting a true result, right?

140
00:07:23.680 --> 00:07:26.180
And then it executes what's inside there.

141
00:07:26.180 --> 00:07:27.790
So very easy to do.

142
00:07:27.790 --> 00:07:30.105
Another one I see, is this one, right.

143
00:07:30.105 --> 00:07:34.804
I do this very often,
especially lately because

144
00:07:34.804 --> 00:07:39.857
I've been playing around
in some C++ in Arduino.

145
00:07:39.857 --> 00:07:44.358
And this is what they would use
in there to do equality check.

146
00:07:44.358 --> 00:07:44.902
>> Okay.

147
00:07:44.902 --> 00:07:48.380
>> But this does not work in
our code either, all right?

148
00:07:48.380 --> 00:07:51.943
Notice how it's actually saying,
the errors, the second equal sign.

149
00:07:51.943 --> 00:07:55.500
If you look, I don't think you
guys can tell onscreen, but

150
00:07:55.500 --> 00:07:57.364
the first equal sign is black.

151
00:07:57.364 --> 00:07:58.644
>> And then blue.
>> Yes, good, so

152
00:07:58.644 --> 00:08:01.453
you can see that,
that second equal is actually blue.

153
00:08:01.453 --> 00:08:05.414
Which is a really good indicator
that something is not right,

154
00:08:05.414 --> 00:08:09.157
because we know our operator
should be black, all right.

155
00:08:09.157 --> 00:08:12.563
So those,
a very kind of a mistake, easy to,

156
00:08:12.563 --> 00:08:17.980
do but in something like this it
might not be easy to spot at first.

157
00:08:17.980 --> 00:08:22.330
Because it succeeded and I get the results
that I think I should be getting.

158
00:08:22.330 --> 00:08:25.980
>> And you're just chugging along,
moving onto the next task, yeah.

159
00:08:25.980 --> 00:08:27.700
[LAUGH]
>> And you're thinking, okay,

160
00:08:27.700 --> 00:08:30.113
a must equal ten, it printed it out, so
I'm going along assuming a is ten and

161
00:08:30.113 --> 00:08:30.970
I'm doing other things.

162
00:08:30.970 --> 00:08:34.940
And a is indeed not ten, so it can
definitely cause some problems later on.

163
00:08:34.940 --> 00:08:37.630
So do be careful with that one,
that is a no no.

164
00:08:38.650 --> 00:08:42.240
All right, so pretty straight forward,
right, not too bad.

165
00:08:42.240 --> 00:08:46.150
An if statement is just the key word if,
open parentheses, condition,

166
00:08:46.150 --> 00:08:51.520
close parentheses, open brace, statements,
close brace, and you're good to go.

167
00:08:51.520 --> 00:08:53.690
Let's real quick talk about
the syntax again though,

168
00:08:53.690 --> 00:08:55.110
I do wanna show you guys this.

169
00:08:55.110 --> 00:08:57.645
I have my way of doing things.

170
00:08:57.645 --> 00:09:02.330
Everybody kind of has their
own way of styling their code.

171
00:09:02.330 --> 00:09:05.210
The end goal is to make sure
that it's readable, and

172
00:09:05.210 --> 00:09:08.080
not just by you, but
that's also very important.

173
00:09:08.080 --> 00:09:09.770
I need to be able to look at
this six months from now.

174
00:09:09.770 --> 00:09:10.840
When I haven't seen it for

175
00:09:10.840 --> 00:09:15.320
180 days, I want to be able to understand
what the heck I did and why I did it.

176
00:09:15.320 --> 00:09:17.568
But also because you're probably
gonna be sharing this or

177
00:09:17.568 --> 00:09:20.010
other people could be working
with your code as well.

178
00:09:20.010 --> 00:09:25.170
So you want to make sure it's readable,
presentable, that it's understandable.

179
00:09:25.170 --> 00:09:26.040
I break this out.

180
00:09:26.040 --> 00:09:31.250
As you can see I've got my if and
then my condition.

181
00:09:31.250 --> 00:09:34.490
Oops and I've just moved
everything there as I drag that.

182
00:09:34.490 --> 00:09:36.160
And then I've got my condition.

183
00:09:36.160 --> 00:09:40.950
And then my open brace, I put it on that
same line, right, and then I return,

184
00:09:40.950 --> 00:09:42.980
I have a line break there, and

185
00:09:42.980 --> 00:09:48.050
then I tab in and all of my statements
will be tabbed into the same point.

186
00:09:48.050 --> 00:09:52.700
And then my close brace goes on the
following line after all of my statements.

187
00:09:52.700 --> 00:09:55.640
And it's aligned with my if, right.

188
00:09:55.640 --> 00:09:57.580
So even if this was nested inside,

189
00:09:57.580 --> 00:10:01.260
gosh darn it,
keeps dragging instead of selecting.

190
00:10:01.260 --> 00:10:05.060
Even if this was nested inside
another loop, right, my if and

191
00:10:05.060 --> 00:10:09.380
my closing brace are lined up,
all right, vertically here.

192
00:10:09.380 --> 00:10:14.100
So that I can tell that this closing
brace matches this if statement.

193
00:10:14.100 --> 00:10:19.000
And it's just a way to keep track of
what belongs inside that if statement.

194
00:10:19.000 --> 00:10:22.990
Other people will do it differently,
and there's nothing wrong with that.

195
00:10:22.990 --> 00:10:26.590
Find your own style that works for you.

196
00:10:26.590 --> 00:10:32.600
If we want to, we can actually
write this all on one line.

197
00:10:32.600 --> 00:10:33.700
There is nothing wrong with this.

198
00:10:33.700 --> 00:10:38.910
In fact, if you're working from your
console and not the ISE you need to

199
00:10:38.910 --> 00:10:43.690
write it all on one line, right, cuz every
time we hit Enter it tries to execute.

200
00:10:43.690 --> 00:10:46.910
So you can definitely write
this all on one line.

201
00:10:46.910 --> 00:10:52.010
In which case, because I wouldn't have a
line break between each set of statements,

202
00:10:52.010 --> 00:10:57.140
I would use a semicolon, and
then I could put additional

203
00:10:57.140 --> 00:11:01.520
statements in here like such, right.

204
00:11:01.520 --> 00:11:05.530
And so like I said, if you wanna keep
it all in one line this is fine.

205
00:11:05.530 --> 00:11:11.171
If it starts getting too long though,
it kinda stretches over,

206
00:11:11.171 --> 00:11:16.925
to me it's much much easier to read
if I have something like this.

207
00:11:16.925 --> 00:11:22.270
So I prefer kinda setting
these up like such, all right.

208
00:11:22.270 --> 00:11:23.810
>> This is not really something
you think about, though.

209
00:11:23.810 --> 00:11:25.690
When you said each person
has their own style,

210
00:11:25.690 --> 00:11:30.840
I was reading an article about
trying to find the identity

211
00:11:30.840 --> 00:11:36.100
of an individual associated with
a digital currency management system.

212
00:11:36.100 --> 00:11:40.990
And they were performing code analysis to
help locate and identify that individual.

213
00:11:40.990 --> 00:11:41.740
So it's kinda neat.

214
00:11:41.740 --> 00:11:43.340
>> They call it a signature, right.

215
00:11:43.340 --> 00:11:47.340
It's almost like the,
I think of the FBI and examining bombs and

216
00:11:47.340 --> 00:11:48.960
they're like okay, there's a signature-
>> Exactly.

217
00:11:48.960 --> 00:11:49.830
>> To this trigger.

218
00:11:49.830 --> 00:11:51.420
The way this trigger was assembled.

219
00:11:51.420 --> 00:11:52.190
Same thing with code.

220
00:11:52.190 --> 00:11:53.560
Yeah, they can find things in there.

221
00:11:53.560 --> 00:11:55.770
They're like, I've seen this code before.

222
00:11:55.770 --> 00:11:56.327
>> This is Mike again.

223
00:11:56.327 --> 00:11:58.237
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, this is that Mike guy.

224
00:11:58.237 --> 00:12:02.565
Now if I am using carriage returns or line
breaks there, I don't need my semicolons.

225
00:12:02.565 --> 00:12:06.232
The semicolons wouldn't hurt anything if I
left them in here between each statement.

226
00:12:06.232 --> 00:12:10.132
And they can help with your readability as
well as far as telling where one statement

227
00:12:10.132 --> 00:12:11.869
ends and the other one begins maybe.

228
00:12:11.869 --> 00:12:18.509
I just like, to me this looks good,
it's very, very easy to work through it.

229
00:12:18.509 --> 00:12:22.416
And if I wanna add another statement I
can definitely do that by just adding

230
00:12:22.416 --> 00:12:23.242
another line.

231
00:12:23.242 --> 00:12:28.021
And I can easily tell that I didn't
forget my closing brace because it's

232
00:12:28.021 --> 00:12:30.200
lined up with my if itself.

233
00:12:30.200 --> 00:12:36.020
And that's one of the things that, I know
sometimes it can be tedious a little

234
00:12:36.020 --> 00:12:40.070
bit when you have lots of code blocks
inside here and start nesting things.

235
00:12:40.070 --> 00:12:43.610
You end up with five closing
curly braces in a row.

236
00:12:43.610 --> 00:12:45.454
And when it looks like this,

237
00:12:47.612 --> 00:12:51.874
It's really hard to tell which one you
missed or which one goes with which or

238
00:12:51.874 --> 00:12:56.580
where I would insert something if I
wanted to be on that third nested level.

239
00:12:56.580 --> 00:12:59.446
But if I did, and
I shouldn't do all of these here, and

240
00:12:59.446 --> 00:13:01.605
it's going to obviously throw
an error cuz there's no opening.

241
00:13:01.605 --> 00:13:08.892
But normally mine would look
something like that, right.

242
00:13:08.892 --> 00:13:12.520
Where, okay, I can see this one goes here,
this one closes here.

243
00:13:12.520 --> 00:13:14.530
>> Okay.

00:25:48.496 --> 00:25:51.774
use that takes a lot less
typing a little more efficient.

467
00:25:51.774 --> 00:25:57.460
It's known as a switch, and that's what
we're gonna cover next, all right?

468
00:25:57.460 --> 00:25:58.805
Forgot what I was doing down here.

469
00:25:58.805 --> 00:25:59.495
Just some examples here.

470
00:25:59.495 --> 00:26:01.805
Here's another if statement.

471
00:26:01.805 --> 00:26:07.102
In this case, I was kind of showing you,
starting to show you some real world,

472
00:26:07.102 --> 00:26:11.200
some actual administration
isnt all that effective, but

473
00:26:11.200 --> 00:26:15.723
I just start to show you another
than dollar sign a, dollar sign b.

474
00:26:15.723 --> 00:26:18.180
So here Im saying get service, right?

475
00:26:18.180 --> 00:26:18.870
We know what that does.

476
00:26:18.870 --> 00:26:22.220
That goes and gets a list of all
the running services on this system.

477
00:26:22.220 --> 00:26:24.410
Or the system I'm running the script on.

478
00:26:24.410 --> 00:26:26.319
So it's get service-name.

479
00:26:26.319 --> 00:26:27.174
>> You're gonna filter
it a little bit here.

480
00:26:27.174 --> 00:26:28.599
>> What's that?
>> You're gonna filter a little bit here.

481
00:26:28.599 --> 00:26:29.409
>> Exactly.

482
00:26:29.409 --> 00:26:30.381
>> Your DNS cache.

483
00:26:30.381 --> 00:26:31.600
>> I'm gonna say DNS cache.

484
00:26:31.600 --> 00:26:34.237
So that's the service that I want to get.

485
00:26:34.237 --> 00:26:36.410
And not just all of them just that one.

486
00:26:36.410 --> 00:26:40.620
Remember, everything in
PowerShell is an object, so

487
00:26:40.620 --> 00:26:44.710
with this it's going to return
that service DNS cache.

488
00:26:44.710 --> 00:26:48.944
I wrap that in parenthesis, and
now I can use a dot, and oops,

489
00:26:48.944 --> 00:26:53.666
I just tried to move the dot, and
I can now access all the properties,

490
00:26:53.666 --> 00:26:56.949
and there I just moved status,
I tell you what.

491
00:26:56.949 --> 00:27:01.206
I can access the properties
of that object.

492
00:27:01.206 --> 00:27:04.092
So here I'm saying I want
to get this service, but

493
00:27:04.092 --> 00:27:06.790
I really just want
the status of that service.

494
00:27:07.800 --> 00:27:13.082
And then, all of these goes
into my condition, my open.

495
00:27:13.082 --> 00:27:16.050
See the open and closing parenthesis
on the outside of that, so

496
00:27:16.050 --> 00:27:17.453
all of that's my condition.

497
00:27:17.453 --> 00:27:19.895
If the services status
is equal to running-

498
00:27:19.895 --> 00:27:21.726
>> Okay, then what?

499
00:27:21.726 --> 00:27:24.412
>> Then perform this action, right?

500
00:27:24.412 --> 00:27:30.537
So we'll execute that, and
I get the DNS client is running.

501
00:27:30.537 --> 00:27:33.496
I could do an else with that,
I was just goofing around here.

502
00:27:33.496 --> 00:27:36.957
Else, the DNS client is not running,
so if it wasn't,

503
00:27:36.957 --> 00:27:40.361
then it would print that last line,
but it is running.

504
00:27:40.361 --> 00:27:43.625
And I don't want to stop it right now,
cuz I would lose my name resolution, so

505
00:27:43.625 --> 00:27:44.891
we're not going to see that.

506
00:27:44.891 --> 00:27:48.911
But that's a good look,
I think at what we can do with an if.

507
00:27:48.911 --> 00:27:52.970
And we've got an if,
you got your else if, you got your else.

508
00:27:52.970 --> 00:27:53.905
Very powerful stuff.

509
00:27:53.905 --> 00:27:57.721
Make sure you get this syntax down and
understand how to use it,

510
00:27:57.721 --> 00:27:59.741
because we will be using it a lot.

511
00:27:59.741 --> 00:28:03.443
>> I feel like we are just opening
the Pandora box of statements here, and

512
00:28:03.443 --> 00:28:04.586
packing into those.

513
00:28:04.586 --> 00:28:08.103
So you don't wanna miss the other types of
statements that we have headed your way,

514
00:28:08.103 --> 00:28:09.775
but for this show we are gonna sign out.

515
00:28:09.775 --> 00:28:11.280
I've been your host Cherokee Boose.

516
00:28:11.280 --> 00:28:12.133
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

517
00:28:12.133 --> 00:28:13.556
>> See you next time here ITProTV.

518
00:28:13.556 --> 00:28:21.216
[MUSIC]

519
00:28:21.216 --> 00:28:23.812
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode you will learn about switch statements. You will see how switch statements are equivalent to a series of If statements, but are simpler to write as well as read.
episodes.title: Switch Statements
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:01.200
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.200 --> 00:00:07.519
I'm your host Don Pezet- [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:07.519 --> 00:00:08.325
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.325 --> 00:00:10.300
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:10.300 --> 00:00:14.140
>> Welcome to your
PowerShell Scripting series.

6
00:00:14.140 --> 00:00:16.070
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:16.070 --> 00:00:19.130
In the last episode we were taking
a look at some if statements and

8
00:00:19.130 --> 00:00:22.670
in this show we're gonna move
on to some switch statements.

9
00:00:22.670 --> 00:00:25.265
We'll switch on to the switch statements.

10
00:00:25.265 --> 00:00:29.280
>> [LAUGH] I was waiting for that, I was
wondering if that was gonna come out.

11
00:00:29.280 --> 00:00:31.240
>> I just thought of it
right as I said it too.

12
00:00:31.240 --> 00:00:32.330
>> That's all right.
>> It's okay,

13
00:00:32.330 --> 00:00:34.740
I'm sure we'll have other
opportunities to mess things up here.

14
00:00:34.740 --> 00:00:37.508
>> We will, well, we'll switch it
up many times throughout the show.

15
00:00:37.508 --> 00:00:39.360
>> I didn't even get a chance
to introduce you, Mike.

16
00:00:39.360 --> 00:00:41.209
How will anyone know who you are?

17
00:00:41.209 --> 00:00:42.175
[LAUGH]
>> Watch,

18
00:00:42.175 --> 00:00:44.713
it's magic,
it's gonna appear right below me.

19
00:00:48.040 --> 00:00:49.495
It was a little slow but there it is.

20
00:00:49.495 --> 00:00:52.695
There it is right down there, all right?

21
00:00:52.695 --> 00:00:53.715
How's everybody doing?

22
00:00:53.715 --> 00:00:55.275
Glad to be back, thank you, Cherokee.

23
00:00:55.275 --> 00:00:57.149
Excited as always, and yeah,

24
00:00:57.149 --> 00:01:00.832
we are gonna switch it up with
some switch statements today.

25
00:01:00.832 --> 00:01:04.635
So as Cherokee was saying, in a previous
episode we took a look at if statements.

26
00:01:04.635 --> 00:01:07.160
And that was a way that I
could check a condition.

27
00:01:07.160 --> 00:01:11.010
And then execute statements based
on the results of that check.

28
00:01:11.010 --> 00:01:16.233
Not the value of the statement, but
whether the statement was true or

29
00:01:16.233 --> 00:01:19.484
false, I could execute code, all right?

30
00:01:19.484 --> 00:01:21.860
And we also saw that we
could do several checks.

31
00:01:21.860 --> 00:01:25.680
We could do a single check,
we could start doing else ifs, and

32
00:01:25.680 --> 00:01:27.360
we could do multiple checks.

33
00:01:27.360 --> 00:01:31.050
And I said, once you start getting
too many if statements, or

34
00:01:31.050 --> 00:01:34.620
too many condition checks,
there's a better way to go about it.

35
00:01:34.620 --> 00:01:39.568
A little bit more efficient, and not so
much efficient as performance goes, but

36
00:01:39.568 --> 00:01:44.467
more about efficient as far as code goes,
writing the code, reading the code.

37
00:01:44.467 --> 00:01:46.752
And again,
I know I've stressed this before.

38
00:01:46.752 --> 00:01:51.070
It's a very important part of writing code
is writing good readable code that other

39
00:01:51.070 --> 00:01:56.820
people can use and understand, or
that you can understand later on, right?

40
00:01:56.820 --> 00:01:59.420
So let's take a look at my screen here and
we'll talk about the switch.

41
00:01:59.420 --> 00:02:03.184
The switch is basically going
to do what an if statement does.

42
00:02:03.184 --> 00:02:06.300
It's gonna allow me to
have a test value or

43
00:02:06.300 --> 00:02:09.860
something that I wanna check
against multiple conditions.

44
00:02:11.200 --> 00:02:13.249
We wouldn't use a switch if
I only had one condition.

45
00:02:13.249 --> 00:02:15.750
I'd use an if statement, easy enough.

46
00:02:15.750 --> 00:02:21.050
I can say, if this is true do this,
N brace, done, right?

47
00:02:21.050 --> 00:02:21.975
Nothing left to do.

48
00:02:21.975 --> 00:02:25.528
But as soon as I start having to
do else if this, else if that,

49
00:02:25.528 --> 00:02:30.330
else if that, that's when I might
wanna consider moving into our switch.

50
00:02:30.330 --> 00:02:35.682
>> Maybe like we're graduating as it's
progressively becoming more complex here.

51
00:02:35.682 --> 00:02:38.312
>> Absolutely,
it'll be a good way to look at it.

52
00:02:38.312 --> 00:02:43.110
So our syntax is very similar,
well, okay, maybe not so much.

53
00:02:43.110 --> 00:02:45.390
Similar a little bit to our ifs.

54
00:02:45.390 --> 00:02:49.350
I've got my switch keyword
that's gonna start it all off.

55
00:02:49.350 --> 00:02:51.880
And I've got my open parentheses, and

56
00:02:51.880 --> 00:02:57.370
in there I'm gonna have the value that
I wanna test against the conditions.

57
00:02:57.370 --> 00:02:58.450
It's a little bit different here.

58
00:02:58.450 --> 00:03:01.840
With the if statement my
parentheses contain the condition

59
00:03:01.840 --> 00:03:04.830
that I wanted to test to see
if it was true or false.

60
00:03:04.830 --> 00:03:05.800
With the switch,

61
00:03:05.800 --> 00:03:09.490
within my parentheses it's the value
that I'm going to be checking, right?

62
00:03:09.490 --> 00:03:11.570
I haven't told it what
the condition is yet,

63
00:03:11.570 --> 00:03:17.320
saying this is what I wanna check, and
then open brace, and then condition.

64
00:03:17.320 --> 00:03:21.896
And then, the actions I wanna perform or
the statements that I want to fire,

65
00:03:21.896 --> 00:03:24.430
if this condition is true.

66
00:03:24.430 --> 00:03:27.340
Well, if that condition isn't true,
it'll move to the next one,

67
00:03:27.340 --> 00:03:30.430
to see if this condition is true.

68
00:03:30.430 --> 00:03:34.040
And if it is,
it will perform those actions, right?

69
00:03:34.040 --> 00:03:40.341
So as like I said,
similar in skeletal syntax maybe.

70
00:03:40.341 --> 00:03:43.330
Keyword, open close parentheses,
open brace, close brace for

71
00:03:43.330 --> 00:03:47.840
my code blocks, but where things
are is a little bit different.

72
00:03:47.840 --> 00:03:50.740
So switch, the value I wanna check,

73
00:03:50.740 --> 00:03:54.110
the condition,
what to do if that condition is true.

74
00:03:54.110 --> 00:03:57.600
The next condition I wanna test,
and what to do if that's true.

75
00:03:57.600 --> 00:04:03.285
And I can have as many of these as I want
but it's gonna be a lot more readable

76
00:04:03.285 --> 00:04:08.913
than a long complex if else, if else,
if else, if else type statement.

77
00:04:08.913 --> 00:04:12.760
Because with the else if's, and
I'll show you an example here in second.

78
00:04:12.760 --> 00:04:14.387
I'll come back to that thought.

79
00:04:14.387 --> 00:04:16.420
All right, so
let's do a very simple one here.

80
00:04:16.420 --> 00:04:19.160
As I scroll down,
here's our first switch statement.

81
00:04:19.160 --> 00:04:21.390
And you can see my keyword switch.

82
00:04:21.390 --> 00:04:24.840
The value I wanna test is the variable A.

83
00:04:24.840 --> 00:04:30.920
I've got my open brace, and
then I have my first condition.

84
00:04:30.920 --> 00:04:33.770
If a is a 1, and
you can really read it like that.

85
00:04:33.770 --> 00:04:36.009
I mean, you kind of are.

86
00:04:36.009 --> 00:04:40.050
You're doing an if inside this switch,
just not using that if syntax.

87
00:04:40.050 --> 00:04:43.810
So if a is 1, do this.

88
00:04:43.810 --> 00:04:47.481
Well if a is 2, do this.

89
00:04:47.481 --> 00:04:49.165
If a is 3, do this.

90
00:04:49.165 --> 00:04:51.248
If a is 4, do this.

91
00:04:51.248 --> 00:04:54.657
Let's see what happens if we set a to,
I don't know, what do you want to say,

92
00:04:54.657 --> 00:04:55.410
Cherokee, 3?

93
00:04:55.410 --> 00:04:56.988
>> 3 is great.

94
00:04:56.988 --> 00:04:59.490
>> Great, I typed it before
I even gave you a chance.

95
00:04:59.490 --> 00:05:01.774
Why did I even ask you?

96
00:05:01.774 --> 00:05:04.960
[LAUGH] What would you like to set it to?

97
00:05:04.960 --> 00:05:06.982
>> I was thinking in my mind 1.

98
00:05:06.982 --> 00:05:08.252
>> Were you?
Okay, let's do 1.

99
00:05:08.252 --> 00:05:10.190
>> Now that you're asking.

100
00:05:10.190 --> 00:05:12.170
>> Okay, we're gonna do 1.

101
00:05:12.170 --> 00:05:13.956
I guess I did ask.
It's only fair.

102
00:05:13.956 --> 00:05:16.345
And now let's execute our switch.

103
00:05:16.345 --> 00:05:17.180
Wait, did I execute that?

104
00:05:17.180 --> 00:05:20.030
Let's make sure a equals 1, there we go.

105
00:05:20.030 --> 00:05:22.870
And now let's run through our switch and
see what happens.

106
00:05:24.020 --> 00:05:26.690
>> 1.
>> All right, I get back 1, so

107
00:05:26.690 --> 00:05:28.600
it worked perfectly.

108
00:05:28.600 --> 00:05:31.580
What if 1 was to equal 3?

109
00:05:31.580 --> 00:05:35.310
Let's execute that, and
then execute our switch again.

110
00:05:36.780 --> 00:05:37.580
I get 3.

111
00:05:37.580 --> 00:05:38.140
>> Okay.

112
00:05:38.140 --> 00:05:40.609
>> Beautiful, easy breezy, right?

113
00:05:40.609 --> 00:05:42.080
That's what we like to say.

114
00:05:42.080 --> 00:05:45.490
So that is a very basic switch statement.

115
00:05:45.490 --> 00:05:49.290
Check a value against these conditions,
and

116
00:05:49.290 --> 00:05:53.890
here are the actions to
perform if it's true, right?

117
00:05:53.890 --> 00:05:58.820
Now these are very short little
code blocks for each one of these.

118
00:05:58.820 --> 00:06:03.804
If I was doing this and it was multiple
statements that I wanted to perform

119
00:06:03.804 --> 00:06:08.804
on if it was 1, I would probably have
this lined up slightly different.

120
00:06:08.804 --> 00:06:13.837
I would do something like this,
right, where I can see

121
00:06:13.837 --> 00:06:18.981
that is definitely the code block for
condition 1, and

122
00:06:18.981 --> 00:06:26.220
these are all of the statements that I
wanna execute, right, if that is true.

123
00:06:26.220 --> 00:06:31.130
So if we set that back to 1,
we should see that

124
00:06:31.130 --> 00:06:35.600
all of those execute, oops.

125
00:06:35.600 --> 00:06:37.082
What did I miss there?

126
00:06:40.184 --> 00:06:44.484
[INAUDIBLE] No, I don't think it
likes my line breaks in there.

127
00:06:44.484 --> 00:06:47.171
I may have to [INAUDIBLE].

128
00:06:47.171 --> 00:06:50.040
But I would line it up,
I have to check my syntax on that.

129
00:06:50.040 --> 00:06:55.223
I'm getting unexpected token,
in expression on statement at line seven.

130
00:06:55.223 --> 00:06:59.377
One, two, three, four, five, six,
seven, it doesn't like this one.

131
00:07:07.278 --> 00:07:08.200
There we go.

132
00:07:08.200 --> 00:07:10.092
It didn't like the line break after that.

133
00:07:10.092 --> 00:07:13.450
Probably have to get some semicolons in
there to make sure I ended each of my

134
00:07:13.450 --> 00:07:13.970
statements.

135
00:07:13.970 --> 00:07:17.050
But I might line it up something
a little more like that

136
00:07:17.050 --> 00:07:19.380
rather than stretch it across the page.

137
00:07:19.380 --> 00:07:23.050
But again,
that is definitely a personal type thing.

138
00:07:23.050 --> 00:07:27.790
>> So I'm just trying to rationalize
where I would use a command like this.

139
00:07:27.790 --> 00:07:33.400
And I'm thinking,
going back to the if terminology here,

140
00:07:33.400 --> 00:07:38.380
but I maybe I could run a command that
says hey, if this particular service is

141
00:07:38.380 --> 00:07:42.760
running, and then I call out a service,
then do a restart.

142
00:07:42.760 --> 00:07:45.770
But I could add multiple
parameters in there for

143
00:07:45.770 --> 00:07:47.430
certain virtual machines or whatever.

144
00:07:47.430 --> 00:07:50.782
So if I had an issue with a service and
I wanted to just say, hey,

145
00:07:50.782 --> 00:07:54.160
I need to restart all those machines,
then that would that be?

146
00:07:54.160 --> 00:07:57.117
>> Yeah,
you could possibly do that with this.

147
00:07:57.117 --> 00:08:00.428
The thing to remember is
you have one condition or

148
00:08:00.428 --> 00:08:02.700
one value that you're testing.

149
00:08:02.700 --> 00:08:07.636
In this case, well, I shouldn't say that,
because we can definitely roll multiple

150
00:08:07.636 --> 00:08:12.390
values in there, I'm gonna show you
an example of that in just a little bit.

151
00:08:12.390 --> 00:08:17.120
So, yeah, you might do something like that
where the condition would change, right?

152
00:08:17.120 --> 00:08:22.290
Over here rather than be a one, cuz this
would be maybe the status of the service.

153
00:08:22.290 --> 00:08:27.140
So, get service dot status type thing,
this would be all the possible values.

154
00:08:27.140 --> 00:08:29.720
Each one of these would be
a possible value for the service.

155
00:08:29.720 --> 00:08:32.510
Stop, started, or something like that.

156
00:08:32.510 --> 00:08:35.440
And what to do if it were started,
and what to do if it were stopped.

157
00:08:36.740 --> 00:08:39.890
So, I can see where maybe you have
a list of virtual machines, and

158
00:08:39.890 --> 00:08:41.410
you want to make sure they're running.

159
00:08:41.410 --> 00:08:45.500
And so, you could have a thing that ran
through a list of virtual machine names,

160
00:08:45.500 --> 00:08:47.010
if it's running, don't do anything.

161
00:08:47.010 --> 00:08:49.075
If it's not, do something.

162
00:08:49.075 --> 00:08:52.472
So, yeah, I could probably work
something out like that, for sure.

163
00:08:52.472 --> 00:08:54.071
All right,
now let's take a look, you know,

164
00:08:54.071 --> 00:08:55.590
what I'm gonna switch
my view a little bit.

165
00:08:55.590 --> 00:08:56.180
In this case,

166
00:08:56.180 --> 00:08:59.470
I think it might make a little more
sense to have a longer pane here.

167
00:08:59.470 --> 00:09:01.690
So, I'll move my script
pane over to the side.

168
00:09:02.800 --> 00:09:06.270
So, here's what we just ran,
this is the switch statement.

169
00:09:06.270 --> 00:09:08.900
Here's the exact same code.

170
00:09:08.900 --> 00:09:10.360
In an if statement.

171
00:09:10.360 --> 00:09:11.640
Which one is easier to read?

172
00:09:11.640 --> 00:09:12.900
>> Yeah, for sure.

173
00:09:12.900 --> 00:09:13.490
The top one, yeah.

174
00:09:13.490 --> 00:09:16.670
>> It's really easy to see, hey,
if it's a two it's gonna do this oops and

175
00:09:16.670 --> 00:09:18.270
I just rearranged things again.

176
00:09:18.270 --> 00:09:20.360
And if it's a three this
is what it's gonna do.

00:20:59.270 --> 00:21:01.467
And that's exactly right, but

00:21:01.467 --> 00:21:05.890
I wanna make sure we understand-
>> Where or how it breaks?

The break is on an entire command,
or the entire switch.

00:21:16.650 --> 00:21:17.850
So in other words.

00:21:17.850 --> 00:21:20.260

let's see what happens.

00:21:41.350 --> 00:21:42.450

424
00:21:42.450 --> 00:21:43.350

00:21:43.350 --> 00:21:46.237

00:21:49.500 --> 00:21:51.696

00:21:51.696 --> 00:21:56.076
So a was three, so it says, it's not one,
it's not two, it is three, so

429
00:21:56.076 --> 00:21:57.590
I'm gonna print three.

430
00:21:57.590 --> 00:21:58.990
And then I'm going to break.

431
00:22:00.360 --> 00:22:01.700
And then that's it.

432
00:22:01.700 --> 00:22:05.610
It does not continue to check
a against four or three,

433
00:22:05.610 --> 00:22:10.980
it also does not go back, and take
the next variable, and test it, right?

434
00:22:10.980 --> 00:22:15.600
I might have 15 values that I'm getting
ready to check, but as soon as the first

00:22:15.600 --> 00:22:21.320
one rings true, and runs into a break
statement, the rest don't get checked.

436
00:22:21.320 --> 00:22:22.820
It stops right there, so

00:22:22.820 --> 00:22:25.790
it's a very important thing to keep in the
back your mind, cuz a lot of people think,

00:22:25.790 --> 00:22:29.510
okay, well I'm done testing a,

00:22:55.845 --> 00:22:58.129
so as soon as it match one it would exit,

00:22:58.129 --> 00:23:01.796
then it would jump out of the switch and

00:23:01.796 --> 00:23:04.370
but we haven't got [CROSSTALK]
>> That's say.

So again,

three, four, three again, and

this condition looks a little different

00:23:41.920 --> 00:23:46.500
I've been keeping these switches very

>> [LAUGH] All right, so here,

none of these are gonna match, but down

Inside close meaning it's a string,

00:25:27.290 --> 00:25:32.340

I think I told you my

episodes.description: In this episode, you will learn about For statements. You will learn how to use For statements to create a loop that runs commands in a command block while a specified condition evaluates to true.
episodes.title: For Statements

25
00:00:57.530 --> 00:01:00.340
Again, I think in our previous
episode we looked at for-each.

26
00:01:00.340 --> 00:01:06.150
And we said that a for-each is really
great for iterating through every object.

27
00:01:06.150 --> 00:01:08.180
When you have an array or
something like that.

28
00:01:08.180 --> 00:01:14.170
You're just simply saying,
for-each items in this collection do this.

29
00:01:14.170 --> 00:01:17.730
Right, and so
it's very good at cycling through.

00:01:17.730 --> 00:01:21.020
We don't have to worry about keeping

31

If it's a 15 element array or

It's gonna go through each one of them and
perform those actions or

34
00:01:30.400 --> 00:01:36.360
A for loop or a for statement allows
me to be a little more specific or

35
00:01:36.360 --> 00:01:40.990
to go through a subset
of items in an array or

36
00:01:40.990 --> 00:01:44.410
perform an action just on certain items.

00:01:44.410 --> 00:01:46.590
So that is what we wanna
take a look at today, so

00:01:46.590 --> 00:01:48.150
let's take a look at my screen here.

39

And we'll start with our basic

40
00:01:51.324 --> 00:01:53.210
I've got my screen kind of flip-flopped.

Makes a little more sense I

42
00:01:56.310 --> 00:01:58.250
I've got our syntax up at the top.

43
00:01:58.250 --> 00:02:01.310
And it starts with a keyword for, right?

44
00:02:01.310 --> 00:02:05.140
And then you have open parenthesis, and
then this is just the syntax, right,

45
00:02:05.140 --> 00:02:09.112
so don't look at the greater than,
less than symbols or things like that.

46
00:02:09.112 --> 00:02:11.990
We're gonna have a init initializer,

47
00:02:11.990 --> 00:02:16.162
a counter basically that we're gonna

48
00:02:16.162 --> 00:02:19.370
We're gonna have a condition, right,

49
00:02:19.370 --> 00:02:22.840
that helps me control how many
times I go through my loop.

50
00:02:22.840 --> 00:02:27.339
And then my repeat is what

51
00:02:27.339 --> 00:02:31.853
to decide how we are stepping
through our for statement.

52
00:02:31.853 --> 00:02:36.610
And then we've got our close parenthesis,
open brace, our statement list and

53
00:02:36.610 --> 00:02:37.960
then our close brace.

54
00:02:37.960 --> 00:02:42.982
So that's the basic syntax array
of what we're gonna call a for

55
00:02:42.982 --> 00:02:44.891
loop or for statement.

56
00:02:44.891 --> 00:02:47.110
So I have an example here.

57
00:02:47.110 --> 00:02:52.880
Let's take a look at this one,
I've got for ($i=0.

58
00:02:52.880 --> 00:02:55.490
So, I'm initializing this
little variable here.

59
00:02:55.490 --> 00:02:59.150
Well, I didn't declare it outside,
although you can, with for loops.

60
00:02:59.150 --> 00:03:00.670
So, I'll talk about that in a second.

61
00:03:00.670 --> 00:03:04.440
I'm declaring it right here in the for
statement.

62
00:03:04.440 --> 00:03:07.880
It's only gonna be used internally
in this for statement in this case.

63
00:03:07.880 --> 00:03:10.522
And I've set its initial value to 0.

64
00:03:10.522 --> 00:03:12.190
Then I have a semicolon, right.

65
00:03:12.190 --> 00:03:15.600
We have semicolons
separating the three parts

66
00:03:15.600 --> 00:03:18.610
to our syntax up here
in our parentheses set.

67
00:03:19.760 --> 00:03:23.024
The second one is the condition, right.

68
00:03:23.024 --> 00:03:28.013
And I'm saying $i less than,
remember our operators that

69
00:03:28.013 --> 00:03:32.510
we talked about, -lt less than 10, right?

70
00:03:32.510 --> 00:03:35.166
And then the repeat is gonna be i++,

71
00:03:35.166 --> 00:03:40.241
remember we talked about that operator

72
00:03:40.241 --> 00:03:43.880
So I'm basically saying hey,
when we start, i is gonna equal zero.

73
00:03:43.880 --> 00:03:50.110
And as long as i is less than 10, I want

74
00:03:50.110 --> 00:03:54.540
And every time you go through the block,
I want you to increment i by one.

75
00:03:55.820 --> 00:04:01.400
Then within the block, within my braces,
this is my statement or my code block.

76
00:04:01.400 --> 00:04:04.360
I'm simply calling $i, I'm saying hey,

77
00:04:04.360 --> 00:04:07.810
print i, just as an example for
our show here.

78

does that mean it'll repeat nine times?

79

>> It should, exactly.

80

Well, let's find out,
right, let's test it.

81
00:04:13.730 --> 00:04:16.460
>> Okay.
>> Let's see what happens, okay?

82
00:04:16.460 --> 00:04:20.030
So, we're gonna select that statement
there and I'm going to execute it or F8.

83
00:04:21.030 --> 00:04:24.208
And we'll see it actually
went through 10 times.

84
00:04:24.208 --> 00:04:25.310
>> It started at zero.

85
00:04:25.310 --> 00:04:29.520
>> Yeah because we set that initial
value to 0, it did start with 0.

86
00:04:29.520 --> 00:04:31.544
But the first time through the loop,
right, so

87
00:04:31.544 --> 00:04:33.275
let's think about what happened here?

88
00:04:33.275 --> 00:04:38.380
Firs, I could see the output,
0 through 9 got printed on my screen.

89
00:04:38.380 --> 00:04:43.590
So, each one of these is a pass
through that loop, okay?

90
00:04:43.590 --> 00:04:44.960

PowerShell, so thank you for that, Mike.

320
00:16:49.785 --> 00:16:51.630
>> Mm-hm.
>> We do have a couple of other statements

321
00:16:51.630 --> 00:16:52.990
that we'll need to cover.

322
00:16:52.990 --> 00:16:54.210
So you don't wanna miss that.

323
00:16:54.210 --> 00:16:56.400
But for this show we'll go ahead and
sign out.

324
00:16:56.400 --> 00:16:58.095
I've been your host Cherokee Boose.

325
00:16:58.095 --> 00:16:58.800
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

326

>> See you next time here at ITPro.TV.

327
