[MUSIC]

328
00:17:07.951 --> 00:17:10.870
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO,TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, we will cover Foreach statements. You will learn how Foreach statements are used to iterate through a series of values in a collection of items. Foreach statements are typically used to run one or more commands against each item in an array.
episodes.title: Foreach Statements
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:03.056
Welcome to ITProTV I'm
your host Don [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:03.056 --> 00:00:08.129
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.129 --> 00:00:11.338
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:11.338 --> 00:00:14.603
>> Welcome ladies and gentlemen to
your PowerShell scripting series,

5
00:00:14.603 --> 00:00:16.357
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:16.357 --> 00:00:20.740
In this episode we'll be taking a look at,
Or Each statements.

7
00:00:20.740 --> 00:00:23.528
And with us today back in
studios we have Mr. Mike Rogers.

8
00:00:23.528 --> 00:00:25.227
Thank you for
joining us today Mike, how are you.

9
00:00:25.227 --> 00:00:26.940
>> I am doing great Cherokee,
thank's for having me back.

10
00:00:26.940 --> 00:00:29.770
Excited as always,
yeah we are getting into for Each.

11
00:00:29.770 --> 00:00:31.498
These are truly loops.

12
00:00:31.498 --> 00:00:32.620
We are going to start looking at.

13
00:00:32.620 --> 00:00:35.671
I know we had a I kept calling it I
think our select statements on another

14
00:00:35.671 --> 00:00:37.500
episode, loops.

15
00:00:37.500 --> 00:00:42.660
These are, all right so let's take a look
here or let's start out talking about it.

16
00:00:42.660 --> 00:00:46.185
Sorry, I just threw our directory
off there to use that keyword

17
00:00:46.185 --> 00:00:47.323
let's take a look.

18
00:00:47.323 --> 00:00:50.320
And my screen magically pops up on screen.

19
00:00:50.320 --> 00:00:55.475
Good stuff but for each,
now we're starting to get into.

20
00:00:55.475 --> 00:00:57.713
A good way to start this off.

21
00:00:57.713 --> 00:01:02.861
A lot of times, as I think I've said
before, we end up with multiple items,

22
00:01:02.861 --> 00:01:06.860
like a list of services that
are running on a machine.

23
00:01:06.860 --> 00:01:12.050
Or a list of processes, or
a certain number of log file

24
00:01:12.050 --> 00:01:17.370
entries that we returned, or whatever the
case may be, values that I need to test.

25
00:01:17.370 --> 00:01:23.290
Anyway we have these Arrays, typically,
is how we're going to be storing those.

26
00:01:23.290 --> 00:01:28.110
And there are many times that I
want to run a command, right,

27
00:01:28.110 --> 00:01:32.990
against not the array, but
each item in the array, right?

28
00:01:32.990 --> 00:01:35.740
I wanna do something against
that first item in the array.

29
00:01:35.740 --> 00:01:38.590
Then I wanna do the same thing
against the next item in the array.

30
00:01:38.590 --> 00:01:41.857
And the same thing in
the next item in the array.

31
00:01:41.857 --> 00:01:44.633
So we want to loop through each

32
00:01:44.633 --> 00:01:49.530
item in that array performing
a series of commands.

33
00:01:50.560 --> 00:01:53.067
And that's where our for
each comes in play.

34
00:01:53.067 --> 00:01:57.897
It's actually a very very
easy statement to write,

35
00:01:57.897 --> 00:02:01.750
to read and to use, and it's very handy.

36
00:02:01.750 --> 00:02:06.085
This is typically used when I want to
do something for all of the items in

37
00:02:06.085 --> 00:02:10.287
an array, and that is something that
we do want to pay attention to.

38
00:02:10.287 --> 00:02:13.576
Because there is other
statements we would use,

39
00:02:13.576 --> 00:02:17.761
when we want to do commands against
a subset of items in array.

40
00:02:17.761 --> 00:02:22.909
Like if I only want to run these commands
on five of the ten items in the array,

41
00:02:22.909 --> 00:02:23.660
right?

42
00:02:23.660 --> 00:02:25.272
>> Like an element,
that we talked about before?

43
00:02:25.272 --> 00:02:26.820
>> Yes we're talking about elements yes.

44
00:02:26.820 --> 00:02:34.345
Maybe just the computer name that starts
with s or ending a certain IP Octet.

45
00:02:35.475 --> 00:02:39.175
So not all of the elements in the array
are going to meet my condition.

46
00:02:39.175 --> 00:02:42.765
And I want to fire the commands
only on those ones that do.

47
00:02:42.765 --> 00:02:46.567
That's actually a for loop that we'll
take a look at here in just a minute.

48
00:02:46.567 --> 00:02:51.227
For each many times I wanna do something
against every element in that array.

49
00:02:51.227 --> 00:02:53.297
And that's where my for
each coming to play.

50
00:02:53.297 --> 00:02:57.590
It makes it extremely easy
to work with arrays and

51
00:02:57.590 --> 00:03:01.264
to do commands on each item in that array.

52
00:03:01.264 --> 00:03:06.170
Well, in fact I was playing with
another language not too long ago.

53
00:03:06.170 --> 00:03:11.120
Working on a little project with
an Adreno which uses their own

54
00:03:11.120 --> 00:03:15.795
kind of modified, or limited,
I wanna say it's a C++.

55
00:03:15.795 --> 00:03:20.315
If I remember that correctly, but anyways
they don't have this capability in my

56
00:03:20.315 --> 00:03:24.701
Adreno code so rifling through an array,
I have to know how many elements are in

57
00:03:24.701 --> 00:03:28.772
there, I have to use counters to keep
track of where I'm at in the array.

58
00:03:28.772 --> 00:03:32.690
With a foreach like we can do here in
PowerShell, I can just throw it at

59
00:03:32.690 --> 00:03:37.285
the array and it's just going to say hey,
for each item in this array, do this and

60
00:03:37.285 --> 00:03:42.080
it doesn't matter if there's two items or
20 items or 2000 items.

61
00:03:42.080 --> 00:03:46.150
It's gonna go through each one of those
one at a time and perform that action.

62
00:03:46.150 --> 00:03:47.620
So extremely handy.

63
00:03:47.620 --> 00:03:50.170
>> Yeah but earlier you had
mentioned in a different show that

64
00:03:50.170 --> 00:03:53.520
there are sometimes like special
cases we should pay attention to.

65
00:03:53.520 --> 00:03:56.718
And when we're talking about our
processing power, and is that something

66
00:03:56.718 --> 00:04:00.439
that would be applicable here, if you're
running something that's pretty taxing?

67
00:04:00.439 --> 00:04:04.196
>> Yeah, yeah, it definitely could be,
it'll be something that you would

68
00:04:04.196 --> 00:04:07.104
have to look at, and monitor,
the fore each itself, for

69
00:04:07.104 --> 00:04:11.188
each loop itself is not really process,
or intensive, or anything like that.

70
00:04:11.188 --> 00:04:12.907
But the fact that you're,

71
00:04:12.907 --> 00:04:17.033
it's the array of 200 that would
be sucking up a lot of memory.

72
00:04:17.033 --> 00:04:19.870
But it is only working
with one object a time.

73
00:04:19.870 --> 00:04:21.877
So if you were doing something against it,

74
00:04:21.877 --> 00:04:25.576
it's not like it's gonna do all 200 at
the same time or anything like that.

75
00:04:25.576 --> 00:04:29.560
So probably not too bad, but definitely
something you'd wanna pay attention to.

76
00:04:29.560 --> 00:04:30.398
>> Okay.
>> Cuz remember,

77
00:04:30.398 --> 00:04:34.522
we did talk about where if I'm resizing
those arrays and there's a lot of elements

78
00:04:34.522 --> 00:04:37.817
in there, It's removing it and
then recreating it [CROSSTALK].

79
00:04:37.817 --> 00:04:41.516
>> Yeah it doesn't like change the deltas
or whatever or add to it or deleting it

80
00:04:41.516 --> 00:04:42.969
>> Exactly it would remove it and

81
00:04:42.969 --> 00:04:45.651
then create a new one with
that element in it all right.

82
00:04:45.651 --> 00:04:50.565
All right so
now let's take a look at my screen here.

83
00:04:50.565 --> 00:04:51.920
There we go look at that.

84
00:04:51.920 --> 00:04:55.887
She's like wait does he mean it this time,
or is that hesitation there,

85
00:04:55.887 --> 00:04:57.134
I know I threw her off.

86
00:04:57.134 --> 00:05:00.395
Thank you for that, Megan.

87
00:05:00.395 --> 00:05:05.203
Four each, right, is my key word,
and then open parenthesis,

88
00:05:05.203 --> 00:05:09.080
dollar sign item in
dollar sign collection.

89
00:05:09.080 --> 00:05:12.472
Again, this is just syntax,
this is not an actual statement,

90
00:05:12.472 --> 00:05:15.289
close parenthesis,
open brace, statement list,

91
00:05:15.289 --> 00:05:18.760
I was like gonna have multiple
statements in here, one or more.

92
00:05:18.760 --> 00:05:25.580
And then close brace, that's my basic
syntax, for my foreach statement right.

93
00:05:25.580 --> 00:05:28.390
The collection is my array.

94
00:05:28.390 --> 00:05:32.380
This is what I want to go through,
though it could be as I have here,

95
00:05:32.380 --> 00:05:36.920
an array of just letters It
could be an array of process, or

96
00:05:36.920 --> 00:05:42.050
services, or computer names,
or whatever user accounts.

97
00:05:42.050 --> 00:05:44.640
You know, whatever the case maybe.

98
00:05:44.640 --> 00:05:46.790
So, that's the collection.

99
00:05:46.790 --> 00:05:51.445
And then, the dollar sign item is
actually a variable that we're gonna

100
00:05:51.445 --> 00:05:53.320
create In the for each loop.

101
00:05:54.380 --> 00:05:57.140
And I can really call it anything I want.

102
00:05:57.140 --> 00:06:01.571
It's what's kind of cool
about it is it gets created

103
00:06:01.571 --> 00:06:04.210
during the run of the for each.

104
00:06:04.210 --> 00:06:09.731
And it doesn't really have to,
let me think of a good way to say this.

105
00:06:09.731 --> 00:06:12.700
Well I will show you in my next example
and I will explain that a little more.

106
00:06:12.700 --> 00:06:16.513
We can put wherever we want there
this is the actual collection or

107
00:06:16.513 --> 00:06:18.740
array that I want to go through.

108
00:06:18.740 --> 00:06:24.080
And then this is what I wanna do to
each one of the items in that array.

109
00:06:24.080 --> 00:06:27.680
So for example,
I have an array here called letters,

110
00:06:27.680 --> 00:06:30.740
I have created it I've got
my assignment operator and

111
00:06:30.740 --> 00:06:35.690
I have assigned multiple values six
different values to this array.

112
00:06:35.690 --> 00:06:41.825
And then in my for each statement I
have for each $ letter in $ letters,

113
00:06:41.825 --> 00:06:46.490
again $ letters is the actual
array that I want to go through.

114
00:06:46.490 --> 00:06:50.800
And this is just saying for each one
of these, for each individual element.

115
00:06:50.800 --> 00:06:54.183
And I call it a letter because
mentally that makes sense to me right?

116
00:06:54.183 --> 00:06:58.200
The array I made plural intentionally.

117
00:06:58.200 --> 00:07:04.652
So there's going to be a collection of
letters or events or processes right?

118
00:07:04.652 --> 00:07:08.300
Or users so
it's probably going to be plural.

119
00:07:08.300 --> 00:07:12.538
And in here I use the singular
to represent one of those items.

120
00:07:12.538 --> 00:07:15.969
So this might be, users, and

121
00:07:15.969 --> 00:07:21.020
I might say for each user in users, right?

122
00:07:21.020 --> 00:07:22.080
I might do something like that.

123
00:07:22.080 --> 00:07:25.495
And let me change those back so
the rest of my lab works, right?

124
00:07:25.495 --> 00:07:29.980
But again, I can call anything I want,
I could say $ sign for every $Bob or Bobo,

125
00:07:29.980 --> 00:07:32.000
or whatever I ended up typing there.

126
00:07:32.000 --> 00:07:36.320
For every dollar sign Bobo in letters,
do this.

127
00:07:36.320 --> 00:07:38.020
And it's going to work just fine.

128
00:07:38.020 --> 00:07:43.590
I would need to change this
to Bobo to make that work.

129
00:07:43.590 --> 00:07:48.434
So what I'm saying is this is just
internal to the loop and it's representing

130
00:07:48.434 --> 00:07:53.055
an individual item from the collection
that I can call it anything right,

131
00:07:53.055 --> 00:07:57.993
but it is a variable, it does start with
the dollar side so I can't call it Bob.

132
00:07:57.993 --> 00:08:00.401
I do need to call it $bottom, right?

133
00:08:00.401 --> 00:08:02.750
I need to make it an actual variable.

134
00:08:03.910 --> 00:08:09.250
It's really stuck on bobo there so
let's change that back to a letter, right?

135
00:08:09.250 --> 00:08:12.790
So for each letter in letters,
I just want to print the letter out.

136
00:08:12.790 --> 00:08:18.820
That's all I'm doing, I'm just calling
the value of this variable, right?

137
00:08:18.820 --> 00:08:22.700
So if I execute this code,
actually let me assign the array here.

138
00:08:23.820 --> 00:08:28.210
Then we will execute that code and
there we go.

139
00:08:28.210 --> 00:08:33.680
I get a printout of each one of those
elements one line at a time, right?

140
00:08:33.680 --> 00:08:37.490
Well, that's a very simple look at a for
each but there's a lot of

141
00:08:37.490 --> 00:08:41.780
subtle things that are going on in
here that make this really powerful.

142
00:08:41.780 --> 00:08:45.680
One, I don't have to know how many
elements are in the array, right?

143
00:08:45.680 --> 00:08:49.054
We could come up here and do this.

144
00:08:51.232 --> 00:08:53.700
All right, oops, ooh, ow.

145
00:08:53.700 --> 00:08:57.394
I'm having trouble with my
selection phase here, gee.

146
00:08:58.620 --> 00:09:03.640
Let's call that H and maybe I or
something like that, right?

147
00:09:03.640 --> 00:09:05.803
So I just changed the length of the array.

148
00:09:05.803 --> 00:09:08.296
I'm not changing anything in my for each.

149
00:09:08.296 --> 00:09:11.001
I am gonna reassigned this though,
that would help.

150
00:09:11.001 --> 00:09:13.681
I'm not changing like for
each statement at all.

151
00:09:13.681 --> 00:09:17.340
And execute it and
notice it goes to each element nice and

152
00:09:17.340 --> 00:09:21.100
tidy and
it didn't require any effort on my part.

153
00:09:21.100 --> 00:09:25.160
So the arrays can be of any size,
they can change, and the for

154
00:09:25.160 --> 00:09:28.770
each loop doesn't have to know
how many elements to expect.

155
00:09:28.770 --> 00:09:31.660
It's automatically gonna start
with that first element and

156
00:09:31.660 --> 00:09:34.970
it's gonna go until it runs out of
elements which is really handy.

157
00:09:34.970 --> 00:09:38.890
When we see for statements and
other kinds of loops, I might have to keep

158
00:09:38.890 --> 00:09:43.680
track of that myself or in my code and
use like a counter variable and

159
00:09:43.680 --> 00:09:46.300
incremented it to go through each and
one of those items.

160
00:09:46.300 --> 00:09:48.380
And have to know how many there are so

161
00:09:48.380 --> 00:09:50.720
I know when to stop as
I'm going through that.

162
00:09:50.720 --> 00:09:53.130
With the for each,
I don't need that, right?

163
00:09:53.130 --> 00:09:55.930
Also notice I didn't have to increment.

164
00:09:55.930 --> 00:09:58.679
Speaking of increment,
I didn't have to say, next letter.

165
00:09:58.679 --> 00:10:02.240
Or letter plus one to move
to the next position.

166
00:10:02.240 --> 00:10:03.348
It did that all on its own.

167
00:10:03.348 --> 00:10:06.180
It said, all right,
I'm gonna take the first element,

168
00:10:06.180 --> 00:10:08.309
the first letter in letters, and do this.

169
00:10:08.309 --> 00:10:12.710
Then I'm gonna automatically move
on to the next letter and do this.

170
00:10:12.710 --> 00:10:16.570
And then to the next one until I
run out of elements in that array.

171
00:10:16.570 --> 00:10:21.490
So all that stuff is built in to that for
each statement.

172
00:10:21.490 --> 00:10:24.690
Makes it extremely easy to work with,
right?

173
00:10:24.690 --> 00:10:29.630
Let's try another example here, I got one,
let's see, $services = getService.

174
00:10:29.630 --> 00:10:32.107
So, if we execute that, right,

175
00:10:32.107 --> 00:10:38.060
now $services should
include all of my services.

176
00:10:39.350 --> 00:10:41.220
And there they are, right?

177
00:10:41.220 --> 00:10:45.480
If we switch this around real quick,
we'll see that I get the status.

178
00:10:45.480 --> 00:10:47.360
I get back their name, and

179
00:10:47.360 --> 00:10:52.990
their display name by default
when I run that command, right?

180
00:10:54.150 --> 00:10:58.200
Then I've got a loop here that says for
each service in services.

181
00:10:59.270 --> 00:11:01.950
Then again, I could have called
this anything I want but to me,

182
00:11:01.950 --> 00:11:05.440
it mentally it make sense for
each service, in services and

183
00:11:05.440 --> 00:11:11.330
I could spelled it out service,
I just put SVC there, I want to do this.

184
00:11:11.330 --> 00:11:14.970
What's really cool what I'm showing
you here is that in this case,

185
00:11:14.970 --> 00:11:19.690
I'm not passing through a single
character, I'm passing through objects.

186
00:11:20.880 --> 00:11:24.480
When I do a Get Service,
this is an object and

187
00:11:24.480 --> 00:11:28.920
that object has several
properties associated with it,

188
00:11:28.920 --> 00:11:33.260
possibly methods as well that it can
perform and I have access to those.

189
00:11:33.260 --> 00:11:37.690
Because as I pass that first element
through, that element is an object and

190
00:11:37.690 --> 00:11:40.170
all of its capabilities
come with that object.

191
00:11:40.170 --> 00:11:41.550
All of its properties,

192
00:11:41.550 --> 00:11:45.130
any methods associated with it
are gonna be available to me.

193
00:11:45.130 --> 00:11:50.270
So here, I'm using my .notation to
access the service.displayname.

194
00:11:50.270 --> 00:11:54.780
I don't want all of the properties, I
just want that one property, displayname.

195
00:11:54.780 --> 00:11:59.090
But for each one, start with the first
service in that big old list and

196
00:11:59.090 --> 00:12:00.330
show me the display name.

197
00:12:00.330 --> 00:12:04.670
Then go to the second object, that next
service and show me the display name.

198
00:12:04.670 --> 00:12:12.215
So if I run this, Notice I get a nice
tidy list of just the display names for

199
00:12:12.215 --> 00:12:16.760
each one of those services that's
apparently running on that system.

200
00:12:18.860 --> 00:12:21.810
And that .notation will come in handy.

201
00:12:21.810 --> 00:12:26.110
Again, remembering that everything
in PowerShell is an object is key,

202
00:12:26.110 --> 00:12:29.300
cuz you can access a lot of stuff and
things you can you might not know.

203
00:12:29.300 --> 00:12:32.140
As you're learning PowerShell and
as you're playing with PowerShell and

204
00:12:32.140 --> 00:12:33.830
trying to figure out what's going on,

205
00:12:33.830 --> 00:12:37.280
one of the best things you can
do is use that tab autofill.

206
00:12:37.280 --> 00:12:38.414
And unlike for Mike,

207
00:12:38.414 --> 00:12:42.579
you don't have to know the first couple
of letters that used to have autofill.

208
00:12:42.579 --> 00:12:43.683
It's the great thing about it.

209
00:12:43.683 --> 00:12:46.355
You do not, watch.

210
00:12:46.355 --> 00:12:48.440
and look at my list that comes up,
all right?

211
00:12:48.440 --> 00:12:52.841
Because I'm here in the ISE,
I get my IntelliSense and

212
00:12:52.841 --> 00:12:55.623
it's looking at what I am typing.

episodes.description: In this episode, we discuss Do statements. You will see how to use Do statements to run code blocks one or more times. You will also learn to control Do statement execution with either a While or Until condition.

episodes.description: In this episode, you will learn how to construct a while statement. While statements run commands in a command block as long as a conditional test evaluates to true.

episodes.description: In this episode, we will use the knowledge from the previous episodes to write a PowerShell script. We will go through the process of taking a repetitive task and creating a script that will help automate the process.
episodes.title: Writing a Script Part 2

be cuz I've told you before I'm

We can't use any kinds of quotations

00:07:45.363 --> 00:07:46.544
It has to be those parenthesis there?

00:07:46.544 --> 00:07:47.723
>> Has to be the parenthesis, yes.

So you got open close brackets around

And really what you should think

Think about your order of operations.

00:08:02.098 --> 00:08:04.071
Right is basically what I'm doing.

00:08:04.071 --> 00:08:08.530
I'm encapsulating this particular

We're just encapsulating

00:08:10.910 --> 00:08:11.460

elseif files isnot

00:27:41.784 --> 00:27:45.251
[SOUND] Confirm dialogue box,
that's what I tried to write there.

579
00:27:45.251 --> 00:27:49.230
This guy right here is
actually based on .NET.

580
00:27:49.230 --> 00:27:50.290
It's going and getting,

581
00:27:50.290 --> 00:27:53.810
cuz it's one of the cool things about
PowerShell, because it's based in .NET.

582
00:27:53.810 --> 00:27:56.239
You can access those classes as well.

583
00:27:56.239 --> 00:27:59.513
We were talking about this the other day,
outside of our episodes,

584
00:27:59.513 --> 00:28:02.450
the fact that arrays in PowerShell
are a little bit limited.

585
00:28:02.450 --> 00:28:07.119
In fact, they don't have like a push and
pop methods to add, remove members, but

586
00:28:07.119 --> 00:28:08.752
the .NET class array does.

587
00:28:08.752 --> 00:28:10.041
So when you create an array,

588
00:28:10.041 --> 00:28:13.770
you can technically create one based
on that class, not PowerShell's class.

589
00:28:13.770 --> 00:28:15.570
Anyway, that's another episode.

590
00:28:15.570 --> 00:28:19.398
This let's just run it,
you're like hush Mike just show me.

591
00:28:19.398 --> 00:28:21.310
>> [LAUGH]
>> There you go.

592
00:28:21.310 --> 00:28:22.403
>> Look at it.

593
00:28:22.403 --> 00:28:24.499
>> So
there's a little dialog box that pops up,

594
00:28:24.499 --> 00:28:27.100
do you want to delete
the remaining files in the folder?

595
00:28:27.100 --> 00:28:28.560
Now this is not my script,

596
00:28:28.560 --> 00:28:34.450
again I borrowed this from the Scripting
Guy in their PowerShell tips of the week.

597
00:28:34.450 --> 00:28:36.310
So I give them full credit for
this, I'll go,

598
00:28:36.310 --> 00:28:38.250
we should go check out
their webpage maybe.

599
00:28:38.250 --> 00:28:41.890
But there is your little dialog box,
so you can see the title,

600
00:28:41.890 --> 00:28:46.874
delete files, the message, do you wanna
delete the remaining files in the folder?

601
00:28:46.874 --> 00:28:51.212
That's what shows up here, and
then she's got a variable for yes, and

602
00:28:51.212 --> 00:28:55.600
then making a button, and
this will delete all files in the folder.

603
00:28:55.600 --> 00:28:59.063
No, retain all files in the folder.

604
00:28:59.063 --> 00:29:02.649
Here they're actually calling
the dialog box, with a yes,

605
00:29:02.649 --> 00:29:04.770
no, or maybe it's here, result.

606
00:29:04.770 --> 00:29:07.300
This is where you're storing
the result of the click, and

607
00:29:07.300 --> 00:29:10.210
then they're using a switch
to see what you selected.

608
00:29:11.520 --> 00:29:14.750
So, if I say no, I get you selected no.

609
00:29:14.750 --> 00:29:16.580
I run that script again, I say yes.

610
00:29:16.580 --> 00:29:17.252
>> So pretty.

611
00:29:17.252 --> 00:29:18.267
>> You selected yes.

612
00:29:18.267 --> 00:29:21.460
Yeah, right.
But it's an actual pop up dialog box, that

613
00:29:21.460 --> 00:29:24.370
you're more than welcome again, if you
wanna take a look at the Scripting Guys,

614
00:29:24.370 --> 00:29:27.850
do a Google search for
PowerShell dialog box tip of the week or

615
00:29:27.850 --> 00:29:30.030
PowerShell tip of the week,
I'm sure you'll find it, and

616
00:29:30.030 --> 00:29:33.670
I'll put a link for it in the show notes,
and I'll put the script up there as well.

617
00:29:33.670 --> 00:29:35.760
But yeah, I thought that was pretty cool.

618
00:29:35.760 --> 00:29:38.567
I almost put it in the show,
>> And I also-

619
00:29:38.567 --> 00:29:39.286
>> And now I did!

620
00:29:39.286 --> 00:29:41.920
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, and I also like how it came right

621
00:29:41.920 --> 00:29:45.840
there in the forefront, and it's not like,
I don't know if you've ever seen

622
00:29:45.840 --> 00:29:51.490
the dialogue boxes that pop-up way in
the background, and you're like [NOISE].

623
00:29:51.490 --> 00:29:51.990
>> Yeah, you're just waiting,
and waiting, and

624
00:29:51.990 --> 00:29:52.578
waiting,-
>> [LAUGH]

625
00:29:52.578 --> 00:29:54.150
>> And there it was.

626
00:29:54.150 --> 00:29:58.541
So, you can definitely do a little
graphical stuff with PowerShell.

627
00:29:58.541 --> 00:29:59.822
We can make forms.

628
00:29:59.822 --> 00:30:03.479
All of that is available in PowerShell but
that's another show.

629
00:30:03.479 --> 00:30:06.430
>> All right, this has been a really
great set of three shows here, Mike.

630
00:30:06.430 --> 00:30:08.920
So, thank you for that, and
thank you for joining us as well, but

631
00:30:08.920 --> 00:30:10.675
it looks like we're out of time for
this show.

632
00:30:10.675 --> 00:30:12.515
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.

633
00:30:12.515 --> 00:30:13.220
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

634
00:30:13.220 --> 00:30:15.098
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

635
00:30:18.631 --> 00:30:24.336
[MUSIC]

636
00:30:24.336 --> 00:30:27.259
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, we take a look at how to create a function in PowerShell. We demonstrate creating the function, and saving the function in a way that lends itself to reusability.
episodes.title: Function Basics
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:01.240
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.240 --> 00:00:07.382
I'm your host [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:07.382 --> 00:00:08.542
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.542 --> 00:00:11.863
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.863 --> 00:00:14.823
>> Welcome ladies and gentlemen to
your PowerShell Scripting series.

6
00:00:14.823 --> 00:00:15.790
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:17.170 --> 00:00:20.600
In this episode,
we'll be taking a look at function basics.

8
00:00:20.600 --> 00:00:23.530
And with us today, back in studio
is we have Mr. Mike Rodrick.

9
00:00:23.530 --> 00:00:24.850
Thank you for joining us today, Mike.

10
00:00:24.850 --> 00:00:25.460
How are you?

11
00:00:25.460 --> 00:00:26.250
>> I'm doing great, Cherokee.

12
00:00:26.250 --> 00:00:27.040
Thanks for having me back.

13
00:00:27.040 --> 00:00:28.150
Excited as always.

14
00:00:28.150 --> 00:00:31.430
And yeah, we're diving into
the world of functions today.

15
00:00:31.430 --> 00:00:33.340
>> Yeah, what's a function Mike?

16
00:00:33.340 --> 00:00:34.270
>> Gonna be a lot of fun hopefully.

17
00:00:34.270 --> 00:00:36.000
It's a good starting question, right?

18
00:00:36.000 --> 00:00:37.720
What the heck is a function?

19
00:00:37.720 --> 00:00:41.240
And really if we wanted to find a function
we could put a definition on it.

20
00:00:41.240 --> 00:00:44.510
We could say it's a collection of
PowerShell statements that we assign

21
00:00:44.510 --> 00:00:45.550
and name to.

22
00:00:45.550 --> 00:00:49.134
It's very similar to what we might
think of as a script, right?

23
00:00:49.134 --> 00:00:52.200
Our script was a collection
of PowerShell statements.

24
00:00:52.200 --> 00:00:53.230
It had a name that we could use.

25
00:00:53.230 --> 00:00:57.350
But a function's a little bit of
a smaller unit, then a script.

26
00:00:57.350 --> 00:01:02.360
A function is a way to take a single

27
00:01:02.360 --> 00:01:07.040
task and kind of encapsulate it,
give it a name.

28
00:01:07.040 --> 00:01:10.470
And then I can call that name and
run that function.

29
00:01:10.470 --> 00:01:13.420
It'll make more sense I
think as we go through here

30
00:01:13.420 --> 00:01:17.410
I like to look at it if we start a little
bit bigger and we look at script, right?

31
00:01:17.410 --> 00:01:18.860
We talked about writing scripts.

32
00:01:18.860 --> 00:01:21.770
We did a couple demos on that and we said

33
00:01:21.770 --> 00:01:26.780
scripts are great ways to encapsulate our
PowerShell code, give us a re-usability.

34
00:01:26.780 --> 00:01:31.200
If there are task that I have
to do on a repeated basis or

35
00:01:31.200 --> 00:01:35.290
some kinda scheduled task or they're
just monotonous, tedious kinda things.

36
00:01:35.290 --> 00:01:38.880
We could try to automate some of that
using scripts like we did with our hey,

37
00:01:38.880 --> 00:01:40.150
let's go check these files,

38
00:01:40.150 --> 00:01:43.650
see if there's any older than 30 days and
move them to the archive folder, right?

39
00:01:43.650 --> 00:01:47.840
Really nice, I didn't have to do it
manually I had a script that we could run

40
00:01:47.840 --> 00:01:49.320
and it did it automatically.

41
00:01:49.320 --> 00:01:51.480
So that was the idea behind a script.

42
00:01:51.480 --> 00:01:55.280
So scripts give us the ability
to take an entire job and

43
00:01:55.280 --> 00:01:59.770
kind of wrap it up, give it a name and
then have the re-usability.

44
00:01:59.770 --> 00:02:05.880
But some of the stuff within the script
could be reused in other places, right?

45
00:02:05.880 --> 00:02:09.700
There might be things that I put in my
script that I find myself putting in

46
00:02:09.700 --> 00:02:11.230
many scripts, right?

47
00:02:11.230 --> 00:02:15.100
Every script that I write seems to
need this particular capability like

48
00:02:15.100 --> 00:02:17.600
converting bytes to terabytes, or

49
00:02:17.600 --> 00:02:22.510
doing a conversion rate from Euros
to Dollars or something like that.

50
00:02:22.510 --> 00:02:26.180
I seem to write a lot of scripts and
they all need that capability.

51
00:02:26.180 --> 00:02:29.880
Wouldn't it be nice if I could bottle that
up, right, capture that little one little

52
00:02:29.880 --> 00:02:34.710
task, converting Euros to Dollars and
set it aside and then with each

53
00:02:34.710 --> 00:02:38.950
script that I write, I don't have to
re-write that code on how to convert,

54
00:02:38.950 --> 00:02:44.970
I can just call that little function
from my script and have that capability.

55
00:02:44.970 --> 00:02:48.970
So now I can add that conversion
capability to any script I write

56
00:02:48.970 --> 00:02:50.460
just by calling that name.

57
00:02:50.460 --> 00:02:53.370
And that's really the idea
behind a function, right?

58
00:02:53.370 --> 00:02:57.910
But they do work a lot like scripts and
the fact that they are given a name,

59
00:02:57.910 --> 00:02:59.610
we're going to call them by name.

60
00:02:59.610 --> 00:03:04.010
We can pass parameters, the functions,
they can return values,

61
00:03:04.010 --> 00:03:08.520
they can be written to accept
data from pipelines, so

62
00:03:08.520 --> 00:03:11.380
they do have a lot of similarities,
I guess, with scripts.

63
00:03:11.380 --> 00:03:15.550
>> Okay, so then at what point would you
not use the term function, but then,

64
00:03:15.550 --> 00:03:17.070
like transition into a script.

65
00:03:17.070 --> 00:03:18.740
Is there a link, or?

66
00:03:18.740 --> 00:03:21.830
>> Yeah, I like to look at,
I usually write scripts.

67
00:03:21.830 --> 00:03:26.550
And as I'm writing script, if I find
something that, again, have to write a lot

68
00:03:26.550 --> 00:03:31.050
every script I use or a lot of the scripts
I use, I find myself writing this code.

69
00:03:31.050 --> 00:03:33.820
And in the beginning, what you'll
find yourself doing is copying and

70
00:03:33.820 --> 00:03:35.030
pasting, right?

71
00:03:35.030 --> 00:03:37.410
You'll go,
I did that in the other script I wrote.

72
00:03:37.410 --> 00:03:42.050
Let me just go copy that code out of
that script and paste it in this one and

73
00:03:42.050 --> 00:03:42.960
I'm good to go, right?

74
00:03:42.960 --> 00:03:47.100
So we can definitely do that but at
some point, you might wanna advance your

75
00:03:47.100 --> 00:03:51.180
PowerShell skills and say let me take
that and turn it into a function

76
00:03:51.180 --> 00:03:55.070
because I'm gonna show you how one,
we can use functions in multiple scripts.

77
00:03:55.070 --> 00:03:58.510
I can also make those available to other
people so if you were writing a script and

78
00:03:58.510 --> 00:04:01.682
you needed to convert Euros to dollars,
I could say, hey,

79
00:04:01.682 --> 00:04:05.250
Cherokee there's a function right here you
can use, just use that in your script.

80
00:04:05.250 --> 00:04:08.410
>> Okay.
>> So functions are smaller than scripts,

81
00:04:08.410 --> 00:04:13.150
right, we use them within scripts, they're
little, usually have a single topic, or

82
00:04:13.150 --> 00:04:15.160
a single task that they perform.

83
00:04:15.160 --> 00:04:21.250
And I might have dozens of functions
within a single script, right?.

84
00:04:21.250 --> 00:04:23.230
Or use multiple functions in this script.

85
00:04:23.230 --> 00:04:26.790
>> Sure like a modular design,
like a subset of that actuals.

86
00:04:26.790 --> 00:04:27.800
>> And I like that term,

87
00:04:27.800 --> 00:04:31.100
that term modular is really what we're
getting out of these functions, right,

88
00:04:31.100 --> 00:04:36.960
the ability to have these little blocks of
code that I can use to build scripts from.

89
00:04:36.960 --> 00:04:39.170
That's really what we wanna think of.

90
00:04:39.170 --> 00:04:41.260
So that's the idea behind a function.

91
00:04:41.260 --> 00:04:42.490
Let's take a look at my screen here and

92
00:04:42.490 --> 00:04:47.740
I'll show you the basic syntax of
a function is simply the keyword function.

93
00:04:47.740 --> 00:04:49.930
And then whatever you
wanna call the function,

94
00:04:49.930 --> 00:04:54.250
the name of the function,
open curly brace, or open brace,

95
00:04:54.250 --> 00:04:59.420
my statements that the function is going
to execute and then my close curly brace.

96
00:04:59.420 --> 00:05:03.550
So very similar to a lot of the other
things that we've done in here,

97
00:05:03.550 --> 00:05:08.360
same naming I don't know if we've really
talked about a lot of naming conventions.

98
00:05:08.360 --> 00:05:11.670
When we write these functions
Microsoft will recommend

99
00:05:11.670 --> 00:05:14.830
that you stick with
PowerShell's naming convention.

100
00:05:14.830 --> 00:05:17.990
Which means there's a certain
set of verbs that I should use.

101
00:05:17.990 --> 00:05:23.700
I think there's not that many verbs,
20 something, I can't remember exactly but

102
00:05:23.700 --> 00:05:28.290
what they would recommend is you stick
with the verbs that already exist.

103
00:05:28.290 --> 00:05:31.690
And if you're creating something new for
example use the word new.

104
00:05:31.690 --> 00:05:36.950
If you're modifying an existing object
with your function use the word set,

105
00:05:36.950 --> 00:05:37.680
that kind of thing.

106
00:05:37.680 --> 00:05:41.330
So kind of follow those don't use
verbs that don't already exist in

107
00:05:41.330 --> 00:05:46.070
PowerShell's language and then the noun
after the dash should represent

108
00:05:46.070 --> 00:05:50.400
the item that it's
performing the action on.

109
00:05:50.400 --> 00:05:55.000
So like if you think of New-ADUser and
I know just from that term I'm

110
00:05:55.000 --> 00:05:58.440
creating new an active
director user account, right?

111
00:05:58.440 --> 00:06:00.045
And that's what they recommend.

112
00:06:00.045 --> 00:06:04.040
Now do whatever you want and
if you're doing them internally just for

113
00:06:04.040 --> 00:06:07.870
yourself doesn't really matter but as you
start to share them, you might get to

114
00:06:07.870 --> 00:06:11.440
the point where you want to publish
this stuff up to the PowerShell gallery.

115
00:06:11.440 --> 00:06:16.490
Share with other PowerShell users in
the community, in which case it is

116
00:06:16.490 --> 00:06:21.040
really important that we do follow those
naming conventions and name them properly.

117
00:06:21.040 --> 00:06:22.840
So I'll try to that in my show here.

118
00:06:22.840 --> 00:06:26.882
I have a bad habit of just
calling them A,B,C,D or

119
00:06:26.882 --> 00:06:29.780
something very none,
>> Arbitrary there, but.

120
00:06:29.780 --> 00:06:35.310
>> Yeah or not following their
format at least with my name.

121
00:06:35.310 --> 00:06:38.910
So, that's just a little bit of
background there on functions.

122
00:06:38.910 --> 00:06:41.210
So let's talk about writing a function.

123
00:06:41.210 --> 00:06:45.680
And really what I wanna do is try to do
like we did with the scripts, where we

124
00:06:45.680 --> 00:06:49.060
kind of work and think through the entire
process of writing the function.

125
00:06:49.060 --> 00:06:51.230
So we'll kind of look at what we've got,

126
00:06:51.230 --> 00:06:55.360
decide that we wanna make a function
out of it and then work our way through

127
00:06:55.360 --> 00:06:59.090
creating that function and
then trying to use that function.

128
00:06:59.090 --> 00:07:00.710
So what I'm gonna do is
Im gonna jump back over,

129
00:07:00.710 --> 00:07:04.920
if you remember if you've watched
our writing in script episodes.

130
00:07:04.920 --> 00:07:08.350
We came up with this one to archive files,

131
00:07:08.350 --> 00:07:12.540
where we were able to pass the path,
the directory we wanted to look in and

132
00:07:12.540 --> 00:07:15.900
the number of days we considered to
be old, and at the point of archive.

133
00:07:15.900 --> 00:07:18.640
And it would scan that directory,

134
00:07:18.640 --> 00:07:22.870
return a list of files that was
older than, or hadn't been modified.

135
00:07:22.870 --> 00:07:25.060
Since that particular
date that we picked and

136
00:07:25.060 --> 00:07:30.330
then give us the option to archive
those into our archive folder.

137
00:07:30.330 --> 00:07:32.600
And will verify that it's still reading,

138
00:07:32.600 --> 00:07:37.020
I do think when we wrote this script
I forgot to do one more thing

139
00:07:37.020 --> 00:07:39.800
because we were already pushing
our time limits I think.

140
00:07:39.800 --> 00:07:45.430
But this might not have been the one
you saw in the scripting episode.

141
00:07:45.430 --> 00:07:48.597
So just to explain if anybody's
going wait I didn't see that one and

142
00:07:48.597 --> 00:07:49.661
what the heck is that?

143
00:07:49.661 --> 00:07:53.466
Remember, we could point it to a directory
and then it would look for files.

144
00:07:53.466 --> 00:07:57.527
If it comes back with 0 files, 0 files
were older than the particular date

145
00:07:57.527 --> 00:08:01.405
There's really no point in popping
up the yes, no dialog box, right?

146
00:08:01.405 --> 00:08:04.523
Because there's zero files to archive,
so if you choose yes or no, I mean,

147
00:08:04.523 --> 00:08:05.806
you don't even wanna bother.

148
00:08:05.806 --> 00:08:06.699
>> It's not doing anything.

149
00:08:06.699 --> 00:08:09.899
>> Yeah, you don't even wanna bother
asking the person because there aren't

150
00:08:09.899 --> 00:08:11.190
any files to archive.

151
00:08:11.190 --> 00:08:16.890
So that's all this was was I just put this
if statement around the entire prompt and

152
00:08:16.890 --> 00:08:20.840
that way if there were no files in
the list, it didn't even bother saying

153
00:08:20.840 --> 00:08:23.660
hey do you want to archive
because that's kind of silly.

154
00:08:23.660 --> 00:08:26.440
Other than that the script
is exactly as we ended with

155
00:08:26.440 --> 00:08:28.540
at the end of our other episode.

156
00:08:28.540 --> 00:08:29.656
So, as I look at this script.

157
00:08:29.656 --> 00:08:30.754
And this is usually the way, and

158
00:08:30.754 --> 00:08:32.550
everybody's gonna work
a little bit differently.

159
00:08:32.550 --> 00:08:36.340
But this is usually the way I work and
I'll come back and

160
00:08:36.340 --> 00:08:40.980
I'll look at this script and I'll think
to myself, I might be able to use this,

161
00:08:40.980 --> 00:08:44.560
I'm looking at this part here
as I go down through the script.

162
00:08:44.560 --> 00:08:49.910
This is pretty specific to my script
this is pretty specific to what we're

163
00:08:49.910 --> 00:08:54.680
doing here in the script but as we get
down here the whole idea of prompting for

164
00:08:54.680 --> 00:08:59.070
yes or no that's something I think I
might be able to use in other places.

165
00:08:59.070 --> 00:09:00.630

episodes.description: In this episode, we take a look at how to create a function in PowerShell. We demonstrate creating the function, and saving the function in a way that lends itself to reusability.
